938 
939 /*************************************************************************
940 Spline fitting report:
941  RMSError RMS error
942  AvgError average error
943  AvgRelError average relative error (for non-zero Y[I])
944  MaxError maximum error
945 
946 Fields below are filled by obsolete functions (Spline1DFitCubic,
947 Spline1DFitHermite). Modern fitting functions do NOT fill these fields:
948  TaskRCond reciprocal of task's condition number
949 *************************************************************************/
950 class _spline1dfitreport_owner
951 {
952 public:
957  _spline1dfitreport_owner();
963  _spline1dfitreport_owner(const _spline1dfitreport_owner &rhs);
970  _spline1dfitreport_owner& operator=(const _spline1dfitreport_owner &rhs);
975  virtual ~_spline1dfitreport_owner();
981  alglib_impl::spline1dfitreport* c_ptr();
987  alglib_impl::spline1dfitreport* c_ptr() const;
988 protected:
989  alglib_impl::spline1dfitreport *p_struct;
990 };
995 class spline1dfitreport : public _spline1dfitreport_owner
996 {
997 public:
1002  spline1dfitreport();
1008  spline1dfitreport(const spline1dfitreport &rhs);
1015  spline1dfitreport& operator=(const spline1dfitreport &rhs);
1020  virtual ~spline1dfitreport();
1021  double &taskrcond;
1022  double &rmserror;
1023  double &avgerror;
1024  double &avgrelerror;
1025  double &maxerror;
1027 };
1028 #endif

1275 
1276 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_LSFIT) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
1277 /*************************************************************************
1278 Polynomial fitting report:
1279  TaskRCond reciprocal of task's condition number
1280  RMSError RMS error
1281  AvgError average error
1282  AvgRelError average relative error (for non-zero Y[I])
1283  MaxError maximum error
1284 *************************************************************************/
1285 class _polynomialfitreport_owner
1286 {
1287 public:

1305  _polynomialfitreport_owner& operator=(const _polynomialfitreport_owner &rhs);
1310  virtual ~_polynomialfitreport_owner();
1316  alglib_impl::polynomialfitreport* c_ptr();
1322  alglib_impl::polynomialfitreport* c_ptr() const;
1323 protected:
1324  alglib_impl::polynomialfitreport *p_struct;
1325 };

1453 
1454 /*************************************************************************
1455 Least squares fitting report. This structure contains informational fields
1456 which are set by fitting functions provided by this unit.
1457 
1458 Different functions initialize different sets of fields, so you should
1459 read documentation on specific function you used in order to know which
1460 fields are initialized.
1461 
1462  TaskRCond reciprocal of task's condition number
1463  IterationsCount number of internal iterations
1464 
1465  VarIdx if user-supplied gradient contains errors which were
1466  detected by nonlinear fitter, this field is set to
1467  index of the first component of gradient which is
1468  suspected to be spoiled by bugs.
1469 
1470  RMSError RMS error
1471  AvgError average error
1472  AvgRelError average relative error (for non-zero Y[I])
1473  MaxError maximum error
1474 
1475  WRMSError weighted RMS error
1476 
1477  CovPar covariance matrix for parameters, filled by some solvers
1478  ErrPar vector of errors in parameters, filled by some solvers
1479  ErrCurve vector of fit errors - variability of the best-fit
1480  curve, filled by some solvers.
1481  Noise vector of per-point noise estimates, filled by
1482  some solvers.
1483  R2 coefficient of determination (non-weighted, non-adjusted),
1484  filled by some solvers.
1485 *************************************************************************/
1486 class _lsfitreport_owner
1487 {
1488 public:
1493  _lsfitreport_owner();
1499  _lsfitreport_owner(const _lsfitreport_owner &rhs);
1506  _lsfitreport_owner& operator=(const _lsfitreport_owner &rhs);
1511  virtual ~_lsfitreport_owner();
1517  alglib_impl::lsfitreport* c_ptr();
1523  alglib_impl::lsfitreport* c_ptr() const;
1524 protected:
1525  alglib_impl::lsfitreport *p_struct;
1526 };
1531 class lsfitreport : public _lsfitreport_owner
1532 {
1533 public:
1538  lsfitreport();
1544  lsfitreport(const lsfitreport &rhs);
1551  lsfitreport& operator=(const lsfitreport &rhs);
1556  virtual ~lsfitreport();

1558  ae_int_t &iterationscount;
1559  ae_int_t &varidx;
1560  double &rmserror;
1561  double &avgerror;
1562  double &avgrelerror;
1563  double &maxerror;

2003 class _rbfmodel_owner

2077 
2078 /*************************************************************************
2079 RBF solution report:
2080 * TerminationType - termination type, positive values - success,
2081  non-positive - failure.
2082 
2083 Fields which are set by modern RBF solvers (hierarchical):
2084 * RMSError - root-mean-square error; NAN for old solvers (ML, QNN)
2085 * MaxError - maximum error; NAN for old solvers (ML, QNN)
2086 *************************************************************************/
2087 class _rbfreport_owner
2088 {
2089 public:
2094  _rbfreport_owner();
2100  _rbfreport_owner(const _rbfreport_owner &rhs);
2107  _rbfreport_owner& operator=(const _rbfreport_owner &rhs);
2112  virtual ~_rbfreport_owner();
2118  alglib_impl::rbfreport* c_ptr();
2124  alglib_impl::rbfreport* c_ptr() const;
2125 protected:
2126  alglib_impl::rbfreport *p_struct;
2127 };
2132 class rbfreport : public _rbfreport_owner
2133 {

2152  rbfreport& operator=(const rbfreport &rhs);
2157  virtual ~rbfreport();
2158  double &rmserror;
2159  double &maxerror;
2160  ae_int_t &arows;
2161  ae_int_t &acols;
2162  ae_int_t &annz;

2171 
2172 #endif
2173 
2174 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_IDWINT) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
2175 /*************************************************************************
2176 IDW interpolation
2177 
2178 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2179  Z - IDW interpolant built with one of model building
2180  subroutines.
2181  X - array[0..NX-1], interpolation point
2182 
2183 Result:
2184  IDW interpolant Z(X)
2185 
2186  -- ALGLIB --
2187  Copyright 02.03.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
2188 *************************************************************************/
2189 double idwcalc(const idwinterpolant &z, const real_1d_array &x, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2190 
2191 
2192 /*************************************************************************
2193 IDW interpolant using modified Shepard method for uniform point
2194 distributions.
2195 
2196 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2197  XY - X and Y values, array[0..N-1,0..NX].
2198  First NX columns contain X-values, last column contain
2199  Y-values.
2200  N - number of nodes, N>0.
2201  NX - space dimension, NX>=1.
2202  D - nodal function type, either:
2203  * 0 constant model. Just for demonstration only, worst
2204  model ever.
2205  * 1 linear model, least squares fitting. Simpe model for
2206  datasets too small for quadratic models
2207  * 2 quadratic model, least squares fitting. Best model
2208  available (if your dataset is large enough).
2209  * -1 "fast" linear model, use with caution!!! It is
2210  significantly faster than linear/quadratic and better
2211  than constant model. But it is less robust (especially
2212  in the presence of noise).
2213  NQ - number of points used to calculate nodal functions (ignored
2214  for constant models). NQ should be LARGER than:
2215  * max(1.5*(1+NX),2^NX+1) for linear model,
2216  * max(3/4*(NX+2)*(NX+1),2^NX+1) for quadratic model.
2217  Values less than this threshold will be silently increased.
2218  NW - number of points used to calculate weights and to interpolate.
2219  Required: >=2^NX+1, values less than this threshold will be
2220  silently increased.
2221  Recommended value: about 2*NQ
2222 
2223 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2224  Z - IDW interpolant.
2225 
2226 NOTES:
2227  * best results are obtained with quadratic models, worst - with constant
2228  models
2229  * when N is large, NQ and NW must be significantly smaller than N both
2230  to obtain optimal performance and to obtain optimal accuracy. In 2 or
2231  3-dimensional tasks NQ=15 and NW=25 are good values to start with.
2232  * NQ and NW may be greater than N. In such cases they will be
2233  automatically decreased.
2234  * this subroutine is always succeeds (as long as correct parameters are
2235  passed).
2236  * see 'Multivariate Interpolation of Large Sets of Scattered Data' by
2237  Robert J. Renka for more information on this algorithm.
2238  * this subroutine assumes that point distribution is uniform at the small
2239  scales. If it isn't - for example, points are concentrated along
2240  "lines", but "lines" distribution is uniform at the larger scale - then
2241  you should use IDWBuildModifiedShepardR()
2242 
2243 
2244  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2245  Copyright 02.03.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
2246 *************************************************************************/
2247 void idwbuildmodifiedshepard(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t nx, const ae_int_t d, const ae_int_t nq, const ae_int_t nw, idwinterpolant &z, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2248 
2249 
2250 /*************************************************************************
2251 IDW interpolant using modified Shepard method for non-uniform datasets.
2252 
2253 This type of model uses constant nodal functions and interpolates using
2254 all nodes which are closer than user-specified radius R. It may be used
2255 when points distribution is non-uniform at the small scale, but it is at
2256 the distances as large as R.
2257 
2258 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2259  XY - X and Y values, array[0..N-1,0..NX].
2260  First NX columns contain X-values, last column contain
2261  Y-values.
2262  N - number of nodes, N>0.
2263  NX - space dimension, NX>=1.
2264  R - radius, R>0
2265 
2266 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2267  Z - IDW interpolant.
2268 
2269 NOTES:
2270 * if there is less than IDWKMin points within R-ball, algorithm selects
2271  IDWKMin closest ones, so that continuity properties of interpolant are
2272  preserved even far from points.
2273 
2274  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2275  Copyright 11.04.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
2276 *************************************************************************/
2277 void idwbuildmodifiedshepardr(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t nx, const double r, idwinterpolant &z, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2278 
2279 
2280 /*************************************************************************
2281 IDW model for noisy data.
2282 
2283 This subroutine may be used to handle noisy data, i.e. data with noise in
2284 OUTPUT values. It differs from IDWBuildModifiedShepard() in the following
2285 aspects:
2286 * nodal functions are not constrained to pass through nodes: Qi(xi)<>yi,
2287  i.e. we have fitting instead of interpolation.
2288 * weights which are used during least squares fitting stage are all equal
2289  to 1.0 (independently of distance)
2290 * "fast"-linear or constant nodal functions are not supported (either not
2291  robust enough or too rigid)
2292 
2293 This problem require far more complex tuning than interpolation problems.
2294 Below you can find some recommendations regarding this problem:
2295 * focus on tuning NQ; it controls noise reduction. As for NW, you can just
2296  make it equal to 2*NQ.
2297 * you can use cross-validation to determine optimal NQ.
2298 * optimal NQ is a result of complex tradeoff between noise level (more
2299  noise = larger NQ required) and underlying function complexity (given
2300  fixed N, larger NQ means smoothing of compex features in the data). For
2301  example, NQ=N will reduce noise to the minimum level possible, but you
2302  will end up with just constant/linear/quadratic (depending on D) least
2303  squares model for the whole dataset.
2304 
2305 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2306  XY - X and Y values, array[0..N-1,0..NX].
2307  First NX columns contain X-values, last column contain
2308  Y-values.
2309  N - number of nodes, N>0.
2310  NX - space dimension, NX>=1.
2311  D - nodal function degree, either:
2312  * 1 linear model, least squares fitting. Simpe model for
2313  datasets too small for quadratic models (or for very
2314  noisy problems).
2315  * 2 quadratic model, least squares fitting. Best model
2316  available (if your dataset is large enough).
2317  NQ - number of points used to calculate nodal functions. NQ should
2318  be significantly larger than 1.5 times the number of
2319  coefficients in a nodal function to overcome effects of noise:
2320  * larger than 1.5*(1+NX) for linear model,
2321  * larger than 3/4*(NX+2)*(NX+1) for quadratic model.
2322  Values less than this threshold will be silently increased.
2323  NW - number of points used to calculate weights and to interpolate.
2324  Required: >=2^NX+1, values less than this threshold will be
2325  silently increased.
2326  Recommended value: about 2*NQ or larger
2327 
2328 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2329  Z - IDW interpolant.
2330 
2331 NOTES:
2332  * best results are obtained with quadratic models, linear models are not
2333  recommended to use unless you are pretty sure that it is what you want
2334  * this subroutine is always succeeds (as long as correct parameters are
2335  passed).
2336  * see 'Multivariate Interpolation of Large Sets of Scattered Data' by
2337  Robert J. Renka for more information on this algorithm.
2338 
2339 
2340  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2341  Copyright 02.03.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
2342 *************************************************************************/
2343 void idwbuildnoisy(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t nx, const ae_int_t d, const ae_int_t nq, const ae_int_t nw, idwinterpolant &z, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2344 #endif
2345 
2346 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_RATINT) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
2347 /*************************************************************************
2348 Rational interpolation using barycentric formula
2349 
2350 F(t) = SUM(i=0,n-1,w[i]*f[i]/(t-x[i])) / SUM(i=0,n-1,w[i]/(t-x[i]))
2351 
2352 Input parameters:
2353  B - barycentric interpolant built with one of model building
2354  subroutines.
2355  T - interpolation point
2356 
2357 Result:
2358  barycentric interpolant F(t)
2359 
2360  -- ALGLIB --
2361  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2362 *************************************************************************/
2363 double barycentriccalc(const barycentricinterpolant &b, const double t, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2364 
2365 
2366 /*************************************************************************
2367 Differentiation of barycentric interpolant: first derivative.
2368 
2369 Algorithm used in this subroutine is very robust and should not fail until
2370 provided with values too close to MaxRealNumber (usually MaxRealNumber/N
2371 or greater will overflow).
2372 
2373 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2374  B - barycentric interpolant built with one of model building
2375  subroutines.
2376  T - interpolation point
2377 
2378 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2379  F - barycentric interpolant at T
2380  DF - first derivative
2381 
2382 NOTE
2383 
2384 
2385  -- ALGLIB --
2386  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2387 *************************************************************************/
2388 void barycentricdiff1(const barycentricinterpolant &b, const double t, double &f, double &df, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2389 
2390 
2391 /*************************************************************************
2392 Differentiation of barycentric interpolant: first/second derivatives.
2393 
2394 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2395  B - barycentric interpolant built with one of model building
2396  subroutines.
2397  T - interpolation point
2398 
2399 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2400  F - barycentric interpolant at T
2401  DF - first derivative
2402  D2F - second derivative
2403 
2404 NOTE: this algorithm may fail due to overflow/underflor if used on data
2405 whose values are close to MaxRealNumber or MinRealNumber. Use more robust
2406 BarycentricDiff1() subroutine in such cases.
2407 
2408 
2409  -- ALGLIB --
2410  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2411 *************************************************************************/
2412 void barycentricdiff2(const barycentricinterpolant &b, const double t, double &f, double &df, double &d2f, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2413 
2414 
2415 /*************************************************************************
2416 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the argument.
2417 
2418 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2419  B - rational interpolant in barycentric form
2420  CA, CB - transformation coefficients: x = CA*t + CB
2421 
2422 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2423  B - transformed interpolant with X replaced by T
2424 
2425  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2426  Copyright 19.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2427 *************************************************************************/
2428 void barycentriclintransx(const barycentricinterpolant &b, const double ca, const double cb, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2429 
2430 
2431 /*************************************************************************
2432 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the barycentric
2433 interpolant.
2434 
2435 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2436  B - rational interpolant in barycentric form
2437  CA, CB - transformation coefficients: B2(x) = CA*B(x) + CB
2438 
2439 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2440  B - transformed interpolant
2441 
2442  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2443  Copyright 19.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2444 *************************************************************************/
2445 void barycentriclintransy(const barycentricinterpolant &b, const double ca, const double cb, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2446 
2447 
2448 /*************************************************************************
2449 Extracts X/Y/W arrays from rational interpolant
2450 
2451 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2452  B - barycentric interpolant
2453 
2454 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2455  N - nodes count, N>0
2456  X - interpolation nodes, array[0..N-1]
2457  F - function values, array[0..N-1]
2458  W - barycentric weights, array[0..N-1]
2459 
2460  -- ALGLIB --
2461  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2462 *************************************************************************/
2463 void barycentricunpack(const barycentricinterpolant &b, ae_int_t &n, real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, real_1d_array &w, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2464 
2465 
2466 /*************************************************************************
2467 Rational interpolant from X/Y/W arrays
2468 
2469 F(t) = SUM(i=0,n-1,w[i]*f[i]/(t-x[i])) / SUM(i=0,n-1,w[i]/(t-x[i]))
2470 
2471 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2472  X - interpolation nodes, array[0..N-1]
2473  F - function values, array[0..N-1]
2474  W - barycentric weights, array[0..N-1]
2475  N - nodes count, N>0
2476 
2477 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2478  B - barycentric interpolant built from (X, Y, W)
2479 
2480  -- ALGLIB --
2481  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2482 *************************************************************************/
2483 void barycentricbuildxyw(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t n, barycentricinterpolant &b, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2484 
2485 
2486 /*************************************************************************
2487 Rational interpolant without poles
2488 
2489 The subroutine constructs the rational interpolating function without real
2490 poles (see 'Barycentric rational interpolation with no poles and high
2491 rates of approximation', Michael S. Floater. and Kai Hormann, for more
2492 information on this subject).
2493 
2494 Input parameters:
2495  X - interpolation nodes, array[0..N-1].
2496  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
2497  N - number of nodes, N>0.
2498  D - order of the interpolation scheme, 0 <= D <= N-1.
2499  D<0 will cause an error.
2500  D>=N it will be replaced with D=N-1.
2501  if you don't know what D to choose, use small value about 3-5.
2502 
2503 Output parameters:
2504  B - barycentric interpolant.
2505 
2506 Note:
2507  this algorithm always succeeds and calculates the weights with close
2508  to machine precision.
2509 
2510  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2511  Copyright 17.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2512 *************************************************************************/
2513 void barycentricbuildfloaterhormann(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t d, barycentricinterpolant &b, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2514 #endif
2515 
2516 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_FITSPHERE) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
2517 /*************************************************************************
2518 Fits least squares (LS) circle (or NX-dimensional sphere) to data (a set
2519 of points in NX-dimensional space).
2520 
2521 Least squares circle minimizes sum of squared deviations between distances
2522 from points to the center and some "candidate" radius, which is also
2523 fitted to the data.
2524 
2525 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2526  XY - array[NPoints,NX] (or larger), contains dataset.
2527  One row = one point in NX-dimensional space.
2528  NPoints - dataset size, NPoints>0
2529  NX - space dimensionality, NX>0 (1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and so on)
2530 
2531 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2532  CX - central point for a sphere
2533  R - radius
2534 
2535  -- ALGLIB --
2536  Copyright 07.05.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
2537 *************************************************************************/
2538 void fitspherels(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nx, real_1d_array &cx, double &r, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2539 
2540 
2541 /*************************************************************************
2542 Fits minimum circumscribed (MC) circle (or NX-dimensional sphere) to data
2543 (a set of points in NX-dimensional space).
2544 
2545 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2546  XY - array[NPoints,NX] (or larger), contains dataset.
2547  One row = one point in NX-dimensional space.
2548  NPoints - dataset size, NPoints>0
2549  NX - space dimensionality, NX>0 (1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and so on)
2550 
2551 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2552  CX - central point for a sphere
2553  RHi - radius
2554 
2555 NOTE: this function is an easy-to-use wrapper around more powerful "expert"
2556  function fitspherex().
2557 
2558  This wrapper is optimized for ease of use and stability - at the
2559  cost of somewhat lower performance (we have to use very tight
2560  stopping criteria for inner optimizer because we want to make sure
2561  that it will converge on any dataset).
2562 
2563  If you are ready to experiment with settings of "expert" function,
2564  you can achieve ~2-4x speedup over standard "bulletproof" settings.
2565 
2566 
2567  -- ALGLIB --
2568  Copyright 14.04.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
2569 *************************************************************************/
2570 void fitspheremc(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nx, real_1d_array &cx, double &rhi, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2571 
2572 
2573 /*************************************************************************
2574 Fits maximum inscribed circle (or NX-dimensional sphere) to data (a set of
2575 points in NX-dimensional space).
2576 
2577 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2578  XY - array[NPoints,NX] (or larger), contains dataset.
2579  One row = one point in NX-dimensional space.
2580  NPoints - dataset size, NPoints>0
2581  NX - space dimensionality, NX>0 (1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and so on)
2582 
2583 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2584  CX - central point for a sphere
2585  RLo - radius
2586 
2587 NOTE: this function is an easy-to-use wrapper around more powerful "expert"
2588  function fitspherex().
2589 
2590  This wrapper is optimized for ease of use and stability - at the
2591  cost of somewhat lower performance (we have to use very tight
2592  stopping criteria for inner optimizer because we want to make sure
2593  that it will converge on any dataset).
2594 
2595  If you are ready to experiment with settings of "expert" function,
2596  you can achieve ~2-4x speedup over standard "bulletproof" settings.
2597 
2598 
2599  -- ALGLIB --
2600  Copyright 14.04.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
2601 *************************************************************************/
2602 void fitspheremi(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nx, real_1d_array &cx, double &rlo, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2603 
2604 
2605 /*************************************************************************
2606 Fits minimum zone circle (or NX-dimensional sphere) to data (a set of
2607 points in NX-dimensional space).
2608 
2609 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2610  XY - array[NPoints,NX] (or larger), contains dataset.
2611  One row = one point in NX-dimensional space.
2612  NPoints - dataset size, NPoints>0
2613  NX - space dimensionality, NX>0 (1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and so on)
2614 
2615 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2616  CX - central point for a sphere
2617  RLo - radius of inscribed circle
2618  RHo - radius of circumscribed circle
2619 
2620 NOTE: this function is an easy-to-use wrapper around more powerful "expert"
2621  function fitspherex().
2622 
2623  This wrapper is optimized for ease of use and stability - at the
2624  cost of somewhat lower performance (we have to use very tight
2625  stopping criteria for inner optimizer because we want to make sure
2626  that it will converge on any dataset).
2627 
2628  If you are ready to experiment with settings of "expert" function,
2629  you can achieve ~2-4x speedup over standard "bulletproof" settings.
2630 
2631 
2632  -- ALGLIB --
2633  Copyright 14.04.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
2634 *************************************************************************/
2635 void fitspheremz(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nx, real_1d_array &cx, double &rlo, double &rhi, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2636 
2637 
2638 /*************************************************************************
2639 Fitting minimum circumscribed, maximum inscribed or minimum zone circles
2640 (or NX-dimensional spheres) to data (a set of points in NX-dimensional
2641 space).
2642 
2643 This is expert function which allows to tweak many parameters of
2644 underlying nonlinear solver:
2645 * stopping criteria for inner iterations
2646 * number of outer iterations
2647 * penalty coefficient used to handle nonlinear constraints (we convert
2648  unconstrained nonsmooth optimization problem ivolving max() and/or min()
2649  operations to quadratically constrained smooth one).
2650 
2651 You may tweak all these parameters or only some of them, leaving other
2652 ones at their default state - just specify zero value, and solver will
2653 fill it with appropriate default one.
2654 
2655 These comments also include some discussion of approach used to handle
2656 such unusual fitting problem, its stability, drawbacks of alternative
2657 methods, and convergence properties.
2658 
2659 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2660  XY - array[NPoints,NX] (or larger), contains dataset.
2661  One row = one point in NX-dimensional space.
2662  NPoints - dataset size, NPoints>0
2663  NX - space dimensionality, NX>0 (1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and so on)
2664  ProblemType-used to encode problem type:
2665  * 0 for least squares circle
2666  * 1 for minimum circumscribed circle/sphere fitting (MC)
2667  * 2 for maximum inscribed circle/sphere fitting (MI)
2668  * 3 for minimum zone circle fitting (difference between
2669  Rhi and Rlo is minimized), denoted as MZ
2670  EpsX - stopping condition for NLC optimizer:
2671  * must be non-negative
2672  * use 0 to choose default value (1.0E-12 is used by default)
2673  * you may specify larger values, up to 1.0E-6, if you want
2674  to speed-up solver; NLC solver performs several
2675  preconditioned outer iterations, so final result
2676  typically has precision much better than EpsX.
2677  AULIts - number of outer iterations performed by NLC optimizer:
2678  * must be non-negative
2679  * use 0 to choose default value (20 is used by default)
2680  * you may specify values smaller than 20 if you want to
2681  speed up solver; 10 often results in good combination of
2682  precision and speed; sometimes you may get good results
2683  with just 6 outer iterations.
2684  Ignored for ProblemType=0.
2685  Penalty - penalty coefficient for NLC optimizer:
2686  * must be non-negative
2687  * use 0 to choose default value (1.0E6 in current version)
2688  * it should be really large, 1.0E6...1.0E7 is a good value
2689  to start from;
2690  * generally, default value is good enough
2691  Ignored for ProblemType=0.
2692 
2693 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2694  CX - central point for a sphere
2695  RLo - radius:
2696  * for ProblemType=2,3, radius of the inscribed sphere
2697  * for ProblemType=0 - radius of the least squares sphere
2698  * for ProblemType=1 - zero
2699  RHo - radius:
2700  * for ProblemType=1,3, radius of the circumscribed sphere
2701  * for ProblemType=0 - radius of the least squares sphere
2702  * for ProblemType=2 - zero
2703 
2704 NOTE: ON THE UNIQUENESS OF SOLUTIONS
2705 
2706 ALGLIB provides solution to several related circle fitting problems: MC
2707 (minimum circumscribed), MI (maximum inscribed) and MZ (minimum zone)
2708 fitting, LS (least squares) fitting.
2709 
2710 It is important to note that among these problems only MC and LS are
2711 convex and have unique solution independently from starting point.
2712 
2713 As for MI, it may (or may not, depending on dataset properties) have
2714 multiple solutions, and it always has one degenerate solution C=infinity
2715 which corresponds to infinitely large radius. Thus, there are no guarantees
2716 that solution to MI returned by this solver will be the best one (and no
2717 one can provide you with such guarantee because problem is NP-hard). The
2718 only guarantee you have is that this solution is locally optimal, i.e. it
2719 can not be improved by infinitesimally small tweaks in the parameters.
2720 
2721 It is also possible to "run away" to infinity when started from bad
2722 initial point located outside of point cloud (or when point cloud does not
2723 span entire circumference/surface of the sphere).
2724 
2725 Finally, MZ (minimum zone circle) stands somewhere between MC and MI in
2726 stability. It is somewhat regularized by "circumscribed" term of the merit
2727 function; however, solutions to MZ may be non-unique, and in some unlucky
2728 cases it is also possible to "run away to infinity".
2729 
2730 
2731 NOTE: ON THE NONLINEARLY CONSTRAINED PROGRAMMING APPROACH
2732 
2733 The problem formulation for MC (minimum circumscribed circle; for the
2734 sake of simplicity we omit MZ and MI here) is:
2735 
2736  [ [ ]2 ]
2737  min [ max [ XY[i]-C ] ]
2738  C [ i [ ] ]
2739 
2740 i.e. it is unconstrained nonsmooth optimization problem of finding "best"
2741 central point, with radius R being unambiguously determined from C. In
2742 order to move away from non-smoothness we use following reformulation:
2743 
2744  [ ] [ ]2
2745  min [ R ] subject to R>=0, [ XY[i]-C ] <= R^2
2746  C,R [ ] [ ]
2747 
2748 i.e. it becomes smooth quadratically constrained optimization problem with
2749 linear target function. Such problem statement is 100% equivalent to the
2750 original nonsmooth one, but much easier to approach. We solve it with
2751 MinNLC solver provided by ALGLIB.
2752 
2753 
2754 NOTE: ON INSTABILITY OF SEQUENTIAL LINEAR PROGRAMMING APPROACJ
2755 
2756 ALGLIB has nonlinearly constrained solver which proved to be stable on
2757 such problems. However, some authors proposed to linearize constraints in
2758 the vicinity of current approximation (Ci,Ri) and to get next approximate
2759 solution (Ci+1,Ri+1) as solution to linear programming problem. Obviously,
2760 LP problems are easier than nonlinearly constrained ones.
2761 
2762 Indeed, SLP approach to MC/MI/MZ resulted in ~10-20x increase in
2763 performance (when compared with NLC solver). However, it turned out that
2764 in some cases linearized model fails to predict correct direction for next
2765 step and tells us that we converged to solution even when we are still 2-4
2766 digits of precision away from it.
2767 
2768 It is important that it is not failure of LP solver - it is failure of the
2769 linear model; even when solved exactly, it fails to handle subtle
2770 nonlinearities which arise near the solution. We validated it by comparing
2771 results returned by ALGLIB linear solver with that of MATLAB.
2772 
2773 In our experiments with SLP solver:
2774 * MC failed most often, at both realistic and synthetic datasets
2775 * MI sometimes failed, but sometimes succeeded
2776 * MZ often succeeded; our guess is that presence of two independent sets
2777  of constraints (one set for Rlo and another one for Rhi) and two terms
2778  in the target function (Rlo and Rhi) regularizes task, so when linear
2779  model fails to handle nonlinearities from Rlo, it uses Rhi as a hint
2780  (and vice versa).
2781 
2782 Because SLP approach failed to achieve stable results, we do not include
2783 it in ALGLIB.
2784 
2785 
2786  -- ALGLIB --
2787  Copyright 14.04.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
2788 *************************************************************************/
2789 void fitspherex(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nx, const ae_int_t problemtype, const double epsx, const ae_int_t aulits, const double penalty, real_1d_array &cx, double &rlo, double &rhi, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2790 #endif
2791 
2792 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_INTFITSERV) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
2793 
2794 #endif
2795 
2796 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_SPLINE1D) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
2797 /*************************************************************************
2798 This subroutine builds linear spline interpolant
2799 
2800 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2801  X - spline nodes, array[0..N-1]
2802  Y - function values, array[0..N-1]
2803  N - points count (optional):
2804  * N>=2
2805  * if given, only first N points are used to build spline
2806  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
2807  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
2808 
2809 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2810  C - spline interpolant
2811 
2812 
2813 ORDER OF POINTS
2814 
2815 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
2816 
2817  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2818  Copyright 24.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2819 *************************************************************************/
2820 void spline1dbuildlinear(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, spline1dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2821 void spline1dbuildlinear(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, spline1dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2822 
2823 
2824 /*************************************************************************
2825 This subroutine builds cubic spline interpolant.
2826 
2827 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2828  X - spline nodes, array[0..N-1].
2829  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
2830 
2831 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
2832  N - points count:
2833  * N>=2
2834  * if given, only first N points are used to build spline
2835  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
2836  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
2837  BoundLType - boundary condition type for the left boundary
2838  BoundL - left boundary condition (first or second derivative,
2839  depending on the BoundLType)
2840  BoundRType - boundary condition type for the right boundary
2841  BoundR - right boundary condition (first or second derivative,
2842  depending on the BoundRType)
2843 
2844 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2845  C - spline interpolant
2846 
2847 ORDER OF POINTS
2848 
2849 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
2850 
2851 SETTING BOUNDARY VALUES:
2852 
2853 The BoundLType/BoundRType parameters can have the following values:
2854  * -1, which corresonds to the periodic (cyclic) boundary conditions.
2855  In this case:
2856  * both BoundLType and BoundRType must be equal to -1.
2857  * BoundL/BoundR are ignored
2858  * Y[last] is ignored (it is assumed to be equal to Y[first]).
2859  * 0, which corresponds to the parabolically terminated spline
2860  (BoundL and/or BoundR are ignored).
2861  * 1, which corresponds to the first derivative boundary condition
2862  * 2, which corresponds to the second derivative boundary condition
2863  * by default, BoundType=0 is used
2864 
2865 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
2866 
2867 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
2868 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
2869 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
2870 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
2871 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
2872 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
2873 
2874  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2875  Copyright 23.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2876 *************************************************************************/
2877 void spline1dbuildcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundltype, const double boundl, const ae_int_t boundrtype, const double boundr, spline1dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2878 void spline1dbuildcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, spline1dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2879 
2880 
2881 /*************************************************************************
2882 This function solves following problem: given table y[] of function values
2883 at nodes x[], it calculates and returns table of function derivatives d[]
2884 (calculated at the same nodes x[]).
2885 
2886 This function yields same result as Spline1DBuildCubic() call followed by
2887 sequence of Spline1DDiff() calls, but it can be several times faster when
2888 called for ordered X[] and X2[].
2889 
2890 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2891  X - spline nodes
2892  Y - function values
2893 
2894 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
2895  N - points count:
2896  * N>=2
2897  * if given, only first N points are used
2898  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
2899  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
2900  BoundLType - boundary condition type for the left boundary
2901  BoundL - left boundary condition (first or second derivative,
2902  depending on the BoundLType)
2903  BoundRType - boundary condition type for the right boundary
2904  BoundR - right boundary condition (first or second derivative,
2905  depending on the BoundRType)
2906 
2907 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2908  D - derivative values at X[]
2909 
2910 ORDER OF POINTS
2911 
2912 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
2913 Derivative values are correctly reordered on return, so D[I] is always
2914 equal to S'(X[I]) independently of points order.
2915 
2916 SETTING BOUNDARY VALUES:
2917 
2918 The BoundLType/BoundRType parameters can have the following values:
2919  * -1, which corresonds to the periodic (cyclic) boundary conditions.
2920  In this case:
2921  * both BoundLType and BoundRType must be equal to -1.
2922  * BoundL/BoundR are ignored
2923  * Y[last] is ignored (it is assumed to be equal to Y[first]).
2924  * 0, which corresponds to the parabolically terminated spline
2925  (BoundL and/or BoundR are ignored).
2926  * 1, which corresponds to the first derivative boundary condition
2927  * 2, which corresponds to the second derivative boundary condition
2928  * by default, BoundType=0 is used
2929 
2930 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
2931 
2932 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
2933 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
2934 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
2935 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
2936 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
2937 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
2938 
2939  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2940  Copyright 03.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
2941 *************************************************************************/
2942 void spline1dgriddiffcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundltype, const double boundl, const ae_int_t boundrtype, const double boundr, real_1d_array &d, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2943 void spline1dgriddiffcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, real_1d_array &d, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2944 
2945 
2946 /*************************************************************************
2947 This function solves following problem: given table y[] of function values
2948 at nodes x[], it calculates and returns tables of first and second
2949 function derivatives d1[] and d2[] (calculated at the same nodes x[]).
2950 
2951 This function yields same result as Spline1DBuildCubic() call followed by
2952 sequence of Spline1DDiff() calls, but it can be several times faster when
2953 called for ordered X[] and X2[].
2954 
2955 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2956  X - spline nodes
2957  Y - function values
2958 
2959 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
2960  N - points count:
2961  * N>=2
2962  * if given, only first N points are used
2963  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
2964  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
2965  BoundLType - boundary condition type for the left boundary
2966  BoundL - left boundary condition (first or second derivative,
2967  depending on the BoundLType)
2968  BoundRType - boundary condition type for the right boundary
2969  BoundR - right boundary condition (first or second derivative,
2970  depending on the BoundRType)
2971 
2972 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2973  D1 - S' values at X[]
2974  D2 - S'' values at X[]
2975 
2976 ORDER OF POINTS
2977 
2978 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
2979 Derivative values are correctly reordered on return, so D[I] is always
2980 equal to S'(X[I]) independently of points order.
2981 
2982 SETTING BOUNDARY VALUES:
2983 
2984 The BoundLType/BoundRType parameters can have the following values:
2985  * -1, which corresonds to the periodic (cyclic) boundary conditions.
2986  In this case:
2987  * both BoundLType and BoundRType must be equal to -1.
2988  * BoundL/BoundR are ignored
2989  * Y[last] is ignored (it is assumed to be equal to Y[first]).
2990  * 0, which corresponds to the parabolically terminated spline
2991  (BoundL and/or BoundR are ignored).
2992  * 1, which corresponds to the first derivative boundary condition
2993  * 2, which corresponds to the second derivative boundary condition
2994  * by default, BoundType=0 is used
2995 
2996 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
2997 
2998 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
2999 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
3000 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
3001 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
3002 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
3003 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
3004 
3005  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3006  Copyright 03.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3007 *************************************************************************/
3008 void spline1dgriddiff2cubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundltype, const double boundl, const ae_int_t boundrtype, const double boundr, real_1d_array &d1, real_1d_array &d2, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3009 void spline1dgriddiff2cubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, real_1d_array &d1, real_1d_array &d2, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3010 
3011 
3012 /*************************************************************************
3013 This function solves following problem: given table y[] of function values
3014 at old nodes x[] and new nodes x2[], it calculates and returns table of
3015 function values y2[] (calculated at x2[]).
3016 
3017 This function yields same result as Spline1DBuildCubic() call followed by
3018 sequence of Spline1DDiff() calls, but it can be several times faster when
3019 called for ordered X[] and X2[].
3020 
3021 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3022  X - old spline nodes
3023  Y - function values
3024  X2 - new spline nodes
3025 
3026 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
3027  N - points count:
3028  * N>=2
3029  * if given, only first N points from X/Y are used
3030  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
3031  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
3032  BoundLType - boundary condition type for the left boundary
3033  BoundL - left boundary condition (first or second derivative,
3034  depending on the BoundLType)
3035  BoundRType - boundary condition type for the right boundary
3036  BoundR - right boundary condition (first or second derivative,
3037  depending on the BoundRType)
3038  N2 - new points count:
3039  * N2>=2
3040  * if given, only first N2 points from X2 are used
3041  * if not given, automatically detected from X2 size
3042 
3043 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3044  F2 - function values at X2[]
3045 
3046 ORDER OF POINTS
3047 
3048 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
3049 Function values are correctly reordered on return, so F2[I] is always
3050 equal to S(X2[I]) independently of points order.
3051 
3052 SETTING BOUNDARY VALUES:
3053 
3054 The BoundLType/BoundRType parameters can have the following values:
3055  * -1, which corresonds to the periodic (cyclic) boundary conditions.
3056  In this case:
3057  * both BoundLType and BoundRType must be equal to -1.
3058  * BoundL/BoundR are ignored
3059  * Y[last] is ignored (it is assumed to be equal to Y[first]).
3060  * 0, which corresponds to the parabolically terminated spline
3061  (BoundL and/or BoundR are ignored).
3062  * 1, which corresponds to the first derivative boundary condition
3063  * 2, which corresponds to the second derivative boundary condition
3064  * by default, BoundType=0 is used
3065 
3066 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
3067 
3068 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
3069 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
3070 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
3071 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
3072 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
3073 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
3074 
3075  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3076  Copyright 03.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3077 *************************************************************************/
3078 void spline1dconvcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundltype, const double boundl, const ae_int_t boundrtype, const double boundr, const real_1d_array &x2, const ae_int_t n2, real_1d_array &y2, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3079 void spline1dconvcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &x2, real_1d_array &y2, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3080 
3081 
3082 /*************************************************************************
3083 This function solves following problem: given table y[] of function values
3084 at old nodes x[] and new nodes x2[], it calculates and returns table of
3085 function values y2[] and derivatives d2[] (calculated at x2[]).
3086 
3087 This function yields same result as Spline1DBuildCubic() call followed by
3088 sequence of Spline1DDiff() calls, but it can be several times faster when
3089 called for ordered X[] and X2[].
3090 
3091 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3092  X - old spline nodes
3093  Y - function values
3094  X2 - new spline nodes
3095 
3096 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
3097  N - points count:
3098  * N>=2
3099  * if given, only first N points from X/Y are used
3100  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
3101  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
3102  BoundLType - boundary condition type for the left boundary
3103  BoundL - left boundary condition (first or second derivative,
3104  depending on the BoundLType)
3105  BoundRType - boundary condition type for the right boundary
3106  BoundR - right boundary condition (first or second derivative,
3107  depending on the BoundRType)
3108  N2 - new points count:
3109  * N2>=2
3110  * if given, only first N2 points from X2 are used
3111  * if not given, automatically detected from X2 size
3112 
3113 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3114  F2 - function values at X2[]
3115  D2 - first derivatives at X2[]
3116 
3117 ORDER OF POINTS
3118 
3119 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
3120 Function values are correctly reordered on return, so F2[I] is always
3121 equal to S(X2[I]) independently of points order.
3122 
3123 SETTING BOUNDARY VALUES:
3124 
3125 The BoundLType/BoundRType parameters can have the following values:
3126  * -1, which corresonds to the periodic (cyclic) boundary conditions.
3127  In this case:
3128  * both BoundLType and BoundRType must be equal to -1.
3129  * BoundL/BoundR are ignored
3130  * Y[last] is ignored (it is assumed to be equal to Y[first]).
3131  * 0, which corresponds to the parabolically terminated spline
3132  (BoundL and/or BoundR are ignored).
3133  * 1, which corresponds to the first derivative boundary condition
3134  * 2, which corresponds to the second derivative boundary condition
3135  * by default, BoundType=0 is used
3136 
3137 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
3138 
3139 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
3140 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
3141 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
3142 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
3143 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
3144 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
3145 
3146  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3147  Copyright 03.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3148 *************************************************************************/
3149 void spline1dconvdiffcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundltype, const double boundl, const ae_int_t boundrtype, const double boundr, const real_1d_array &x2, const ae_int_t n2, real_1d_array &y2, real_1d_array &d2, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3150 void spline1dconvdiffcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &x2, real_1d_array &y2, real_1d_array &d2, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3151 
3152 
3153 /*************************************************************************
3154 This function solves following problem: given table y[] of function values
3155 at old nodes x[] and new nodes x2[], it calculates and returns table of
3156 function values y2[], first and second derivatives d2[] and dd2[]
3157 (calculated at x2[]).
3158 
3159 This function yields same result as Spline1DBuildCubic() call followed by
3160 sequence of Spline1DDiff() calls, but it can be several times faster when
3161 called for ordered X[] and X2[].
3162 
3163 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3164  X - old spline nodes
3165  Y - function values
3166  X2 - new spline nodes
3167 
3168 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
3169  N - points count:
3170  * N>=2
3171  * if given, only first N points from X/Y are used
3172  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
3173  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
3174  BoundLType - boundary condition type for the left boundary
3175  BoundL - left boundary condition (first or second derivative,
3176  depending on the BoundLType)
3177  BoundRType - boundary condition type for the right boundary
3178  BoundR - right boundary condition (first or second derivative,
3179  depending on the BoundRType)
3180  N2 - new points count:
3181  * N2>=2
3182  * if given, only first N2 points from X2 are used
3183  * if not given, automatically detected from X2 size
3184 
3185 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3186  F2 - function values at X2[]
3187  D2 - first derivatives at X2[]
3188  DD2 - second derivatives at X2[]
3189 
3190 ORDER OF POINTS
3191 
3192 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
3193 Function values are correctly reordered on return, so F2[I] is always
3194 equal to S(X2[I]) independently of points order.
3195 
3196 SETTING BOUNDARY VALUES:
3197 
3198 The BoundLType/BoundRType parameters can have the following values:
3199  * -1, which corresonds to the periodic (cyclic) boundary conditions.
3200  In this case:
3201  * both BoundLType and BoundRType must be equal to -1.
3202  * BoundL/BoundR are ignored
3203  * Y[last] is ignored (it is assumed to be equal to Y[first]).
3204  * 0, which corresponds to the parabolically terminated spline
3205  (BoundL and/or BoundR are ignored).
3206  * 1, which corresponds to the first derivative boundary condition
3207  * 2, which corresponds to the second derivative boundary condition
3208  * by default, BoundType=0 is used
3209 
3210 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
3211 
3212 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
3213 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
3214 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
3215 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
3216 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
3217 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
3218 
3219  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3220  Copyright 03.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3221 *************************************************************************/
3222 void spline1dconvdiff2cubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundltype, const double boundl, const ae_int_t boundrtype, const double boundr, const real_1d_array &x2, const ae_int_t n2, real_1d_array &y2, real_1d_array &d2, real_1d_array &dd2, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3223 void spline1dconvdiff2cubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &x2, real_1d_array &y2, real_1d_array &d2, real_1d_array &dd2, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3224 
3225 
3226 /*************************************************************************
3227 This subroutine builds Catmull-Rom spline interpolant.
3228 
3229 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3230  X - spline nodes, array[0..N-1].
3231  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
3232 
3233 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
3234  N - points count:
3235  * N>=2
3236  * if given, only first N points are used to build spline
3237  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
3238  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
3239  BoundType - boundary condition type:
3240  * -1 for periodic boundary condition
3241  * 0 for parabolically terminated spline (default)
3242  Tension - tension parameter:
3243  * tension=0 corresponds to classic Catmull-Rom spline (default)
3244  * 0<tension<1 corresponds to more general form - cardinal spline
3245 
3246 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3247  C - spline interpolant
3248 
3249 
3250 ORDER OF POINTS
3251 
3252 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
3253 
3254 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
3255 
3256 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
3257 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
3258 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
3259 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
3260 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
3261 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
3262 
3263  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3264  Copyright 23.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3265 *************************************************************************/
3266 void spline1dbuildcatmullrom(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundtype, const double tension, spline1dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3267 void spline1dbuildcatmullrom(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, spline1dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3268 
3269 
3270 /*************************************************************************
3271 This subroutine builds Hermite spline interpolant.
3272 
3273 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3274  X - spline nodes, array[0..N-1]
3275  Y - function values, array[0..N-1]
3276  D - derivatives, array[0..N-1]
3277  N - points count (optional):
3278  * N>=2
3279  * if given, only first N points are used to build spline
3280  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
3281  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
3282 
3283 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3284  C - spline interpolant.
3285 
3286 
3287 ORDER OF POINTS
3288 
3289 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
3290 
3291  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3292  Copyright 23.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3293 *************************************************************************/
3294 void spline1dbuildhermite(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &d, const ae_int_t n, spline1dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3295 void spline1dbuildhermite(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &d, spline1dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3296 
3297 
3298 /*************************************************************************
3299 This subroutine builds Akima spline interpolant
3300 
3301 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3302  X - spline nodes, array[0..N-1]
3303  Y - function values, array[0..N-1]
3304  N - points count (optional):
3305  * N>=2
3306  * if given, only first N points are used to build spline
