3322 void spline1dbuildakima(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, spline1dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3323 
3324 
3325 /*************************************************************************
3326 This subroutine calculates the value of the spline at the given point X.
3327 
3328 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3329  C - spline interpolant
3330  X - point
3331 
3332 Result:
3333  S(x)
3334 
3335  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3336  Copyright 23.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3337 *************************************************************************/
3338 double spline1dcalc(const spline1dinterpolant &c, const double x, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3339 
3340 
3341 /*************************************************************************
3342 This subroutine differentiates the spline.
3343 
3344 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3345  C - spline interpolant.
3346  X - point
3347 
3348 Result:
3349  S - S(x)
3350  DS - S'(x)
3351  D2S - S''(x)
3352 
3353  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3354  Copyright 24.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3355 *************************************************************************/
3356 void spline1ddiff(const spline1dinterpolant &c, const double x, double &s, double &ds, double &d2s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3357 
3358 
3359 /*************************************************************************
3360 This subroutine unpacks the spline into the coefficients table.
3361 
3362 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3363  C - spline interpolant.
3364  X - point
3365 
3366 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3367  Tbl - coefficients table, unpacked format, array[0..N-2, 0..5].
3368  For I = 0...N-2:
3369  Tbl[I,0] = X[i]
3370  Tbl[I,1] = X[i+1]
3371  Tbl[I,2] = C0
3372  Tbl[I,3] = C1
3373  Tbl[I,4] = C2
3374  Tbl[I,5] = C3
3375  On [x[i], x[i+1]] spline is equals to:
3376  S(x) = C0 + C1*t + C2*t^2 + C3*t^3
3377  t = x-x[i]
3378 
3379 NOTE:
3380  You can rebuild spline with Spline1DBuildHermite() function, which
3381  accepts as inputs function values and derivatives at nodes, which are
3382  easy to calculate when you have coefficients.
3383 
3384  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3385  Copyright 29.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3386 *************************************************************************/
3387 void spline1dunpack(const spline1dinterpolant &c, ae_int_t &n, real_2d_array &tbl, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3388 
3389 
3390 /*************************************************************************
3391 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the spline argument.
3392 
3393 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3394  C - spline interpolant.
3395  A, B- transformation coefficients: x = A*t + B
3396 Result:
3397  C - transformed spline
3398 
3399  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3400  Copyright 30.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3401 *************************************************************************/
3402 void spline1dlintransx(const spline1dinterpolant &c, const double a, const double b, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3403 
3404 
3405 /*************************************************************************
3406 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the spline.
3407 
3408 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3409  C - spline interpolant.
3410  A, B- transformation coefficients: S2(x) = A*S(x) + B
3411 Result:
3412  C - transformed spline
3413 
3414  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3415  Copyright 30.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3416 *************************************************************************/
3417 void spline1dlintransy(const spline1dinterpolant &c, const double a, const double b, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3418 
3419 
3420 /*************************************************************************
3421 This subroutine integrates the spline.
3422 
3423 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3424  C - spline interpolant.
3425  X - right bound of the integration interval [a, x],
3426  here 'a' denotes min(x[])
3427 Result:
3428  integral(S(t)dt,a,x)
3429 
3430  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3431  Copyright 23.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3432 *************************************************************************/
3433 double spline1dintegrate(const spline1dinterpolant &c, const double x, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3434 
3435 
3436 /*************************************************************************
3437 Fitting by penalized cubic spline.
3438 
3439 Equidistant grid with M nodes on [min(x,xc),max(x,xc)] is used to build
3440 basis functions. Basis functions are cubic splines with natural boundary
3441 conditions. Problem is regularized by adding non-linearity penalty to the
3442 usual least squares penalty function:
3443 
3444  S(x) = arg min { LS + P }, where
3445  LS = SUM { w[i]^2*(y[i] - S(x[i]))^2 } - least squares penalty
3446  P = C*10^rho*integral{ S''(x)^2*dx } - non-linearity penalty
3447  rho - tunable constant given by user
3448  C - automatically determined scale parameter,
3449  makes penalty invariant with respect to scaling of X, Y, W.
3450 
3451  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3452  !
3453  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3454  ! of this function:
3455  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3456  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3457  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
3458  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
3459  !
3460  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3461  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3462  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3463 
3464 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3465  X - points, array[0..N-1].
3466  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
3467  N - number of points (optional):
3468  * N>0
3469  * if given, only first N elements of X/Y are processed
3470  * if not given, automatically determined from X/Y sizes
3471  M - number of basis functions ( = number_of_nodes), M>=4.
3472  Rho - regularization constant passed by user. It penalizes
3473  nonlinearity in the regression spline. It is logarithmically
3474  scaled, i.e. actual value of regularization constant is
3475  calculated as 10^Rho. It is automatically scaled so that:
3476  * Rho=2.0 corresponds to moderate amount of nonlinearity
3477  * generally, it should be somewhere in the [-8.0,+8.0]
3478  If you do not want to penalize nonlineary,
3479  pass small Rho. Values as low as -15 should work.
3480 
3481 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3482  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
3483  * Info>0 task is solved
3484  * Info<=0 an error occured:
3485  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD or
3486  Cholesky decomposition; problem may be
3487  too ill-conditioned (very rare)
3488  S - spline interpolant.
3489  Rep - Following fields are set:
3490  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
3491  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
3492  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
3493  * MaxError maximum error
3494  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
3495 
3496 IMPORTANT:
3497  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
3498 
3499 NOTE 1: additional nodes are added to the spline outside of the fitting
3500 interval to force linearity when x<min(x,xc) or x>max(x,xc). It is done
3501 for consistency - we penalize non-linearity at [min(x,xc),max(x,xc)], so
3502 it is natural to force linearity outside of this interval.
3503 
3504 NOTE 2: function automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted
3505 array.
3506 
3507  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3508  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
3509 *************************************************************************/
3510 void spline1dfitpenalized(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const double rho, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3511 void spline1dfitpenalized(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, const double rho, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3512 
3513 
3514 /*************************************************************************
3515 Weighted fitting by penalized cubic spline.
3516 
3517 Equidistant grid with M nodes on [min(x,xc),max(x,xc)] is used to build
3518 basis functions. Basis functions are cubic splines with natural boundary
3519 conditions. Problem is regularized by adding non-linearity penalty to the
3520 usual least squares penalty function:
3521 
3522  S(x) = arg min { LS + P }, where
3523  LS = SUM { w[i]^2*(y[i] - S(x[i]))^2 } - least squares penalty
3524  P = C*10^rho*integral{ S''(x)^2*dx } - non-linearity penalty
3525  rho - tunable constant given by user
3526  C - automatically determined scale parameter,
3527  makes penalty invariant with respect to scaling of X, Y, W.
3528 
3529  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3530  !
3531  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3532  ! of this function:
3533  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3534  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3535  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
3536  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
3537  !
3538  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3539  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3540  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3541 
3542 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3543  X - points, array[0..N-1].
3544  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
3545  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
3546  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations from
3547  given values is multiplied by the square of corresponding
3548  weight. Fill it by 1's if you don't want to solve weighted
3549  problem.
3550  N - number of points (optional):
3551  * N>0
3552  * if given, only first N elements of X/Y/W are processed
3553  * if not given, automatically determined from X/Y/W sizes
3554  M - number of basis functions ( = number_of_nodes), M>=4.
3555  Rho - regularization constant passed by user. It penalizes
3556  nonlinearity in the regression spline. It is logarithmically
3557  scaled, i.e. actual value of regularization constant is
3558  calculated as 10^Rho. It is automatically scaled so that:
3559  * Rho=2.0 corresponds to moderate amount of nonlinearity
3560  * generally, it should be somewhere in the [-8.0,+8.0]
3561  If you do not want to penalize nonlineary,
3562  pass small Rho. Values as low as -15 should work.
3563 
3564 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3565  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
3566  * Info>0 task is solved
3567  * Info<=0 an error occured:
3568  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD or
3569  Cholesky decomposition; problem may be
3570  too ill-conditioned (very rare)
3571  S - spline interpolant.
3572  Rep - Following fields are set:
3573  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
3574  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
3575  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
3576  * MaxError maximum error
3577  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
3578 
3579 IMPORTANT:
3580  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
3581 
3582 NOTE 1: additional nodes are added to the spline outside of the fitting
3583 interval to force linearity when x<min(x,xc) or x>max(x,xc). It is done
3584 for consistency - we penalize non-linearity at [min(x,xc),max(x,xc)], so
3585 it is natural to force linearity outside of this interval.
3586 
3587 NOTE 2: function automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted
3588 array.
3589 
3590  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3591  Copyright 19.10.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3592 *************************************************************************/
3593 void spline1dfitpenalizedw(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const double rho, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3594 void spline1dfitpenalizedw(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t m, const double rho, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3595 
3596 
3597 /*************************************************************************
3598 This function builds monotone cubic Hermite interpolant. This interpolant
3599 is monotonic in [x(0),x(n-1)] and is constant outside of this interval.
3600 
3601 In case y[] form non-monotonic sequence, interpolant is piecewise
3602 monotonic. Say, for x=(0,1,2,3,4) and y=(0,1,2,1,0) interpolant will
3603 monotonically grow at [0..2] and monotonically decrease at [2..4].
3604 
3605 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3606  X - spline nodes, array[0..N-1]. Subroutine automatically
3607  sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
3608  Y - function values, array[0..N-1]
3609  N - the number of points(N>=2).
3610 
3611 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3612  C - spline interpolant.
3613 
3614  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3615  Copyright 21.06.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3616 *************************************************************************/
3617 void spline1dbuildmonotone(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, spline1dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3618 void spline1dbuildmonotone(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, spline1dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3619 #endif
3620 
3621 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_PARAMETRIC) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
3622 /*************************************************************************
3623 This function builds non-periodic 2-dimensional parametric spline which
3624 starts at (X[0],Y[0]) and ends at (X[N-1],Y[N-1]).
3625 
3626 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3627  XY - points, array[0..N-1,0..1].
3628  XY[I,0:1] corresponds to the Ith point.
3629  Order of points is important!
3630  N - points count, N>=5 for Akima splines, N>=2 for other types of
3631  splines.
3632  ST - spline type:
3633  * 0 Akima spline
3634  * 1 parabolically terminated Catmull-Rom spline (Tension=0)
3635  * 2 parabolically terminated cubic spline
3636  PT - parameterization type:
3637  * 0 uniform
3638  * 1 chord length
3639  * 2 centripetal
3640 
3641 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3642  P - parametric spline interpolant
3643 
3644 
3645 NOTES:
3646 * this function assumes that there all consequent points are distinct.
3647  I.e. (x0,y0)<>(x1,y1), (x1,y1)<>(x2,y2), (x2,y2)<>(x3,y3) and so on.
3648  However, non-consequent points may coincide, i.e. we can have (x0,y0)=
3649  =(x2,y2).
3650 
3651  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3652  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3653 *************************************************************************/
3654 void pspline2build(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t st, const ae_int_t pt, pspline2interpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3655 
3656 
3657 /*************************************************************************
3658 This function builds non-periodic 3-dimensional parametric spline which
3659 starts at (X[0],Y[0],Z[0]) and ends at (X[N-1],Y[N-1],Z[N-1]).
3660 
3661 Same as PSpline2Build() function, but for 3D, so we won't duplicate its
3662 description here.
3663 
3664  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3665  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3666 *************************************************************************/
3667 void pspline3build(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t st, const ae_int_t pt, pspline3interpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3668 
3669 
3670 /*************************************************************************
3671 This function builds periodic 2-dimensional parametric spline which
3672 starts at (X[0],Y[0]), goes through all points to (X[N-1],Y[N-1]) and then
3673 back to (X[0],Y[0]).
3674 
3675 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3676  XY - points, array[0..N-1,0..1].
3677  XY[I,0:1] corresponds to the Ith point.
3678  XY[N-1,0:1] must be different from XY[0,0:1].
3679  Order of points is important!
3680  N - points count, N>=3 for other types of splines.
3681  ST - spline type:
3682  * 1 Catmull-Rom spline (Tension=0) with cyclic boundary conditions
3683  * 2 cubic spline with cyclic boundary conditions
3684  PT - parameterization type:
3685  * 0 uniform
3686  * 1 chord length
3687  * 2 centripetal
3688 
3689 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3690  P - parametric spline interpolant
3691 
3692 
3693 NOTES:
3694 * this function assumes that there all consequent points are distinct.
3695  I.e. (x0,y0)<>(x1,y1), (x1,y1)<>(x2,y2), (x2,y2)<>(x3,y3) and so on.
3696  However, non-consequent points may coincide, i.e. we can have (x0,y0)=
3697  =(x2,y2).
3698 * last point of sequence is NOT equal to the first point. You shouldn't
3699  make curve "explicitly periodic" by making them equal.
3700 
3701  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3702  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3703 *************************************************************************/
3704 void pspline2buildperiodic(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t st, const ae_int_t pt, pspline2interpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3705 
3706 
3707 /*************************************************************************
3708 This function builds periodic 3-dimensional parametric spline which
3709 starts at (X[0],Y[0],Z[0]), goes through all points to (X[N-1],Y[N-1],Z[N-1])
3710 and then back to (X[0],Y[0],Z[0]).
3711 
3712 Same as PSpline2Build() function, but for 3D, so we won't duplicate its
3713 description here.
3714 
3715  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3716  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3717 *************************************************************************/
3718 void pspline3buildperiodic(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t st, const ae_int_t pt, pspline3interpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3719 
3720 
3721 /*************************************************************************
3722 This function returns vector of parameter values correspoding to points.
3723 
3724 I.e. for P created from (X[0],Y[0])...(X[N-1],Y[N-1]) and U=TValues(P) we
3725 have
3726  (X[0],Y[0]) = PSpline2Calc(P,U[0]),
3727  (X[1],Y[1]) = PSpline2Calc(P,U[1]),
3728  (X[2],Y[2]) = PSpline2Calc(P,U[2]),
3729  ...
3730 
3731 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3732  P - parametric spline interpolant
3733 
3734 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3735  N - array size
3736  T - array[0..N-1]
3737 
3738 
3739 NOTES:
3740 * for non-periodic splines U[0]=0, U[0]<U[1]<...<U[N-1], U[N-1]=1
3741 * for periodic splines U[0]=0, U[0]<U[1]<...<U[N-1], U[N-1]<1
3742 
3743  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3744  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3745 *************************************************************************/
3746 void pspline2parametervalues(const pspline2interpolant &p, ae_int_t &n, real_1d_array &t, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3747 
3748 
3749 /*************************************************************************
3750 This function returns vector of parameter values correspoding to points.
3751 
3752 Same as PSpline2ParameterValues(), but for 3D.
3753 
3754  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3755  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3756 *************************************************************************/
3757 void pspline3parametervalues(const pspline3interpolant &p, ae_int_t &n, real_1d_array &t, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3758 
3759 
3760 /*************************************************************************
3761 This function calculates the value of the parametric spline for a given
3762 value of parameter T
3763 
3764 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3765  P - parametric spline interpolant
3766  T - point:
3767  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3768  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3769  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3770  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3771  by making T=T-floor(T).
3772 
3773 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3774  X - X-position
3775  Y - Y-position
3776 
3777 
3778  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3779  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3780 *************************************************************************/
3781 void pspline2calc(const pspline2interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3782 
3783 
3784 /*************************************************************************
3785 This function calculates the value of the parametric spline for a given
3786 value of parameter T.
3787 
3788 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3789  P - parametric spline interpolant
3790  T - point:
3791  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3792  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3793  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3794  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3795  by making T=T-floor(T).
3796 
3797 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3798  X - X-position
3799  Y - Y-position
3800  Z - Z-position
3801 
3802 
3803  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3804  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3805 *************************************************************************/
3806 void pspline3calc(const pspline3interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &y, double &z, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3807 
3808 
3809 /*************************************************************************
3810 This function calculates tangent vector for a given value of parameter T
3811 
3812 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3813  P - parametric spline interpolant
3814  T - point:
3815  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3816  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3817  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3818  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3819  by making T=T-floor(T).
3820 
3821 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3822  X - X-component of tangent vector (normalized)
3823  Y - Y-component of tangent vector (normalized)
3824 
3825 NOTE:
3826  X^2+Y^2 is either 1 (for non-zero tangent vector) or 0.
3827 
3828 
3829  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3830  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3831 *************************************************************************/
3832 void pspline2tangent(const pspline2interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3833 
3834 
3835 /*************************************************************************
3836 This function calculates tangent vector for a given value of parameter T
3837 
3838 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3839  P - parametric spline interpolant
3840  T - point:
3841  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3842  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3843  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3844  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3845  by making T=T-floor(T).
3846 
3847 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3848  X - X-component of tangent vector (normalized)
3849  Y - Y-component of tangent vector (normalized)
3850  Z - Z-component of tangent vector (normalized)
3851 
3852 NOTE:
3853  X^2+Y^2+Z^2 is either 1 (for non-zero tangent vector) or 0.
3854 
3855 
3856  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3857  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3858 *************************************************************************/
3859 void pspline3tangent(const pspline3interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &y, double &z, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3860 
3861 
3862 /*************************************************************************
3863 This function calculates derivative, i.e. it returns (dX/dT,dY/dT).
3864 
3865 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3866  P - parametric spline interpolant
3867  T - point:
3868  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3869  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3870  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3871  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3872  by making T=T-floor(T).
3873 
3874 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3875  X - X-value
3876  DX - X-derivative
3877  Y - Y-value
3878  DY - Y-derivative
3879 
3880

3882  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3883 *************************************************************************/
3884 void pspline2diff(const pspline2interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &dx, double &y, double &dy, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3885 
3886 
3887 /*************************************************************************
3888 This function calculates derivative, i.e. it returns (dX/dT,dY/dT,dZ/dT).
3889

3892  T - point:
3893  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3894  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3895  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3896  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3897  by making T=T-floor(T).
3898

3900  X - X-value

3911 void pspline3diff(const pspline3interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &dx, double &y, double &dy, double &z, double &dz, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3912 
3913 
3914 /*************************************************************************
3915 This function calculates first and second derivative with respect to T.
3916 
3917 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3918  P - parametric spline interpolant
3919  T - point:
3920  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3921  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3922  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3923  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3924  by making T=T-floor(T).
3925 
3926 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:

3937 *************************************************************************/
3938 void pspline2diff2(const pspline2interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &dx, double &d2x, double &y, double &dy, double &d2y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3939 
3940 
3941 /*************************************************************************
3942 This function calculates first and second derivative with respect to T.
3943 
3944 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3945  P - parametric spline interpolant
3946  T - point:
3947  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3948  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3949  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3950  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3951  by making T=T-floor(T).

3968 void pspline3diff2(const pspline3interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &dx, double &d2x, double &y, double &dy, double &d2y, double &z, double &dz, double &d2z, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3969 
3970 
3971 /*************************************************************************
3972 This function calculates arc length, i.e. length of curve between t=a
3973 and t=b.
3974 
3975 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3976  P - parametric spline interpolant
3977  A,B - parameter values corresponding to arc ends:
3978  * B>A will result in positive length returned
3979  * B<A will result in negative length returned
3980 
3981 RESULT:
3982  length of arc starting at T=A and ending at T=B.
3983 
3984 
3985  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3986  Copyright 30.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3987 *************************************************************************/
3988 double pspline2arclength(const pspline2interpolant &p, const double a, const double b, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3989 
3990 
3991 /*************************************************************************
3992 This function calculates arc length, i.e. length of curve between t=a
3993 and t=b.
3994 
3995 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3996  P - parametric spline interpolant
3997  A,B - parameter values corresponding to arc ends:
3998  * B>A will result in positive length returned
3999  * B<A will result in negative length returned
4000 
4001 RESULT:
4002  length of arc starting at T=A and ending at T=B.
4003 
4004 
4005  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4006  Copyright 30.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4007 *************************************************************************/
4008 double pspline3arclength(const pspline3interpolant &p, const double a, const double b, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4009 
4010 
4011 /*************************************************************************
4012 This subroutine fits piecewise linear curve to points with Ramer-Douglas-
4013 Peucker algorithm. This function performs PARAMETRIC fit, i.e. it can be
4014 used to fit curves like circles.
4015 
4016 On input it accepts dataset which describes parametric multidimensional
4017 curve X(t), with X being vector, and t taking values in [0,N), where N is
4018 a number of points in dataset. As result, it returns reduced dataset X2,
4019 which can be used to build parametric curve X2(t), which approximates
4020 X(t) with desired precision (or has specified number of sections).
4021 
4022 
4023 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4024  X - array of multidimensional points:
4025  * at least N elements, leading N elements are used if more
4026  than N elements were specified
4027  * order of points is IMPORTANT because it is parametric
4028  fit
4029  * each row of array is one point which has D coordinates
4030  N - number of elements in X
4031  D - number of dimensions (elements per row of X)
4032  StopM - stopping condition - desired number of sections:
4033  * at most M sections are generated by this function
4034  * less than M sections can be generated if we have N<M
4035  (or some X are non-distinct).
4036  * zero StopM means that algorithm does not stop after
4037  achieving some pre-specified section count
4038  StopEps - stopping condition - desired precision:
4039  * algorithm stops after error in each section is at most Eps
4040  * zero Eps means that algorithm does not stop after
4041  achieving some pre-specified precision
4042 
4043 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4044  X2 - array of corner points for piecewise approximation,
4045  has length NSections+1 or zero (for NSections=0).
4046  Idx2 - array of indexes (parameter values):
4047  * has length NSections+1 or zero (for NSections=0).
4048  * each element of Idx2 corresponds to same-numbered
4049  element of X2
4050  * each element of Idx2 is index of corresponding element
4051  of X2 at original array X, i.e. I-th row of X2 is
4052  Idx2[I]-th row of X.
4053  * elements of Idx2 can be treated as parameter values
4054  which should be used when building new parametric curve
4055  * Idx2[0]=0, Idx2[NSections]=N-1
4056  NSections- number of sections found by algorithm, NSections<=M,
4057  NSections can be zero for degenerate datasets
4058  (N<=1 or all X[] are non-distinct).
4059 
4060 NOTE: algorithm stops after:
4061  a) dividing curve into StopM sections
4062  b) achieving required precision StopEps
4063  c) dividing curve into N-1 sections
4064  If both StopM and StopEps are non-zero, algorithm is stopped by the
4065  FIRST criterion which is satisfied. In case both StopM and StopEps
4066  are zero, algorithm stops because of (c).
4067 
4068  -- ALGLIB --
4069  Copyright 02.10.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey
4070 *************************************************************************/
4071 void parametricrdpfixed(const real_2d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t d, const ae_int_t stopm, const double stopeps, real_2d_array &x2, integer_1d_array &idx2, ae_int_t &nsections, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4072 #endif
4073 
4074 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_SPLINE3D) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
4075 /*************************************************************************
4076 This subroutine calculates the value of the trilinear or tricubic spline at
4077 the given point (X,Y,Z).
4078 
4079 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4080  C - coefficients table.
4081  Built by BuildBilinearSpline or BuildBicubicSpline.
4082  X, Y,
4083  Z - point
4084 
4085 Result:
4086  S(x,y,z)
4087 
4088  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4089  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4090 *************************************************************************/
4091 double spline3dcalc(const spline3dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, const double z, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4092 
4093 
4094 /*************************************************************************
4095 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the spline argument.
4096 
4097 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4098  C - spline interpolant
4099  AX, BX - transformation coefficients: x = A*u + B
4100  AY, BY - transformation coefficients: y = A*v + B
4101  AZ, BZ - transformation coefficients: z = A*w + B
4102 
4103 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4104  C - transformed spline
4105 
4106  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4107  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4108 *************************************************************************/
4109 void spline3dlintransxyz(const spline3dinterpolant &c, const double ax, const double bx, const double ay, const double by, const double az, const double bz, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4110 
4111 
4112 /*************************************************************************
4113 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the spline.
4114 
4115 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4116  C - spline interpolant.
4117  A, B- transformation coefficients: S2(x,y) = A*S(x,y,z) + B
4118 
4119 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4120  C - transformed spline
4121 
4122  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4123  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4124 *************************************************************************/
4125 void spline3dlintransf(const spline3dinterpolant &c, const double a, const double b, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4126 
4127 
4128 /*************************************************************************
4129 Trilinear spline resampling
4130 
4131 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4132  A - array[0..OldXCount*OldYCount*OldZCount-1], function
4133  values at the old grid, :
4134  A[0] x=0,y=0,z=0
4135  A[1] x=1,y=0,z=0
4136  A[..] ...
4137  A[..] x=oldxcount-1,y=0,z=0
4138  A[..] x=0,y=1,z=0
4139  A[..] ...
4140  ...
4141  OldZCount - old Z-count, OldZCount>1
4142  OldYCount - old Y-count, OldYCount>1
4143  OldXCount - old X-count, OldXCount>1
4144  NewZCount - new Z-count, NewZCount>1
4145  NewYCount - new Y-count, NewYCount>1
4146  NewXCount - new X-count, NewXCount>1
4147 
4148 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4149  B - array[0..NewXCount*NewYCount*NewZCount-1], function
4150  values at the new grid:
4151  B[0] x=0,y=0,z=0
4152  B[1] x=1,y=0,z=0
4153  B[..] ...
4154  B[..] x=newxcount-1,y=0,z=0
4155  B[..] x=0,y=1,z=0
4156  B[..] ...
4157  ...
4158 
4159  -- ALGLIB routine --
4160  26.04.2012
4161  Copyright by Bochkanov Sergey
4162 *************************************************************************/
4163 void spline3dresampletrilinear(const real_1d_array &a, const ae_int_t oldzcount, const ae_int_t oldycount, const ae_int_t oldxcount, const ae_int_t newzcount, const ae_int_t newycount, const ae_int_t newxcount, real_1d_array &b, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4164 
4165 
4166 /*************************************************************************
4167 This subroutine builds trilinear vector-valued spline.
4168 
4169 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4170  X - spline abscissas, array[0..N-1]
4171  Y - spline ordinates, array[0..M-1]
4172  Z - spline applicates, array[0..L-1]
4173  F - function values, array[0..M*N*L*D-1]:
4174  * first D elements store D values at (X[0],Y[0],Z[0])
4175  * next D elements store D values at (X[1],Y[0],Z[0])
4176  * next D elements store D values at (X[2],Y[0],Z[0])
4177  * ...
4178  * next D elements store D values at (X[0],Y[1],Z[0])
4179  * next D elements store D values at (X[1],Y[1],Z[0])
4180  * next D elements store D values at (X[2],Y[1],Z[0])
4181  * ...
4182  * next D elements store D values at (X[0],Y[0],Z[1])
4183  * next D elements store D values at (X[1],Y[0],Z[1])
4184  * next D elements store D values at (X[2],Y[0],Z[1])
4185  * ...
4186  * general form - D function values at (X[i],Y[j]) are stored
4187  at F[D*(N*(M*K+J)+I)...D*(N*(M*K+J)+I)+D-1].
4188  M,N,
4189  L - grid size, M>=2, N>=2, L>=2
4190  D - vector dimension, D>=1
4191 
4192 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4193  C - spline interpolant
4194 
4195  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4196  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4197 *************************************************************************/
4198 void spline3dbuildtrilinearv(const real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, const real_1d_array &z, const ae_int_t l, const real_1d_array &f, const ae_int_t d, spline3dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4199 
4200 
4201 /*************************************************************************
4202 This subroutine calculates bilinear or bicubic vector-valued spline at the
4203 given point (X,Y,Z).
4204 
4205 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4206  C - spline interpolant.
4207  X, Y,
4208  Z - point
4209  F - output buffer, possibly preallocated array. In case array size
4210  is large enough to store result, it is not reallocated. Array
4211  which is too short will be reallocated
4212 
4213 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4214  F - array[D] (or larger) which stores function values
4215 
4216  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4217  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4218 *************************************************************************/
4219 void spline3dcalcvbuf(const spline3dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, const double z, real_1d_array &f, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4220 
4221 
4222 /*************************************************************************
4223 This subroutine calculates trilinear or tricubic vector-valued spline at the
4224 given point (X,Y,Z).
4225 
4226 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4227  C - spline interpolant.
4228  X, Y,
4229  Z - point
4230 
4231 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4232  F - array[D] which stores function values. F is out-parameter and
4233  it is reallocated after call to this function. In case you
4234  want to reuse previously allocated F, you may use
4235  Spline2DCalcVBuf(), which reallocates F only when it is too
4236  small.
4237 
4238  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4239  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4240 *************************************************************************/
4241 void spline3dcalcv(const spline3dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, const double z, real_1d_array &f, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4242 
4243 
4244 /*************************************************************************
4245 This subroutine unpacks tri-dimensional spline into the coefficients table
4246 
4247 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4248  C - spline interpolant.
4249 
4250 Result:
4251  N - grid size (X)
4252  M - grid size (Y)
4253  L - grid size (Z)
4254  D - number of components
4255  SType- spline type. Currently, only one spline type is supported:
4256  trilinear spline, as indicated by SType=1.
4257  Tbl - spline coefficients: [0..(N-1)*(M-1)*(L-1)*D-1, 0..13].
4258  For T=0..D-1 (component index), I = 0...N-2 (x index),
4259  J=0..M-2 (y index), K=0..L-2 (z index):
4260  Q := T + I*D + J*D*(N-1) + K*D*(N-1)*(M-1),
4261 
4262  Q-th row stores decomposition for T-th component of the
4263  vector-valued function
4264 
4265  Tbl[Q,0] = X[i]
4266  Tbl[Q,1] = X[i+1]
4267  Tbl[Q,2] = Y[j]
4268  Tbl[Q,3] = Y[j+1]
4269  Tbl[Q,4] = Z[k]
4270  Tbl[Q,5] = Z[k+1]
4271 
4272  Tbl[Q,6] = C000
4273  Tbl[Q,7] = C100
4274  Tbl[Q,8] = C010
4275  Tbl[Q,9] = C110
4276  Tbl[Q,10]= C001
4277  Tbl[Q,11]= C101
4278  Tbl[Q,12]= C011
4279  Tbl[Q,13]= C111
4280  On each grid square spline is equals to:
4281  S(x) = SUM(c[i,j,k]*(x^i)*(y^j)*(z^k), i=0..1, j=0..1, k=0..1)
4282  t = x-x[j]
4283  u = y-y[i]
4284  v = z-z[k]
4285 
4286  NOTE: format of Tbl is given for SType=1. Future versions of
4287  ALGLIB can use different formats for different values of
4288  SType.
4289 
4290  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4291  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4292 *************************************************************************/
4293 void spline3dunpackv(const spline3dinterpolant &c, ae_int_t &n, ae_int_t &m, ae_int_t &l, ae_int_t &d, ae_int_t &stype, real_2d_array &tbl, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4294 #endif
4295 
4296 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_POLINT) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
4297 /*************************************************************************
4298 Conversion from barycentric representation to Chebyshev basis.
4299 This function has O(N^2) complexity.
4300 
4301 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4302  P - polynomial in barycentric form
4303  A,B - base interval for Chebyshev polynomials (see below)
4304  A<>B
4305 
4306 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
4307  T - coefficients of Chebyshev representation;
4308  P(x) = sum { T[i]*Ti(2*(x-A)/(B-A)-1), i=0..N-1 },
4309  where Ti - I-th Chebyshev polynomial.
4310 
4311 NOTES:
4312  barycentric interpolant passed as P may be either polynomial obtained
4313  from polynomial interpolation/ fitting or rational function which is
4314  NOT polynomial. We can't distinguish between these two cases, and this
4315  algorithm just tries to work assuming that P IS a polynomial. If not,
4316  algorithm will return results, but they won't have any meaning.
4317 
4318  -- ALGLIB --
4319  Copyright 30.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4320 *************************************************************************/
4321 void polynomialbar2cheb(const barycentricinterpolant &p, const double a, const double b, real_1d_array &t, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4322 
4323 
4324 /*************************************************************************
4325 Conversion from Chebyshev basis to barycentric representation.
4326 This function has O(N^2) complexity.
4327 
4328 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4329  T - coefficients of Chebyshev representation;
4330  P(x) = sum { T[i]*Ti(2*(x-A)/(B-A)-1), i=0..N },
4331  where Ti - I-th Chebyshev polynomial.
4332  N - number of coefficients:
4333  * if given, only leading N elements of T are used
4334  * if not given, automatically determined from size of T
4335  A,B - base interval for Chebyshev polynomials (see above)
4336  A<B
4337 
4338 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
4339  P - polynomial in barycentric form
4340 
4341  -- ALGLIB --
4342  Copyright 30.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4343 *************************************************************************/
4344 void polynomialcheb2bar(const real_1d_array &t, const ae_int_t n, const double a, const double b, barycentricinterpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4345 void polynomialcheb2bar(const real_1d_array &t, const double a, const double b, barycentricinterpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4346 
4347 
4348 /*************************************************************************
4349 Conversion from barycentric representation to power basis.
4350 This function has O(N^2) complexity.
4351 
4352 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4353  P - polynomial in barycentric form
4354  C - offset (see below); 0.0 is used as default value.
4355  S - scale (see below); 1.0 is used as default value. S<>0.
4356 
4357 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
4358  A - coefficients, P(x) = sum { A[i]*((X-C)/S)^i, i=0..N-1 }
4359  N - number of coefficients (polynomial degree plus 1)
4360 
4361 NOTES:
4362 1. this function accepts offset and scale, which can be set to improve
4363  numerical properties of polynomial. For example, if P was obtained as
4364  result of interpolation on [-1,+1], you can set C=0 and S=1 and
4365  represent P as sum of 1, x, x^2, x^3 and so on. In most cases you it
4366  is exactly what you need.
4367 
4368  However, if your interpolation model was built on [999,1001], you will
4369  see significant growth of numerical errors when using {1, x, x^2, x^3}
4370  as basis. Representing P as sum of 1, (x-1000), (x-1000)^2, (x-1000)^3
4371  will be better option. Such representation can be obtained by using
4372  1000.0 as offset C and 1.0 as scale S.
4373 
4374 2. power basis is ill-conditioned and tricks described above can't solve
4375  this problem completely. This function will return coefficients in
4376  any case, but for N>8 they will become unreliable. However, N's
4377  less than 5 are pretty safe.
4378 
4379 3. barycentric interpolant passed as P may be either polynomial obtained
4380  from polynomial interpolation/ fitting or rational function which is
4381  NOT polynomial. We can't distinguish between these two cases, and this
4382  algorithm just tries to work assuming that P IS a polynomial. If not,
4383  algorithm will return results, but they won't have any meaning.
4384 
4385  -- ALGLIB --
4386  Copyright 30.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4387 *************************************************************************/
4388 void polynomialbar2pow(const barycentricinterpolant &p, const double c, const double s, real_1d_array &a, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4389 void polynomialbar2pow(const barycentricinterpolant &p, real_1d_array &a, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4390 
4391 
4392 /*************************************************************************
4393 Conversion from power basis to barycentric representation.
4394 This function has O(N^2) complexity.
4395 
4396 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4397  A - coefficients, P(x) = sum { A[i]*((X-C)/S)^i, i=0..N-1 }
4398  N - number of coefficients (polynomial degree plus 1)
4399  * if given, only leading N elements of A are used
4400  * if not given, automatically determined from size of A
4401  C - offset (see below); 0.0 is used as default value.
4402  S - scale (see below); 1.0 is used as default value. S<>0.
4403 
4404 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
4405  P - polynomial in barycentric form
4406 
4407 
4408 NOTES:
4409 1. this function accepts offset and scale, which can be set to improve
4410  numerical properties of polynomial. For example, if you interpolate on
4411  [-1,+1], you can set C=0 and S=1 and convert from sum of 1, x, x^2,
4412  x^3 and so on. In most cases you it is exactly what you need.
4413 
4414  However, if your interpolation model was built on [999,1001], you will
4415  see significant growth of numerical errors when using {1, x, x^2, x^3}
4416  as input basis. Converting from sum of 1, (x-1000), (x-1000)^2,
4417  (x-1000)^3 will be better option (you have to specify 1000.0 as offset
4418  C and 1.0 as scale S).
4419 
4420 2. power basis is ill-conditioned and tricks described above can't solve
4421  this problem completely. This function will return barycentric model
4422  in any case, but for N>8 accuracy well degrade. However, N's less than
4423  5 are pretty safe.
4424 
4425  -- ALGLIB --
4426  Copyright 30.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
4427 *************************************************************************/
4428 void polynomialpow2bar(const real_1d_array &a, const ae_int_t n, const double c, const double s, barycentricinterpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4429 void polynomialpow2bar(const real_1d_array &a, barycentricinterpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4430 
4431 
4432 /*************************************************************************
4433 Lagrange intepolant: generation of the model on the general grid.
4434 This function has O(N^2) complexity.
4435 
4436 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4437  X - abscissas, array[0..N-1]
4438  Y - function values, array[0..N-1]
4439  N - number of points, N>=1
4440 
4441 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
4442  P - barycentric model which represents Lagrange interpolant
4443  (see ratint unit info and BarycentricCalc() description for
4444  more information).
4445 
4446  -- ALGLIB --
4447  Copyright 02.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4448 *************************************************************************/
4449 void polynomialbuild(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, barycentricinterpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4450 void polynomialbuild(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, barycentricinterpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4451 
4452 
4453 /*************************************************************************
4454 Lagrange intepolant: generation of the model on equidistant grid.
4455 This function has O(N) complexity.
4456 
4457 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4458  A - left boundary of [A,B]
4459  B - right boundary of [A,B]
4460  Y - function values at the nodes, array[0..N-1]
4461  N - number of points, N>=1
4462  for N=1 a constant model is constructed.
4463 
4464 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
4465  P - barycentric model which represents Lagrange interpolant
4466  (see ratint unit info and BarycentricCalc() description for
4467  more information).
4468 
4469  -- ALGLIB --
4470  Copyright 03.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4471 *************************************************************************/
4472 void polynomialbuildeqdist(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, barycentricinterpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4473 void polynomialbuildeqdist(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &y, barycentricinterpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4474 
4475 
4476 /*************************************************************************
4477 Lagrange intepolant on Chebyshev grid (first kind).
4478 This function has O(N) complexity.
4479 
4480 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4481  A - left boundary of [A,B]
4482  B - right boundary of [A,B]
4483  Y - function values at the nodes, array[0..N-1],
4484  Y[I] = Y(0.5*(B+A) + 0.5*(B-A)*Cos(PI*(2*i+1)/(2*n)))
4485  N - number of points, N>=1
4486  for N=1 a constant model is constructed.
4487 
4488 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
4489  P - barycentric model which represents Lagrange interpolant
4490  (see ratint unit info and BarycentricCalc() description for
4491  more information).
4492 
4493  -- ALGLIB --
4494  Copyright 03.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4495 *************************************************************************/
4496 void polynomialbuildcheb1(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, barycentricinterpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4497 void polynomialbuildcheb1(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &y, barycentricinterpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4498 
4499 
4500 /*************************************************************************
4501 Lagrange intepolant on Chebyshev grid (second kind).
4502 This function has O(N) complexity.
4503 
4504 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4505  A - left boundary of [A,B]
4506  B - right boundary of [A,B]
4507  Y - function values at the nodes, array[0..N-1],
4508  Y[I] = Y(0.5*(B+A) + 0.5*(B-A)*Cos(PI*i/(n-1)))
4509  N - number of points, N>=1
4510  for N=1 a constant model is constructed.
4511 
4512 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
4513  P - barycentric model which represents Lagrange interpolant
4514  (see ratint unit info and BarycentricCalc() description for
4515  more information).
4516 
4517  -- ALGLIB --
4518  Copyright 03.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4519 *************************************************************************/
4520 void polynomialbuildcheb2(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, barycentricinterpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4521 void polynomialbuildcheb2(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &y, barycentricinterpolant &p, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4522 
4523 
4524 /*************************************************************************
4525 Fast equidistant polynomial interpolation function with O(N) complexity
4526 
4527 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4528  A - left boundary of [A,B]
4529  B - right boundary of [A,B]
4530  F - function values, array[0..N-1]
4531  N - number of points on equidistant grid, N>=1
4532  for N=1 a constant model is constructed.
4533  T - position where P(x) is calculated
4534 
4535 RESULT
4536  value of the Lagrange interpolant at T
4537 
4538 IMPORTANT
4539  this function provides fast interface which is not overflow-safe
4540  nor it is very precise.
4541  the best option is to use PolynomialBuildEqDist()/BarycentricCalc()
4542  subroutines unless you are pretty sure that your data will not result
4543  in overflow.
4544 
4545  -- ALGLIB --
4546  Copyright 02.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4547 *************************************************************************/
4548 double polynomialcalceqdist(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &f, const ae_int_t n, const double t, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4549 double polynomialcalceqdist(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &f, const double t, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4550 
4551 
4552 /*************************************************************************
4553 Fast polynomial interpolation function on Chebyshev points (first kind)
4554 with O(N) complexity.
4555 
4556 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4557  A - left boundary of [A,B]
4558  B - right boundary of [A,B]
4559  F - function values, array[0..N-1]
4560  N - number of points on Chebyshev grid (first kind),
4561  X[i] = 0.5*(B+A) + 0.5*(B-A)*Cos(PI*(2*i+1)/(2*n))
4562  for N=1 a constant model is constructed.
4563  T - position where P(x) is calculated
4564 
4565 RESULT
4566  value of the Lagrange interpolant at T
4567 
4568 IMPORTANT
4569  this function provides fast interface which is not overflow-safe
4570  nor it is very precise.
4571  the best option is to use PolIntBuildCheb1()/BarycentricCalc()
4572  subroutines unless you are pretty sure that your data will not result
4573  in overflow.
4574 
4575  -- ALGLIB --
4576  Copyright 02.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4577 *************************************************************************/
4578 double polynomialcalccheb1(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &f, const ae_int_t n, const double t, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4579 double polynomialcalccheb1(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &f, const double t, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4580 
4581 
4582 /*************************************************************************
4583 Fast polynomial interpolation function on Chebyshev points (second kind)
4584 with O(N) complexity.
4585 
4586 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4587  A - left boundary of [A,B]
4588  B - right boundary of [A,B]
4589  F - function values, array[0..N-1]
4590  N - number of points on Chebyshev grid (second kind),
4591  X[i] = 0.5*(B+A) + 0.5*(B-A)*Cos(PI*i/(n-1))
4592  for N=1 a constant model is constructed.
4593  T - position where P(x) is calculated
4594 
4595 RESULT
4596  value of the Lagrange interpolant at T
4597 
4598 IMPORTANT
4599  this function provides fast interface which is not overflow-safe
4600  nor it is very precise.
4601  the best option is to use PolIntBuildCheb2()/BarycentricCalc()
4602  subroutines unless you are pretty sure that your data will not result
4603  in overflow.
4604 
4605  -- ALGLIB --
4606  Copyright 02.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4607 *************************************************************************/
4608 double polynomialcalccheb2(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &f, const ae_int_t n, const double t, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4609 double polynomialcalccheb2(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &f, const double t, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4610 #endif
4611 
4612 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_LSFIT) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
4613 /*************************************************************************
4614 This subroutine fits piecewise linear curve to points with Ramer-Douglas-
4615 Peucker algorithm, which stops after generating specified number of linear
4616 sections.
4617 
4618 IMPORTANT:
4619 * it does NOT perform least-squares fitting; it builds curve, but this
4620  curve does not minimize some least squares metric. See description of
4621  RDP algorithm (say, in Wikipedia) for more details on WHAT is performed.
4622 * this function does NOT work with parametric curves (i.e. curves which
4623  can be represented as {X(t),Y(t)}. It works with curves which can be
4624  represented as Y(X). Thus, it is impossible to model figures like
4625  circles with this functions.
4626  If you want to work with parametric curves, you should use
4627  ParametricRDPFixed() function provided by "Parametric" subpackage of
4628  "Interpolation" package.
4629 
4630 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4631  X - array of X-coordinates:
4632  * at least N elements
4633  * can be unordered (points are automatically sorted)
4634  * this function may accept non-distinct X (see below for
4635  more information on handling of such inputs)
4636  Y - array of Y-coordinates:
4637  * at least N elements
4638  N - number of elements in X/Y
4639  M - desired number of sections:
4640  * at most M sections are generated by this function
4641  * less than M sections can be generated if we have N<M
4642  (or some X are non-distinct).
4643 
4644 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4645  X2 - X-values of corner points for piecewise approximation,
4646  has length NSections+1 or zero (for NSections=0).
4647  Y2 - Y-values of corner points,
4648  has length NSections+1 or zero (for NSections=0).
4649  NSections- number of sections found by algorithm, NSections<=M,
4650  NSections can be zero for degenerate datasets
4651  (N<=1 or all X[] are non-distinct).
4652 
4653 NOTE: X2/Y2 are ordered arrays, i.e. (X2[0],Y2[0]) is a first point of
4654  curve, (X2[NSection-1],Y2[NSection-1]) is the last point.
4655 
4656  -- ALGLIB --
4657  Copyright 02.10.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey
4658 *************************************************************************/
4659 void lstfitpiecewiselinearrdpfixed(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, real_1d_array &x2, real_1d_array &y2, ae_int_t &nsections, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4660 
4661 
4662 /*************************************************************************
4663 This subroutine fits piecewise linear curve to points with Ramer-Douglas-
4664 Peucker algorithm, which stops after achieving desired precision.
4665 
4666 IMPORTANT:
4667 * it performs non-least-squares fitting; it builds curve, but this curve
4668  does not minimize some least squares metric. See description of RDP
4669  algorithm (say, in Wikipedia) for more details on WHAT is performed.
4670 * this function does NOT work with parametric curves (i.e. curves which
4671  can be represented as {X(t),Y(t)}. It works with curves which can be
4672  represented as Y(X). Thus, it is impossible to model figures like circles
4673  with this functions.
4674  If you want to work with parametric curves, you should use
4675  ParametricRDPFixed() function provided by "Parametric" subpackage of
4676  "Interpolation" package.
4677 
4678 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4679  X - array of X-coordinates:
4680  * at least N elements
4681  * can be unordered (points are automatically sorted)
4682  * this function may accept non-distinct X (see below for
4683  more information on handling of such inputs)
4684  Y - array of Y-coordinates:
4685  * at least N elements
4686  N - number of elements in X/Y
4687  Eps - positive number, desired precision.
4688 
4689 
4690 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4691  X2 - X-values of corner points for piecewise approximation,
4692  has length NSections+1 or zero (for NSections=0).
4693  Y2 - Y-values of corner points,
4694  has length NSections+1 or zero (for NSections=0).
4695  NSections- number of sections found by algorithm,
4696  NSections can be zero for degenerate datasets
4697  (N<=1 or all X[] are non-distinct).
4698 
4699 NOTE: X2/Y2 are ordered arrays, i.e. (X2[0],Y2[0]) is a first point of
4700  curve, (X2[NSection-1],Y2[NSection-1]) is the last point.
4701 
4702  -- ALGLIB --
4703  Copyright 02.10.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey
4704 *************************************************************************/
4705 void lstfitpiecewiselinearrdp(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const double eps, real_1d_array &x2, real_1d_array &y2, ae_int_t &nsections, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4706 
4707 
4708 /*************************************************************************
4709 Fitting by polynomials in barycentric form. This function provides simple
4710 unterface for unconstrained unweighted fitting. See PolynomialFitWC() if
4711 you need constrained fitting.
4712 
4713 Task is linear, so linear least squares solver is used. Complexity of this
4714 computational scheme is O(N*M^2), mostly dominated by least squares solver
4715 
4716 SEE ALSO:
4717  PolynomialFitWC()
4718 
4719 NOTES:
4720  you can convert P from barycentric form to the power or Chebyshev
4721  basis with PolynomialBar2Pow() or PolynomialBar2Cheb() functions from
4722  POLINT subpackage.
4723 
4724  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
4725  !
4726  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
4727  ! of this function:
4728  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
4729  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
4730  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
4731  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
4732  !
4733  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
4734  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
4735  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
4736 
4737 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4738  X - points, array[0..N-1].
4739  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
4740  N - number of points, N>0
4741  * if given, only leading N elements of X/Y are used
4742  * if not given, automatically determined from sizes of X/Y
4743  M - number of basis functions (= polynomial_degree + 1), M>=1
4744 
4745 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4746  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearW() subroutine:
4747  * Info>0 task is solved
4748  * Info<=0 an error occured:
4749  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
4750  P - interpolant in barycentric form.
4751  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearW() subroutine.
4752  Following fields are set:
4753  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
4754  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
4755  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
4756  * MaxError maximum error
4757  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
4758 
4759  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4760  Copyright 10.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4761 *************************************************************************/
4762 void polynomialfit(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, barycentricinterpolant &p, polynomialfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4763 void polynomialfit(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, barycentricinterpolant &p, polynomialfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4764 
4765 
4766 /*************************************************************************
4767 Weighted fitting by polynomials in barycentric form, with constraints on
4768 function values or first derivatives.
4769 
4770 Small regularizing term is used when solving constrained tasks (to improve
4771 stability).
4772 
4773 Task is linear, so linear least squares solver is used. Complexity of this
4774 computational scheme is O(N*M^2), mostly dominated by least squares solver
4775 
4776 SEE ALSO:
4777  PolynomialFit()
4778 
4779 NOTES:
4780  you can convert P from barycentric form to the power or Chebyshev
4781  basis with PolynomialBar2Pow() or PolynomialBar2Cheb() functions from
4782  POLINT subpackage.
4783 
4784  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
4785  !
4786  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
4787  ! of this function:
4788  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
4789  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
4790  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
4791  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
4792  !
4793  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
4794  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
4795  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
4796 
4797 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4798  X - points, array[0..N-1].
4799  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
4800  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
4801  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations from
4802  given values is multiplied by the square of corresponding
4803  weight. Fill it by 1's if you don't want to solve weighted
4804  task.
4805  N - number of points, N>0.
4806  * if given, only leading N elements of X/Y/W are used
4807  * if not given, automatically determined from sizes of X/Y/W
4808  XC - points where polynomial values/derivatives are constrained,
4809  array[0..K-1].
4810  YC - values of constraints, array[0..K-1]
4811  DC - array[0..K-1], types of constraints:
4812  * DC[i]=0 means that P(XC[i])=YC[i]
4813  * DC[i]=1 means that P'(XC[i])=YC[i]
4814  SEE BELOW FOR IMPORTANT INFORMATION ON CONSTRAINTS
4815  K - number of constraints, 0<=K<M.
4816  K=0 means no constraints (XC/YC/DC are not used in such cases)
4817  M - number of basis functions (= polynomial_degree + 1), M>=1
4818 
4819 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4820  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearW() subroutine:
4821  * Info>0 task is solved
4822  * Info<=0 an error occured:
4823  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
4824  -3 means inconsistent constraints
4825  P - interpolant in barycentric form.
4826  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearW() subroutine.
4827  Following fields are set:
4828  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
4829  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
4830  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
4831  * MaxError maximum error
4832  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
4833 
4834 IMPORTANT:
4835  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
4836 
4837 SETTING CONSTRAINTS - DANGERS AND OPPORTUNITIES:
4838 
4839 Setting constraints can lead to undesired results, like ill-conditioned
4840 behavior, or inconsistency being detected. From the other side, it allows
4841 us to improve quality of the fit. Here we summarize our experience with
4842 constrained regression splines:
4843 * even simple constraints can be inconsistent, see Wikipedia article on
4844  this subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birkhoff_interpolation
4845 * the greater is M (given fixed constraints), the more chances that
4846  constraints will be consistent
4847 * in the general case, consistency of constraints is NOT GUARANTEED.
4848 * in the one special cases, however, we can guarantee consistency. This
4849  case is: M>1 and constraints on the function values (NOT DERIVATIVES)
4850 
4851 Our final recommendation is to use constraints WHEN AND ONLY when you
4852 can't solve your task without them. Anything beyond special cases given
4853 above is not guaranteed and may result in inconsistency.
4854 
4855  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4856  Copyright 10.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
4857 *************************************************************************/
4858 void polynomialfitwc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, barycentricinterpolant &p, polynomialfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4859 void polynomialfitwc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, barycentricinterpolant &p, polynomialfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4860 
4861 
4862 /*************************************************************************
4863 This function calculates value of four-parameter logistic (4PL) model at
4864 specified point X. 4PL model has following form:
4865 
4866  F(x|A,B,C,D) = D+(A-D)/(1+Power(x/C,B))
4867 
4868 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4869  X - current point, X>=0:
4870  * zero X is correctly handled even for B<=0
4871  * negative X results in exception.
4872  A, B, C, D- parameters of 4PL model:
4873  * A is unconstrained
4874  * B is unconstrained; zero or negative values are handled
4875  correctly.
4876  * C>0, non-positive value results in exception
4877  * D is unconstrained
4878 
4879 RESULT:
4880  model value at X
4881 
4882 NOTE: if B=0, denominator is assumed to be equal to 2.0 even for zero X
4883  (strictly speaking, 0^0 is undefined).
4884 
4885 NOTE: this function also throws exception if all input parameters are
4886  correct, but overflow was detected during calculations.
4887 
4888 NOTE: this function performs a lot of checks; if you need really high
4889  performance, consider evaluating model yourself, without checking
4890  for degenerate cases.
4891 
4892 
4893  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4894  Copyright 14.05.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey
4895 *************************************************************************/
4896 double logisticcalc4(const double x, const double a, const double b, const double c, const double d, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4897 
4898 
4899 /*************************************************************************
4900 This function calculates value of five-parameter logistic (5PL) model at
4901 specified point X. 5PL model has following form:
4902 
4903  F(x|A,B,C,D,G) = D+(A-D)/Power(1+Power(x/C,B),G)
4904 
4905 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4906  X - current point, X>=0:
4907  * zero X is correctly handled even for B<=0
4908  * negative X results in exception.
4909  A, B, C, D, G- parameters of 5PL model:
4910  * A is unconstrained
4911  * B is unconstrained; zero or negative values are handled
4912  correctly.
4913  * C>0, non-positive value results in exception
4914  * D is unconstrained
4915  * G>0, non-positive value results in exception
4916 
4917 RESULT:
4918  model value at X
4919 
4920 NOTE: if B=0, denominator is assumed to be equal to Power(2.0,G) even for
4921  zero X (strictly speaking, 0^0 is undefined).
4922 
4923 NOTE: this function also throws exception if all input parameters are
4924  correct, but overflow was detected during calculations.
4925 
4926 NOTE: this function performs a lot of checks; if you need really high
4927  performance, consider evaluating model yourself, without checking
4928  for degenerate cases.
4929 
4930 
4931  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4932  Copyright 14.05.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey
4933 *************************************************************************/
4934 double logisticcalc5(const double x, const double a, const double b, const double c, const double d, const double g, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4935 
4936 
4937 /*************************************************************************
4938 This function fits four-parameter logistic (4PL) model to data provided
4939 by user. 4PL model has following form:
4940 
4941  F(x|A,B,C,D) = D+(A-D)/(1+Power(x/C,B))
4942 
4943 Here:
4944  * A, D - unconstrained (see LogisticFit4EC() for constrained 4PL)
4945  * B>=0
4946  * C>0
4947 
4948 IMPORTANT: output of this function is constrained in such way that B>0.
4949  Because 4PL model is symmetric with respect to B, there is no
4950  need to explore B<0. Constraining B makes algorithm easier
4951  to stabilize and debug.
4952  Users who for some reason prefer to work with negative B's
4953  should transform output themselves (swap A and D, replace B by
4954  -B).
4955 
4956 4PL fitting is implemented as follows:
4957 * we perform small number of restarts from random locations which helps to
4958  solve problem of bad local extrema. Locations are only partially random
4959  - we use input data to determine good initial guess, but we include
4960  controlled amount of randomness.
4961 * we perform Levenberg-Marquardt fitting with very tight constraints on
4962  parameters B and C - it allows us to find good initial guess for the
4963  second stage without risk of running into "flat spot".
4964 * second Levenberg-Marquardt round is performed without excessive
4965  constraints. Results from the previous round are used as initial guess.
4966 * after fitting is done, we compare results with best values found so far,
4967  rewrite "best solution" if needed, and move to next random location.
4968 
4969 Overall algorithm is very stable and is not prone to bad local extrema.
4970 Furthermore, it automatically scales when input data have very large or
4971 very small range.
4972 
4973 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4974  X - array[N], stores X-values.
4975  MUST include only non-negative numbers (but may include
4976  zero values). Can be unsorted.
4977  Y - array[N], values to fit.
4978  N - number of points. If N is less than length of X/Y, only
4979  leading N elements are used.
4980 
4981 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4982  A, B, C, D- parameters of 4PL model
4983  Rep - fitting report. This structure has many fields, but ONLY
4984  ONES LISTED BELOW ARE SET:
4985  * Rep.IterationsCount - number of iterations performed
4986  * Rep.RMSError - root-mean-square error
4987  * Rep.AvgError - average absolute error
4988  * Rep.AvgRelError - average relative error (calculated for
4989  non-zero Y-values)
4990  * Rep.MaxError - maximum absolute error
4991  * Rep.R2 - coefficient of determination, R-squared. This
4992  coefficient is calculated as R2=1-RSS/TSS (in case
4993  of nonlinear regression there are multiple ways to
4994  define R2, each of them giving different results).
4995 
4996 NOTE: after you obtained coefficients, you can evaluate model with
4997  LogisticCalc4() function.
4998 
4999 NOTE: if you need better control over fitting process than provided by this
5000  function, you may use LogisticFit45X().
5001 
5002 NOTE: step is automatically scaled according to scale of parameters being
5003  fitted before we compare its length with EpsX. Thus, this function
5004  can be used to fit data with very small or very large values without
5005  changing EpsX.
5006 
5007 
5008  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
5009  Copyright 14.02.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey
5010 *************************************************************************/
5011 void logisticfit4(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, double &a, double &b, double &c, double &d, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5012 
5013 
5014 /*************************************************************************
5015 This function fits four-parameter logistic (4PL) model to data provided
5016 by user, with optional constraints on parameters A and D. 4PL model has
5017 following form:
5018 
5019  F(x|A,B,C,D) = D+(A-D)/(1+Power(x/C,B))
5020 
5021 Here:
5022  * A, D - with optional equality constraints
5023  * B>=0
5024  * C>0
5025 
5026 IMPORTANT: output of this function is constrained in such way that B>0.
5027  Because 4PL model is symmetric with respect to B, there is no
5028  need to explore B<0. Constraining B makes algorithm easier
5029  to stabilize and debug.
5030  Users who for some reason prefer to work with negative B's
5031  should transform output themselves (swap A and D, replace B by
5032  -B).
5033 
5034 4PL fitting is implemented as follows:
5035 * we perform small number of restarts from random locations which helps to
5036  solve problem of bad local extrema. Locations are only partially random
5037  - we use input data to determine good initial guess, but we include
5038  controlled amount of randomness.
5039 * we perform Levenberg-Marquardt fitting with very tight constraints on
5040  parameters B and C - it allows us to find good initial guess for the
5041  second stage without risk of running into "flat spot".
5042 * second Levenberg-Marquardt round is performed without excessive
5043  constraints. Results from the previous round are used as initial guess.
5044 * after fitting is done, we compare results with best values found so far,
5045  rewrite "best solution" if needed, and move to next random location.
5046 
5047 Overall algorithm is very stable and is not prone to bad local extrema.
5048 Furthermore, it automatically scales when input data have very large or
5049 very small range.
5050 
5051 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5052  X - array[N], stores X-values.
5053  MUST include only non-negative numbers (but may include
5054  zero values). Can be unsorted.
5055  Y - array[N], values to fit.
5056  N - number of points. If N is less than length of X/Y, only
5057  leading N elements are used.
5058  CnstrLeft- optional equality constraint for model value at the left
5059  boundary (at X=0). Specify NAN (Not-a-Number) if you do
5060  not need constraint on the model value at X=0 (in C++ you
5061  can pass alglib::fp_nan as parameter, in C# it will be
5062  Double.NaN).
5063  See below, section "EQUALITY CONSTRAINTS" for more
5064  information about constraints.
5065  CnstrRight- optional equality constraint for model value at X=infinity.
5066  Specify NAN (Not-a-Number) if you do not need constraint
5067  on the model value (in C++ you can pass alglib::fp_nan as
5068  parameter, in C# it will be Double.NaN).
5069  See below, section "EQUALITY CONSTRAINTS" for more
5070  information about constraints.
5071 
5072 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5073  A, B, C, D- parameters of 4PL model
5074  Rep - fitting report. This structure has many fields, but ONLY
5075  ONES LISTED BELOW ARE SET:
5076  * Rep.IterationsCount - number of iterations performed
5077  * Rep.RMSError - root-mean-square error
5078  * Rep.AvgError - average absolute error
5079  * Rep.AvgRelError - average relative error (calculated for
5080  non-zero Y-values)
5081  * Rep.MaxError - maximum absolute error
5082  * Rep.R2 - coefficient of determination, R-squared. This
5083  coefficient is calculated as R2=1-RSS/TSS (in case
5084  of nonlinear regression there are multiple ways to
5085  define R2, each of them giving different results).
5086 
5087 NOTE: after you obtained coefficients, you can evaluate model with
5088  LogisticCalc4() function.
5089 
5090 NOTE: if you need better control over fitting process than provided by this
5091  function, you may use LogisticFit45X().
5092 
5093 NOTE: step is automatically scaled according to scale of parameters being
5094  fitted before we compare its length with EpsX. Thus, this function
5095  can be used to fit data with very small or very large values without
5096  changing EpsX.
5097 
5098 EQUALITY CONSTRAINTS ON PARAMETERS
5099 
5100 4PL/5PL solver supports equality constraints on model values at the left
5101 boundary (X=0) and right boundary (X=infinity). These constraints are
5102 completely optional and you can specify both of them, only one - or no
5103 constraints at all.
5104 
5105 Parameter CnstrLeft contains left constraint (or NAN for unconstrained
5106 fitting), and CnstrRight contains right one. For 4PL, left constraint
5107 ALWAYS corresponds to parameter A, and right one is ALWAYS constraint on
5108 D. That's because 4PL model is normalized in such way that B>=0.
5109 
5110 
5111  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
5112  Copyright 14.02.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey
5113 *************************************************************************/
5114 void logisticfit4ec(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const double cnstrleft, const double cnstrright, double &a, double &b, double &c, double &d, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5115 
5116 
5117 /*************************************************************************
