5118 This function fits five-parameter logistic (5PL) model to data provided
5119 by user. 5PL model has following form:
5120 
5121  F(x|A,B,C,D,G) = D+(A-D)/Power(1+Power(x/C,B),G)
5122 
5123 Here:
5124  * A, D - unconstrained
5125  * B - unconstrained
5126  * C>0
5127  * G>0
5128 
5129 IMPORTANT: unlike in 4PL fitting, output of this function is NOT
5130  constrained in such way that B is guaranteed to be positive.
5131  Furthermore, unlike 4PL, 5PL model is NOT symmetric with
5132  respect to B, so you can NOT transform model to equivalent one,
5133  with B having desired sign (>0 or <0).
5134 
5135 5PL fitting is implemented as follows:
5136 * we perform small number of restarts from random locations which helps to
5137  solve problem of bad local extrema. Locations are only partially random
5138  - we use input data to determine good initial guess, but we include
5139  controlled amount of randomness.
5140 * we perform Levenberg-Marquardt fitting with very tight constraints on
5141  parameters B and C - it allows us to find good initial guess for the
5142  second stage without risk of running into "flat spot". Parameter G is
5143  fixed at G=1.
5144 * second Levenberg-Marquardt round is performed without excessive
5145  constraints on B and C, but with G still equal to 1. Results from the
5146  previous round are used as initial guess.
5147 * third Levenberg-Marquardt round relaxes constraints on G and tries two
5148  different models - one with B>0 and one with B<0.
5149 * after fitting is done, we compare results with best values found so far,
5150  rewrite "best solution" if needed, and move to next random location.
5151 
5152 Overall algorithm is very stable and is not prone to bad local extrema.
5153 Furthermore, it automatically scales when input data have very large or
5154 very small range.
5155 
5156 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5157  X - array[N], stores X-values.
5158  MUST include only non-negative numbers (but may include
5159  zero values). Can be unsorted.
5160  Y - array[N], values to fit.
5161  N - number of points. If N is less than length of X/Y, only
5162  leading N elements are used.
5163 
5164 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5165  A,B,C,D,G- parameters of 5PL model
5166  Rep - fitting report. This structure has many fields, but ONLY
5167  ONES LISTED BELOW ARE SET:
5168  * Rep.IterationsCount - number of iterations performed
5169  * Rep.RMSError - root-mean-square error
5170  * Rep.AvgError - average absolute error
5171  * Rep.AvgRelError - average relative error (calculated for
5172  non-zero Y-values)
5173  * Rep.MaxError - maximum absolute error
5174  * Rep.R2 - coefficient of determination, R-squared. This
5175  coefficient is calculated as R2=1-RSS/TSS (in case
5176  of nonlinear regression there are multiple ways to
5177  define R2, each of them giving different results).
5178 
5179 NOTE: after you obtained coefficients, you can evaluate model with
5180  LogisticCalc5() function.
5181 
5182 NOTE: if you need better control over fitting process than provided by this
5183  function, you may use LogisticFit45X().
5184 
5185 NOTE: step is automatically scaled according to scale of parameters being
5186  fitted before we compare its length with EpsX. Thus, this function
5187  can be used to fit data with very small or very large values without
5188  changing EpsX.
5189 
5190 
5191  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
5192  Copyright 14.02.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey
5193 *************************************************************************/
5194 void logisticfit5(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, double &a, double &b, double &c, double &d, double &g, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5195 
5196 
5197 /*************************************************************************
5198 This function fits five-parameter logistic (5PL) model to data provided
5199 by user, subject to optional equality constraints on parameters A and D.
5200 5PL model has following form:
5201 
5202  F(x|A,B,C,D,G) = D+(A-D)/Power(1+Power(x/C,B),G)
5203 
5204 Here:
5205  * A, D - with optional equality constraints
5206  * B - unconstrained
5207  * C>0
5208  * G>0
5209 
5210 IMPORTANT: unlike in 4PL fitting, output of this function is NOT
5211  constrained in such way that B is guaranteed to be positive.
5212  Furthermore, unlike 4PL, 5PL model is NOT symmetric with
5213  respect to B, so you can NOT transform model to equivalent one,
5214  with B having desired sign (>0 or <0).
5215 
5216 5PL fitting is implemented as follows:
5217 * we perform small number of restarts from random locations which helps to
5218  solve problem of bad local extrema. Locations are only partially random
5219  - we use input data to determine good initial guess, but we include
5220  controlled amount of randomness.
5221 * we perform Levenberg-Marquardt fitting with very tight constraints on
5222  parameters B and C - it allows us to find good initial guess for the
5223  second stage without risk of running into "flat spot". Parameter G is
5224  fixed at G=1.
5225 * second Levenberg-Marquardt round is performed without excessive
5226  constraints on B and C, but with G still equal to 1. Results from the
5227  previous round are used as initial guess.
5228 * third Levenberg-Marquardt round relaxes constraints on G and tries two
5229  different models - one with B>0 and one with B<0.
5230 * after fitting is done, we compare results with best values found so far,
5231  rewrite "best solution" if needed, and move to next random location.
5232 
5233 Overall algorithm is very stable and is not prone to bad local extrema.
5234 Furthermore, it automatically scales when input data have very large or
5235 very small range.
5236 
5237 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5238  X - array[N], stores X-values.
5239  MUST include only non-negative numbers (but may include
5240  zero values). Can be unsorted.
5241  Y - array[N], values to fit.
5242  N - number of points. If N is less than length of X/Y, only
5243  leading N elements are used.
5244  CnstrLeft- optional equality constraint for model value at the left
5245  boundary (at X=0). Specify NAN (Not-a-Number) if you do
5246  not need constraint on the model value at X=0 (in C++ you
5247  can pass alglib::fp_nan as parameter, in C# it will be
5248  Double.NaN).
5249  See below, section "EQUALITY CONSTRAINTS" for more
5250  information about constraints.
5251  CnstrRight- optional equality constraint for model value at X=infinity.
5252  Specify NAN (Not-a-Number) if you do not need constraint
5253  on the model value (in C++ you can pass alglib::fp_nan as
5254  parameter, in C# it will be Double.NaN).
5255  See below, section "EQUALITY CONSTRAINTS" for more
5256  information about constraints.
5257 
5258 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5259  A,B,C,D,G- parameters of 5PL model
5260  Rep - fitting report. This structure has many fields, but ONLY
5261  ONES LISTED BELOW ARE SET:
5262  * Rep.IterationsCount - number of iterations performed
5263  * Rep.RMSError - root-mean-square error
5264  * Rep.AvgError - average absolute error
5265  * Rep.AvgRelError - average relative error (calculated for
5266  non-zero Y-values)
5267  * Rep.MaxError - maximum absolute error
5268  * Rep.R2 - coefficient of determination, R-squared. This
5269  coefficient is calculated as R2=1-RSS/TSS (in case
5270  of nonlinear regression there are multiple ways to
5271  define R2, each of them giving different results).
5272 
5273 NOTE: after you obtained coefficients, you can evaluate model with
5274  LogisticCalc5() function.
5275 
5276 NOTE: if you need better control over fitting process than provided by this
5277  function, you may use LogisticFit45X().
5278 
5279 NOTE: step is automatically scaled according to scale of parameters being
5280  fitted before we compare its length with EpsX. Thus, this function
5281  can be used to fit data with very small or very large values without
5282  changing EpsX.
5283 
5284 EQUALITY CONSTRAINTS ON PARAMETERS
5285 
5286 5PL solver supports equality constraints on model values at the left
5287 boundary (X=0) and right boundary (X=infinity). These constraints are
5288 completely optional and you can specify both of them, only one - or no
5289 constraints at all.
5290 
5291 Parameter CnstrLeft contains left constraint (or NAN for unconstrained
5292 fitting), and CnstrRight contains right one.
5293 
5294 Unlike 4PL one, 5PL model is NOT symmetric with respect to change in sign
5295 of B. Thus, negative B's are possible, and left constraint may constrain
5296 parameter A (for positive B's) - or parameter D (for negative B's).
5297 Similarly changes meaning of right constraint.
5298 
5299 You do not have to decide what parameter to constrain - algorithm will
5300 automatically determine correct parameters as fitting progresses. However,
5301 question highlighted above is important when you interpret fitting results.
5302 
5303 
5304  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
5305  Copyright 14.02.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey
5306 *************************************************************************/
5307 void logisticfit5ec(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const double cnstrleft, const double cnstrright, double &a, double &b, double &c, double &d, double &g, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5308 
5309 
5310 /*************************************************************************
5311 This is "expert" 4PL/5PL fitting function, which can be used if you need
5312 better control over fitting process than provided by LogisticFit4() or
5313 LogisticFit5().
5314 
5315 This function fits model of the form
5316 
5317  F(x|A,B,C,D) = D+(A-D)/(1+Power(x/C,B)) (4PL model)
5318 
5319 or
5320 
5321  F(x|A,B,C,D,G) = D+(A-D)/Power(1+Power(x/C,B),G) (5PL model)
5322 
5323 Here:
5324  * A, D - unconstrained
5325  * B>=0 for 4PL, unconstrained for 5PL
5326  * C>0
5327  * G>0 (if present)
5328 
5329 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5330  X - array[N], stores X-values.
5331  MUST include only non-negative numbers (but may include
5332  zero values). Can be unsorted.
5333  Y - array[N], values to fit.
5334  N - number of points. If N is less than length of X/Y, only
5335  leading N elements are used.
5336  CnstrLeft- optional equality constraint for model value at the left
5337  boundary (at X=0). Specify NAN (Not-a-Number) if you do
5338  not need constraint on the model value at X=0 (in C++ you
5339  can pass alglib::fp_nan as parameter, in C# it will be
5340  Double.NaN).
5341  See below, section "EQUALITY CONSTRAINTS" for more
5342  information about constraints.
5343  CnstrRight- optional equality constraint for model value at X=infinity.
5344  Specify NAN (Not-a-Number) if you do not need constraint
5345  on the model value (in C++ you can pass alglib::fp_nan as
5346  parameter, in C# it will be Double.NaN).
5347  See below, section "EQUALITY CONSTRAINTS" for more
5348  information about constraints.
5349  Is4PL - whether 4PL or 5PL models are fitted
5350  LambdaV - regularization coefficient, LambdaV>=0.
5351  Set it to zero unless you know what you are doing.
5352  EpsX - stopping condition (step size), EpsX>=0.
5353  Zero value means that small step is automatically chosen.
5354  See notes below for more information.
5355  RsCnt - number of repeated restarts from random points. 4PL/5PL
5356  models are prone to problem of bad local extrema. Utilizing
5357  multiple random restarts allows us to improve algorithm
5358  convergence.
5359  RsCnt>=0.
5360  Zero value means that function automatically choose small
5361  amount of restarts (recommended).
5362 
5363 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5364  A, B, C, D- parameters of 4PL model
5365  G - parameter of 5PL model; for Is4PL=True, G=1 is returned.
5366  Rep - fitting report. This structure has many fields, but ONLY
5367  ONES LISTED BELOW ARE SET:
5368  * Rep.IterationsCount - number of iterations performed
5369  * Rep.RMSError - root-mean-square error
5370  * Rep.AvgError - average absolute error
5371  * Rep.AvgRelError - average relative error (calculated for
5372  non-zero Y-values)
5373  * Rep.MaxError - maximum absolute error
5374  * Rep.R2 - coefficient of determination, R-squared. This
5375  coefficient is calculated as R2=1-RSS/TSS (in case
5376  of nonlinear regression there are multiple ways to
5377  define R2, each of them giving different results).
5378 
5379 NOTE: after you obtained coefficients, you can evaluate model with
5380  LogisticCalc5() function.
5381 
5382 NOTE: step is automatically scaled according to scale of parameters being
5383  fitted before we compare its length with EpsX. Thus, this function
5384  can be used to fit data with very small or very large values without
5385  changing EpsX.
5386 
5387 EQUALITY CONSTRAINTS ON PARAMETERS
5388 
5389 4PL/5PL solver supports equality constraints on model values at the left
5390 boundary (X=0) and right boundary (X=infinity). These constraints are
5391 completely optional and you can specify both of them, only one - or no
5392 constraints at all.
5393 
5394 Parameter CnstrLeft contains left constraint (or NAN for unconstrained
5395 fitting), and CnstrRight contains right one. For 4PL, left constraint
5396 ALWAYS corresponds to parameter A, and right one is ALWAYS constraint on
5397 D. That's because 4PL model is normalized in such way that B>=0.
5398 
5399 For 5PL model things are different. Unlike 4PL one, 5PL model is NOT
5400 symmetric with respect to change in sign of B. Thus, negative B's are
5401 possible, and left constraint may constrain parameter A (for positive B's)
5402 - or parameter D (for negative B's). Similarly changes meaning of right
5403 constraint.
5404 
5405 You do not have to decide what parameter to constrain - algorithm will
5406 automatically determine correct parameters as fitting progresses. However,
5407 question highlighted above is important when you interpret fitting results.
5408 
5409 
5410  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
5411  Copyright 14.02.2014 by Bochkanov Sergey
5412 *************************************************************************/
5413 void logisticfit45x(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const double cnstrleft, const double cnstrright, const bool is4pl, const double lambdav, const double epsx, const ae_int_t rscnt, double &a, double &b, double &c, double &d, double &g, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5414 
5415 
5416 /*************************************************************************
5417 Weghted rational least squares fitting using Floater-Hormann rational
5418 functions with optimal D chosen from [0,9], with constraints and
5419 individual weights.
5420 
5421 Equidistant grid with M node on [min(x),max(x)] is used to build basis
5422 functions. Different values of D are tried, optimal D (least WEIGHTED root
5423 mean square error) is chosen. Task is linear, so linear least squares
5424 solver is used. Complexity of this computational scheme is O(N*M^2)
5425 (mostly dominated by the least squares solver).
5426 
5427 SEE ALSO
5428 * BarycentricFitFloaterHormann(), "lightweight" fitting without invididual
5429  weights and constraints.
5430 
5431  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
5432  !
5433  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
5434  ! of this function:
5435  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
5436  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
5437  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
5438  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
5439  !
5440  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
5441  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
5442  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
5443 
5444 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5445  X - points, array[0..N-1].
5446  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
5447  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
5448  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations from
5449  given values is multiplied by the square of corresponding
5450  weight. Fill it by 1's if you don't want to solve weighted
5451  task.
5452  N - number of points, N>0.
5453  XC - points where function values/derivatives are constrained,
5454  array[0..K-1].
5455  YC - values of constraints, array[0..K-1]
5456  DC - array[0..K-1], types of constraints:
5457  * DC[i]=0 means that S(XC[i])=YC[i]
5458  * DC[i]=1 means that S'(XC[i])=YC[i]
5459  SEE BELOW FOR IMPORTANT INFORMATION ON CONSTRAINTS
5460  K - number of constraints, 0<=K<M.
5461  K=0 means no constraints (XC/YC/DC are not used in such cases)
5462  M - number of basis functions ( = number_of_nodes), M>=2.
5463 
5464 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5465  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
5466  * Info>0 task is solved
5467  * Info<=0 an error occured:
5468  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
5469  -3 means inconsistent constraints
5470  -1 means another errors in parameters passed
5471  (N<=0, for example)
5472  B - barycentric interpolant.
5473  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
5474  Following fields are set:
5475  * DBest best value of the D parameter
5476  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
5477  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
5478  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
5479  * MaxError maximum error
5480  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
5481 
5482 IMPORTANT:
5483  this subroutine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
5484 
5485 SETTING CONSTRAINTS - DANGERS AND OPPORTUNITIES:
5486 
5487 Setting constraints can lead to undesired results, like ill-conditioned
5488 behavior, or inconsistency being detected. From the other side, it allows
5489 us to improve quality of the fit. Here we summarize our experience with
5490 constrained barycentric interpolants:
5491 * excessive constraints can be inconsistent. Floater-Hormann basis
5492  functions aren't as flexible as splines (although they are very smooth).
5493 * the more evenly constraints are spread across [min(x),max(x)], the more
5494  chances that they will be consistent
5495 * the greater is M (given fixed constraints), the more chances that
5496  constraints will be consistent
5497 * in the general case, consistency of constraints IS NOT GUARANTEED.
5498 * in the several special cases, however, we CAN guarantee consistency.
5499 * one of this cases is constraints on the function VALUES at the interval
5500  boundaries. Note that consustency of the constraints on the function
5501  DERIVATIVES is NOT guaranteed (you can use in such cases cubic splines
5502  which are more flexible).
5503 * another special case is ONE constraint on the function value (OR, but
5504  not AND, derivative) anywhere in the interval
5505 
5506 Our final recommendation is to use constraints WHEN AND ONLY WHEN you
5507 can't solve your task without them. Anything beyond special cases given
5508 above is not guaranteed and may result in inconsistency.
5509 
5510  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
5511  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5512 *************************************************************************/
5513 void barycentricfitfloaterhormannwc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, barycentricinterpolant &b, barycentricfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5514 
5515 
5516 /*************************************************************************
5517 Rational least squares fitting using Floater-Hormann rational functions
5518 with optimal D chosen from [0,9].
5519 
5520 Equidistant grid with M node on [min(x),max(x)] is used to build basis
5521 functions. Different values of D are tried, optimal D (least root mean
5522 square error) is chosen. Task is linear, so linear least squares solver
5523 is used. Complexity of this computational scheme is O(N*M^2) (mostly
5524 dominated by the least squares solver).
5525 
5526  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
5527  !
5528  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
5529  ! of this function:
5530  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
5531  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
5532  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
5533  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
5534  !
5535  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
5536  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
5537  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
5538 
5539 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5540  X - points, array[0..N-1].
5541  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
5542  N - number of points, N>0.
5543  M - number of basis functions ( = number_of_nodes), M>=2.
5544 
5545 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5546  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
5547  * Info>0 task is solved
5548  * Info<=0 an error occured:
5549  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
5550  -3 means inconsistent constraints
5551  B - barycentric interpolant.
5552  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
5553  Following fields are set:
5554  * DBest best value of the D parameter
5555  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
5556  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
5557  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
5558  * MaxError maximum error
5559  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
5560 
5561  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
5562  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5563 *************************************************************************/
5564 void barycentricfitfloaterhormann(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, barycentricinterpolant &b, barycentricfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5565 
5566 
5567 /*************************************************************************
5568 Weighted fitting by cubic spline, with constraints on function values or
5569 derivatives.
5570 
5571 Equidistant grid with M-2 nodes on [min(x,xc),max(x,xc)] is used to build
5572 basis functions. Basis functions are cubic splines with continuous second
5573 derivatives and non-fixed first derivatives at interval ends. Small
5574 regularizing term is used when solving constrained tasks (to improve
5575 stability).
5576 
5577 Task is linear, so linear least squares solver is used. Complexity of this
5578 computational scheme is O(N*M^2), mostly dominated by least squares solver
5579 
5580 SEE ALSO
5581  Spline1DFitHermiteWC() - fitting by Hermite splines (more flexible,
5582  less smooth)
5583  Spline1DFitCubic() - "lightweight" fitting by cubic splines,
5584  without invididual weights and constraints
5585 
5586  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
5587  !
5588  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
5589  ! of this function:
5590  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
5591  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
5592  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
5593  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
5594  !
5595  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
5596  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
5597  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
5598 
5599 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5600  X - points, array[0..N-1].
5601  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
5602  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
5603  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations from
5604  given values is multiplied by the square of corresponding
5605  weight. Fill it by 1's if you don't want to solve weighted
5606  task.
5607  N - number of points (optional):
5608  * N>0
5609  * if given, only first N elements of X/Y/W are processed
5610  * if not given, automatically determined from X/Y/W sizes
5611  XC - points where spline values/derivatives are constrained,
5612  array[0..K-1].
5613  YC - values of constraints, array[0..K-1]
5614  DC - array[0..K-1], types of constraints:
5615  * DC[i]=0 means that S(XC[i])=YC[i]
5616  * DC[i]=1 means that S'(XC[i])=YC[i]
5617  SEE BELOW FOR IMPORTANT INFORMATION ON CONSTRAINTS
5618  K - number of constraints (optional):
5619  * 0<=K<M.
5620  * K=0 means no constraints (XC/YC/DC are not used)
5621  * if given, only first K elements of XC/YC/DC are used
5622  * if not given, automatically determined from XC/YC/DC
5623  M - number of basis functions ( = number_of_nodes+2), M>=4.
5624 
5625 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5626  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
5627  * Info>0 task is solved
5628  * Info<=0 an error occured:
5629  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
5630  -3 means inconsistent constraints
5631  S - spline interpolant.
5632  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
5633  Following fields are set:
5634  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
5635  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
5636  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
5637  * MaxError maximum error
5638  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
5639 
5640 IMPORTANT:
5641  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
5642 
5643 
5644 ORDER OF POINTS
5645 
5646 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
5647 
5648 SETTING CONSTRAINTS - DANGERS AND OPPORTUNITIES:
5649 
5650 Setting constraints can lead to undesired results, like ill-conditioned
5651 behavior, or inconsistency being detected. From the other side, it allows
5652 us to improve quality of the fit. Here we summarize our experience with
5653 constrained regression splines:
5654 * excessive constraints can be inconsistent. Splines are piecewise cubic
5655  functions, and it is easy to create an example, where large number of
5656  constraints concentrated in small area will result in inconsistency.
5657  Just because spline is not flexible enough to satisfy all of them. And
5658  same constraints spread across the [min(x),max(x)] will be perfectly
5659  consistent.
5660 * the more evenly constraints are spread across [min(x),max(x)], the more
5661  chances that they will be consistent
5662 * the greater is M (given fixed constraints), the more chances that
5663  constraints will be consistent
5664 * in the general case, consistency of constraints IS NOT GUARANTEED.
5665 * in the several special cases, however, we CAN guarantee consistency.
5666 * one of this cases is constraints on the function values AND/OR its
5667  derivatives at the interval boundaries.
5668 * another special case is ONE constraint on the function value (OR, but
5669  not AND, derivative) anywhere in the interval
5670 
5671 Our final recommendation is to use constraints WHEN AND ONLY WHEN you
5672 can't solve your task without them. Anything beyond special cases given
5673 above is not guaranteed and may result in inconsistency.
5674 
5675 
5676  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
5677  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5678 *************************************************************************/
5679 void spline1dfitcubicwc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5680 void spline1dfitcubicwc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5681 
5682 
5683 /*************************************************************************
5684 Weighted fitting by Hermite spline, with constraints on function values
5685 or first derivatives.
5686 
5687 Equidistant grid with M nodes on [min(x,xc),max(x,xc)] is used to build
5688 basis functions. Basis functions are Hermite splines. Small regularizing
5689 term is used when solving constrained tasks (to improve stability).
5690 
5691 Task is linear, so linear least squares solver is used. Complexity of this
5692 computational scheme is O(N*M^2), mostly dominated by least squares solver
5693 
5694 SEE ALSO
5695  Spline1DFitCubicWC() - fitting by Cubic splines (less flexible,
5696  more smooth)
5697  Spline1DFitHermite() - "lightweight" Hermite fitting, without
5698  invididual weights and constraints
5699 
5700  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
5701  !
5702  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
5703  ! of this function:
5704  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
5705  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
5706  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
5707  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
5708  !
5709  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
5710  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
5711  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
5712 
5713 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5714  X - points, array[0..N-1].
5715  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
5716  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
5717  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations from
5718  given values is multiplied by the square of corresponding
5719  weight. Fill it by 1's if you don't want to solve weighted
5720  task.
5721  N - number of points (optional):
5722  * N>0
5723  * if given, only first N elements of X/Y/W are processed
5724  * if not given, automatically determined from X/Y/W sizes
5725  XC - points where spline values/derivatives are constrained,
5726  array[0..K-1].
5727  YC - values of constraints, array[0..K-1]
5728  DC - array[0..K-1], types of constraints:
5729  * DC[i]=0 means that S(XC[i])=YC[i]
5730  * DC[i]=1 means that S'(XC[i])=YC[i]
5731  SEE BELOW FOR IMPORTANT INFORMATION ON CONSTRAINTS
5732  K - number of constraints (optional):
5733  * 0<=K<M.
5734  * K=0 means no constraints (XC/YC/DC are not used)
5735  * if given, only first K elements of XC/YC/DC are used
5736  * if not given, automatically determined from XC/YC/DC
5737  M - number of basis functions (= 2 * number of nodes),
5738  M>=4,
5739  M IS EVEN!
5740 
5741 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5742  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearW() subroutine:
5743  * Info>0 task is solved
5744  * Info<=0 an error occured:
5745  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
5746  -3 means inconsistent constraints
5747  -2 means odd M was passed (which is not supported)
5748  -1 means another errors in parameters passed
5749  (N<=0, for example)
5750  S - spline interpolant.
5751  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearW() subroutine.
5752  Following fields are set:
5753  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
5754  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
5755  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
5756  * MaxError maximum error
5757  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
5758 
5759 IMPORTANT:
5760  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
5761 
5762 IMPORTANT:
5763  this subroitine supports only even M's
5764 
5765 
5766 ORDER OF POINTS
5767 
5768 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
5769 
5770 SETTING CONSTRAINTS - DANGERS AND OPPORTUNITIES:
5771 
5772 Setting constraints can lead to undesired results, like ill-conditioned
5773 behavior, or inconsistency being detected. From the other side, it allows
5774 us to improve quality of the fit. Here we summarize our experience with
5775 constrained regression splines:
5776 * excessive constraints can be inconsistent. Splines are piecewise cubic
5777  functions, and it is easy to create an example, where large number of
5778  constraints concentrated in small area will result in inconsistency.
5779  Just because spline is not flexible enough to satisfy all of them. And
5780  same constraints spread across the [min(x),max(x)] will be perfectly
5781  consistent.
5782 * the more evenly constraints are spread across [min(x),max(x)], the more
5783  chances that they will be consistent
5784 * the greater is M (given fixed constraints), the more chances that
5785  constraints will be consistent
5786 * in the general case, consistency of constraints is NOT GUARANTEED.
5787 * in the several special cases, however, we can guarantee consistency.
5788 * one of this cases is M>=4 and constraints on the function value
5789  (AND/OR its derivative) at the interval boundaries.
5790 * another special case is M>=4 and ONE constraint on the function value
5791  (OR, BUT NOT AND, derivative) anywhere in [min(x),max(x)]
5792 
5793 Our final recommendation is to use constraints WHEN AND ONLY when you
5794 can't solve your task without them. Anything beyond special cases given
5795 above is not guaranteed and may result in inconsistency.
5796 
5797  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
5798  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5799 *************************************************************************/
5800 void spline1dfithermitewc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5801 void spline1dfithermitewc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5802 
5803 
5804 /*************************************************************************
5805 Least squares fitting by cubic spline.
5806 
5807 This subroutine is "lightweight" alternative for more complex and feature-
5808 rich Spline1DFitCubicWC(). See Spline1DFitCubicWC() for more information
5809 about subroutine parameters (we don't duplicate it here because of length)
5810 
5811  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
5812  !
5813  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
5814  ! of this function:
5815  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
5816  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
5817  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
5818  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
5819  !
5820  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
5821  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
5822  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
5823

5825  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5826 *************************************************************************/
5827 void spline1dfitcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5828 void spline1dfitcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5829 
5830 
5831 /*************************************************************************
5832 Least squares fitting by Hermite spline.
5833 
5834 This subroutine is "lightweight" alternative for more complex and feature-
5835 rich Spline1DFitHermiteWC(). See Spline1DFitHermiteWC() description for
5836 more information about subroutine parameters (we don't duplicate it here
5837 because of length).
5838 
5839  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
5840  !
5841  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
5842  ! of this function:
5843  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
5844  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
5845  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
5846  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
5847  !
5848  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
5849  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
5850  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
5851
