5853  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5854 *************************************************************************/
5855 void spline1dfithermite(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5856 void spline1dfithermite(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5857 
5858 
5859 /*************************************************************************
5860 Weighted linear least squares fitting.
5861 
5862 QR decomposition is used to reduce task to MxM, then triangular solver or
5863 SVD-based solver is used depending on condition number of the system. It
5864 allows to maximize speed and retain decent accuracy.
5865 
5866 IMPORTANT: if you want to perform polynomial fitting, it may be more
5867  convenient to use PolynomialFit() function. This function gives
5868  best results on polynomial problems and solves numerical
5869  stability issues which arise when you fit high-degree
5870  polynomials to your data.
5871 
5872  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
5873  !
5874  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
5875  ! of this function:
5876  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
5877  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
5878  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
5879  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
5880  !
5881  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
5882  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
5883  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
5884 
5885 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5886  Y - array[0..N-1] Function values in N points.
5887  W - array[0..N-1] Weights corresponding to function values.
5888  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations
5889  from given values is multiplied by the square of
5890  corresponding weight.
5891  FMatrix - a table of basis functions values, array[0..N-1, 0..M-1].
5892  FMatrix[I, J] - value of J-th basis function in I-th point.
5893  N - number of points used. N>=1.
5894  M - number of basis functions, M>=1.
5895 
5896 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5897  Info - error code:
5898  * -4 internal SVD decomposition subroutine failed (very
5899  rare and for degenerate systems only)
5900  * -1 incorrect N/M were specified
5901  * 1 task is solved
5902  C - decomposition coefficients, array[0..M-1]
5903  Rep - fitting report. Following fields are set:
5904  * Rep.TaskRCond reciprocal of condition number
5905  * R2 non-adjusted coefficient of determination
5906  (non-weighted)
5907  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
5908  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
5909  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
5910  * MaxError maximum error
5911  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
5912 
5913 ERRORS IN PARAMETERS
5914 
5915 This solver also calculates different kinds of errors in parameters and
5916 fills corresponding fields of report:
5917 * Rep.CovPar covariance matrix for parameters, array[K,K].
5918 * Rep.ErrPar errors in parameters, array[K],
5919  errpar = sqrt(diag(CovPar))
5920 * Rep.ErrCurve vector of fit errors - standard deviations of empirical
5921  best-fit curve from "ideal" best-fit curve built with
5922  infinite number of samples, array[N].
5923  errcurve = sqrt(diag(F*CovPar*F')),
5924  where F is functions matrix.
5925 * Rep.Noise vector of per-point estimates of noise, array[N]
5926 
5927 NOTE: noise in the data is estimated as follows:
5928  * for fitting without user-supplied weights all points are
5929  assumed to have same level of noise, which is estimated from
5930  the data
5931  * for fitting with user-supplied weights we assume that noise
5932  level in I-th point is inversely proportional to Ith weight.
5933  Coefficient of proportionality is estimated from the data.
5934 
5935 NOTE: we apply small amount of regularization when we invert squared
5936  Jacobian and calculate covariance matrix. It guarantees that
5937  algorithm won't divide by zero during inversion, but skews
5938  error estimates a bit (fractional error is about 10^-9).
5939 
5940  However, we believe that this difference is insignificant for
5941  all practical purposes except for the situation when you want
5942  to compare ALGLIB results with "reference" implementation up
5943  to the last significant digit.
5944 
5945 NOTE: covariance matrix is estimated using correction for degrees
5946  of freedom (covariances are divided by N-M instead of dividing
5947  by N).
5948 
5949  -- ALGLIB --
5950  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
5951 *************************************************************************/
5952 void lsfitlinearw(const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5953 void lsfitlinearw(const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5954 
5955 
5956 /*************************************************************************
5957 Weighted constained linear least squares fitting.
5958 
5959 This is variation of LSFitLinearW(), which searchs for min|A*x=b| given
5960 that K additional constaints C*x=bc are satisfied. It reduces original
5961 task to modified one: min|B*y-d| WITHOUT constraints, then LSFitLinearW()
5962 is called.
5963 
5964 IMPORTANT: if you want to perform polynomial fitting, it may be more
5965  convenient to use PolynomialFit() function. This function gives
5966  best results on polynomial problems and solves numerical
5967  stability issues which arise when you fit high-degree
5968  polynomials to your data.
5969 
5970  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
5971  !
5972  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
5973  ! of this function:
5974  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
5975  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
5976  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
5977  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
5978  !
5979  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
5980  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
5981  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
5982 
5983 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5984  Y - array[0..N-1] Function values in N points.
5985  W - array[0..N-1] Weights corresponding to function values.
5986  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations
5987  from given values is multiplied by the square of
5988  corresponding weight.
5989  FMatrix - a table of basis functions values, array[0..N-1, 0..M-1].
5990  FMatrix[I,J] - value of J-th basis function in I-th point.
5991  CMatrix - a table of constaints, array[0..K-1,0..M].
5992  I-th row of CMatrix corresponds to I-th linear constraint:
5993  CMatrix[I,0]*C[0] + ... + CMatrix[I,M-1]*C[M-1] = CMatrix[I,M]
5994  N - number of points used. N>=1.
5995  M - number of basis functions, M>=1.
5996  K - number of constraints, 0 <= K < M
5997  K=0 corresponds to absence of constraints.
5998 
5999 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6000  Info - error code:
6001  * -4 internal SVD decomposition subroutine failed (very
6002  rare and for degenerate systems only)
6003  * -3 either too many constraints (M or more),
6004  degenerate constraints (some constraints are
6005  repetead twice) or inconsistent constraints were
6006  specified.
6007  * 1 task is solved
6008  C - decomposition coefficients, array[0..M-1]
6009  Rep - fitting report. Following fields are set:
6010  * R2 non-adjusted coefficient of determination
6011  (non-weighted)
6012  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
6013  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
6014  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
6015  * MaxError maximum error
6016  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
6017 
6018 IMPORTANT:
6019  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
6020 
6021 ERRORS IN PARAMETERS
6022 
6023 This solver also calculates different kinds of errors in parameters and
6024 fills corresponding fields of report:
6025 * Rep.CovPar covariance matrix for parameters, array[K,K].
6026 * Rep.ErrPar errors in parameters, array[K],
6027  errpar = sqrt(diag(CovPar))
6028 * Rep.ErrCurve vector of fit errors - standard deviations of empirical
6029  best-fit curve from "ideal" best-fit curve built with
6030  infinite number of samples, array[N].
6031  errcurve = sqrt(diag(F*CovPar*F')),
6032  where F is functions matrix.
6033 * Rep.Noise vector of per-point estimates of noise, array[N]
6034 
6035 IMPORTANT: errors in parameters are calculated without taking into
6036  account boundary/linear constraints! Presence of constraints
6037  changes distribution of errors, but there is no easy way to
6038  account for constraints when you calculate covariance matrix.
6039 
6040 NOTE: noise in the data is estimated as follows:
6041  * for fitting without user-supplied weights all points are
6042  assumed to have same level of noise, which is estimated from
6043  the data
6044  * for fitting with user-supplied weights we assume that noise
6045  level in I-th point is inversely proportional to Ith weight.
6046  Coefficient of proportionality is estimated from the data.
6047 
6048 NOTE: we apply small amount of regularization when we invert squared
6049  Jacobian and calculate covariance matrix. It guarantees that
6050  algorithm won't divide by zero during inversion, but skews
6051  error estimates a bit (fractional error is about 10^-9).
6052 
6053  However, we believe that this difference is insignificant for
6054  all practical purposes except for the situation when you want
6055  to compare ALGLIB results with "reference" implementation up
6056  to the last significant digit.
6057 
6058 NOTE: covariance matrix is estimated using correction for degrees
6059  of freedom (covariances are divided by N-M instead of dividing
6060  by N).
6061 
6062  -- ALGLIB --
6063  Copyright 07.09.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
6064 *************************************************************************/
6065 void lsfitlinearwc(const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, const real_2d_array &cmatrix, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6066 void lsfitlinearwc(const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, const real_2d_array &cmatrix, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6067 
6068 
6069 /*************************************************************************
6070 Linear least squares fitting.
6071 
6072 QR decomposition is used to reduce task to MxM, then triangular solver or
6073 SVD-based solver is used depending on condition number of the system. It
6074 allows to maximize speed and retain decent accuracy.
6075 
6076 IMPORTANT: if you want to perform polynomial fitting, it may be more
6077  convenient to use PolynomialFit() function. This function gives
6078  best results on polynomial problems and solves numerical
6079  stability issues which arise when you fit high-degree
6080  polynomials to your data.
6081 
6082  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
6083  !
6084  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
6085  ! of this function:
6086  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
6087  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
6088  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
6089  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
6090  !
6091  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
6092  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
6093  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
6094 
6095 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6096  Y - array[0..N-1] Function values in N points.
6097  FMatrix - a table of basis functions values, array[0..N-1, 0..M-1].
6098  FMatrix[I, J] - value of J-th basis function in I-th point.
6099  N - number of points used. N>=1.
6100  M - number of basis functions, M>=1.
6101 
6102 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6103  Info - error code:
6104  * -4 internal SVD decomposition subroutine failed (very
6105  rare and for degenerate systems only)
6106  * 1 task is solved
6107  C - decomposition coefficients, array[0..M-1]
6108  Rep - fitting report. Following fields are set:
6109  * Rep.TaskRCond reciprocal of condition number
6110  * R2 non-adjusted coefficient of determination
6111  (non-weighted)
6112  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
6113  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
6114  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
6115  * MaxError maximum error
6116  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
6117 
6118 ERRORS IN PARAMETERS
6119 
6120 This solver also calculates different kinds of errors in parameters and
6121 fills corresponding fields of report:
6122 * Rep.CovPar covariance matrix for parameters, array[K,K].
6123 * Rep.ErrPar errors in parameters, array[K],
6124  errpar = sqrt(diag(CovPar))
6125 * Rep.ErrCurve vector of fit errors - standard deviations of empirical
6126  best-fit curve from "ideal" best-fit curve built with
6127  infinite number of samples, array[N].
6128  errcurve = sqrt(diag(F*CovPar*F')),
6129  where F is functions matrix.
6130 * Rep.Noise vector of per-point estimates of noise, array[N]
6131 
6132 NOTE: noise in the data is estimated as follows:
6133  * for fitting without user-supplied weights all points are
6134  assumed to have same level of noise, which is estimated from
6135  the data
6136  * for fitting with user-supplied weights we assume that noise
6137  level in I-th point is inversely proportional to Ith weight.
6138  Coefficient of proportionality is estimated from the data.
6139 
6140 NOTE: we apply small amount of regularization when we invert squared
6141  Jacobian and calculate covariance matrix. It guarantees that
6142  algorithm won't divide by zero during inversion, but skews
6143  error estimates a bit (fractional error is about 10^-9).
6144 
6145  However, we believe that this difference is insignificant for
6146  all practical purposes except for the situation when you want
6147  to compare ALGLIB results with "reference" implementation up
6148  to the last significant digit.
6149 
6150 NOTE: covariance matrix is estimated using correction for degrees
6151  of freedom (covariances are divided by N-M instead of dividing
6152  by N).
6153 
6154  -- ALGLIB --
6155  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
6156 *************************************************************************/
6157 void lsfitlinear(const real_1d_array &y, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6158 void lsfitlinear(const real_1d_array &y, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6159 
6160 
6161 /*************************************************************************
6162 Constained linear least squares fitting.
6163 
6164 This is variation of LSFitLinear(), which searchs for min|A*x=b| given
6165 that K additional constaints C*x=bc are satisfied. It reduces original
6166 task to modified one: min|B*y-d| WITHOUT constraints, then LSFitLinear()
6167 is called.
6168 
6169 IMPORTANT: if you want to perform polynomial fitting, it may be more
6170  convenient to use PolynomialFit() function. This function gives
6171  best results on polynomial problems and solves numerical
6172  stability issues which arise when you fit high-degree
6173  polynomials to your data.
6174 
6175  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
6176  !
6177  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
6178  ! of this function:
6179  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
6180  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
6181  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
6182  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
6183  !
6184  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
6185  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
6186  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
6187 
6188 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6189  Y - array[0..N-1] Function values in N points.
6190  FMatrix - a table of basis functions values, array[0..N-1, 0..M-1].
6191  FMatrix[I,J] - value of J-th basis function in I-th point.
6192  CMatrix - a table of constaints, array[0..K-1,0..M].
6193  I-th row of CMatrix corresponds to I-th linear constraint:
6194  CMatrix[I,0]*C[0] + ... + CMatrix[I,M-1]*C[M-1] = CMatrix[I,M]
6195  N - number of points used. N>=1.
6196  M - number of basis functions, M>=1.
6197  K - number of constraints, 0 <= K < M
6198  K=0 corresponds to absence of constraints.
6199 
6200 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6201  Info - error code:
6202  * -4 internal SVD decomposition subroutine failed (very
6203  rare and for degenerate systems only)
6204  * -3 either too many constraints (M or more),
6205  degenerate constraints (some constraints are
6206  repetead twice) or inconsistent constraints were
6207  specified.
6208  * 1 task is solved
6209  C - decomposition coefficients, array[0..M-1]
6210  Rep - fitting report. Following fields are set:
6211  * R2 non-adjusted coefficient of determination
6212  (non-weighted)
6213  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
6214  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
6215  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
6216  * MaxError maximum error
6217  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
6218 
6219 IMPORTANT:
6220  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
6221 
6222 ERRORS IN PARAMETERS
6223 
6224 This solver also calculates different kinds of errors in parameters and
6225 fills corresponding fields of report:
6226 * Rep.CovPar covariance matrix for parameters, array[K,K].
6227 * Rep.ErrPar errors in parameters, array[K],
6228  errpar = sqrt(diag(CovPar))
6229 * Rep.ErrCurve vector of fit errors - standard deviations of empirical
6230  best-fit curve from "ideal" best-fit curve built with
6231  infinite number of samples, array[N].
6232  errcurve = sqrt(diag(F*CovPar*F')),
6233  where F is functions matrix.
6234 * Rep.Noise vector of per-point estimates of noise, array[N]
6235 
6236 IMPORTANT: errors in parameters are calculated without taking into
6237  account boundary/linear constraints! Presence of constraints
6238  changes distribution of errors, but there is no easy way to
6239  account for constraints when you calculate covariance matrix.
6240 
6241 NOTE: noise in the data is estimated as follows:
6242  * for fitting without user-supplied weights all points are
6243  assumed to have same level of noise, which is estimated from
6244  the data
6245  * for fitting with user-supplied weights we assume that noise
6246  level in I-th point is inversely proportional to Ith weight.
6247  Coefficient of proportionality is estimated from the data.
6248 
6249 NOTE: we apply small amount of regularization when we invert squared
6250  Jacobian and calculate covariance matrix. It guarantees that
6251  algorithm won't divide by zero during inversion, but skews
6252  error estimates a bit (fractional error is about 10^-9).
6253 
6254  However, we believe that this difference is insignificant for
6255  all practical purposes except for the situation when you want
6256  to compare ALGLIB results with "reference" implementation up
6257  to the last significant digit.
6258 
6259 NOTE: covariance matrix is estimated using correction for degrees
6260  of freedom (covariances are divided by N-M instead of dividing
6261  by N).
6262 
6263  -- ALGLIB --
6264  Copyright 07.09.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
6265 *************************************************************************/
6266 void lsfitlinearc(const real_1d_array &y, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, const real_2d_array &cmatrix, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6267 void lsfitlinearc(const real_1d_array &y, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, const real_2d_array &cmatrix, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6268 
6269 
6270 /*************************************************************************
6271 Weighted nonlinear least squares fitting using function values only.
6272 
6273 Combination of numerical differentiation and secant updates is used to
6274 obtain function Jacobian.
6275 
6276 Nonlinear task min(F(c)) is solved, where
6277 
6278  F(c) = (w[0]*(f(c,x[0])-y[0]))^2 + ... + (w[n-1]*(f(c,x[n-1])-y[n-1]))^2,
6279 
6280  * N is a number of points,
6281  * M is a dimension of a space points belong to,
6282  * K is a dimension of a space of parameters being fitted,
6283  * w is an N-dimensional vector of weight coefficients,
6284  * x is a set of N points, each of them is an M-dimensional vector,
6285  * c is a K-dimensional vector of parameters being fitted
6286 
6287 This subroutine uses only f(c,x[i]).
6288 
6289 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6290  X - array[0..N-1,0..M-1], points (one row = one point)
6291  Y - array[0..N-1], function values.
6292  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
6293  C - array[0..K-1], initial approximation to the solution,
6294  N - number of points, N>1
6295  M - dimension of space
6296  K - number of parameters being fitted
6297  DiffStep- numerical differentiation step;
6298  should not be very small or large;
6299  large = loss of accuracy
6300  small = growth of round-off errors
6301 
6302 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6303  State - structure which stores algorithm state
6304 
6305  -- ALGLIB --
6306  Copyright 18.10.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6307 *************************************************************************/
6308 void lsfitcreatewf(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, const double diffstep, lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6309 void lsfitcreatewf(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &c, const double diffstep, lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6310 
6311 
6312 /*************************************************************************
6313 Nonlinear least squares fitting using function values only.
6314 
6315 Combination of numerical differentiation and secant updates is used to
6316 obtain function Jacobian.
6317 
6318 Nonlinear task min(F(c)) is solved, where
6319 
6320  F(c) = (f(c,x[0])-y[0])^2 + ... + (f(c,x[n-1])-y[n-1])^2,
6321 
6322  * N is a number of points,
6323  * M is a dimension of a space points belong to,
6324  * K is a dimension of a space of parameters being fitted,
6325  * w is an N-dimensional vector of weight coefficients,
6326  * x is a set of N points, each of them is an M-dimensional vector,
6327  * c is a K-dimensional vector of parameters being fitted
6328 
6329 This subroutine uses only f(c,x[i]).
6330 
6331 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6332  X - array[0..N-1,0..M-1], points (one row = one point)
6333  Y - array[0..N-1], function values.
6334  C - array[0..K-1], initial approximation to the solution,
6335  N - number of points, N>1
6336  M - dimension of space
6337  K - number of parameters being fitted
6338  DiffStep- numerical differentiation step;
6339  should not be very small or large;
6340  large = loss of accuracy
6341  small = growth of round-off errors
6342 
6343 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6344  State - structure which stores algorithm state
6345 
6346  -- ALGLIB --
6347  Copyright 18.10.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6348 *************************************************************************/
6349 void lsfitcreatef(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, const double diffstep, lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6350 void lsfitcreatef(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &c, const double diffstep, lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6351 
6352 
6353 /*************************************************************************
6354 Weighted nonlinear least squares fitting using gradient only.
6355 
6356 Nonlinear task min(F(c)) is solved, where
6357 
6358  F(c) = (w[0]*(f(c,x[0])-y[0]))^2 + ... + (w[n-1]*(f(c,x[n-1])-y[n-1]))^2,
6359 
6360  * N is a number of points,
6361  * M is a dimension of a space points belong to,
6362  * K is a dimension of a space of parameters being fitted,
6363  * w is an N-dimensional vector of weight coefficients,
6364  * x is a set of N points, each of them is an M-dimensional vector,
6365  * c is a K-dimensional vector of parameters being fitted
6366 
6367 This subroutine uses only f(c,x[i]) and its gradient.
6368 
6369 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6370  X - array[0..N-1,0..M-1], points (one row = one point)
6371  Y - array[0..N-1], function values.
6372  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
6373  C - array[0..K-1], initial approximation to the solution,
6374  N - number of points, N>1
6375  M - dimension of space
6376  K - number of parameters being fitted
6377  CheapFG - boolean flag, which is:
6378  * True if both function and gradient calculation complexity
6379  are less than O(M^2). An improved algorithm can
6380  be used which corresponds to FGJ scheme from
6381  MINLM unit.
6382  * False otherwise.
6383  Standard Jacibian-bases Levenberg-Marquardt algo
6384  will be used (FJ scheme).
6385 
6386 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6387  State - structure which stores algorithm state
6388 
6389 See also:
6390  LSFitResults
6391  LSFitCreateFG (fitting without weights)
6392  LSFitCreateWFGH (fitting using Hessian)
6393  LSFitCreateFGH (fitting using Hessian, without weights)
6394 
6395  -- ALGLIB --
6396  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
6397 *************************************************************************/
6398 void lsfitcreatewfg(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, const bool cheapfg, lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6399 void lsfitcreatewfg(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &c, const bool cheapfg, lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6400 
6401 
6402 /*************************************************************************
6403 Nonlinear least squares fitting using gradient only, without individual
6404 weights.
6405 
6406 Nonlinear task min(F(c)) is solved, where
6407 
6408  F(c) = ((f(c,x[0])-y[0]))^2 + ... + ((f(c,x[n-1])-y[n-1]))^2,
6409 
6410  * N is a number of points,
6411  * M is a dimension of a space points belong to,
6412  * K is a dimension of a space of parameters being fitted,
6413  * x is a set of N points, each of them is an M-dimensional vector,
6414  * c is a K-dimensional vector of parameters being fitted
6415 
6416 This subroutine uses only f(c,x[i]) and its gradient.
6417 
6418 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6419  X - array[0..N-1,0..M-1], points (one row = one point)
6420  Y - array[0..N-1], function values.
6421  C - array[0..K-1], initial approximation to the solution,
6422  N - number of points, N>1
6423  M - dimension of space
6424  K - number of parameters being fitted
6425  CheapFG - boolean flag, which is:
6426  * True if both function and gradient calculation complexity
6427  are less than O(M^2). An improved algorithm can
6428  be used which corresponds to FGJ scheme from
6429  MINLM unit.
6430  * False otherwise.
6431  Standard Jacibian-bases Levenberg-Marquardt algo
6432  will be used (FJ scheme).
6433 
6434 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6435  State - structure which stores algorithm state
6436 
6437  -- ALGLIB --
6438  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
6439 *************************************************************************/
6440 void lsfitcreatefg(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, const bool cheapfg, lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6441 void lsfitcreatefg(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &c, const bool cheapfg, lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6442 
6443 
6444 /*************************************************************************
6445 Weighted nonlinear least squares fitting using gradient/Hessian.
6446 
6447 Nonlinear task min(F(c)) is solved, where
6448 
6449  F(c) = (w[0]*(f(c,x[0])-y[0]))^2 + ... + (w[n-1]*(f(c,x[n-1])-y[n-1]))^2,
6450 
6451  * N is a number of points,
6452  * M is a dimension of a space points belong to,
6453  * K is a dimension of a space of parameters being fitted,
6454  * w is an N-dimensional vector of weight coefficients,
6455  * x is a set of N points, each of them is an M-dimensional vector,
6456  * c is a K-dimensional vector of parameters being fitted
6457 
6458 This subroutine uses f(c,x[i]), its gradient and its Hessian.
6459 
6460 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6461  X - array[0..N-1,0..M-1], points (one row = one point)
6462  Y - array[0..N-1], function values.
6463  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
6464  C - array[0..K-1], initial approximation to the solution,
6465  N - number of points, N>1
6466  M - dimension of space
6467  K - number of parameters being fitted
6468 
6469 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6470  State - structure which stores algorithm state
6471 
6472  -- ALGLIB --
6473  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
6474 *************************************************************************/
6475 void lsfitcreatewfgh(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6476 void lsfitcreatewfgh(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &c, lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6477 
6478 
6479 /*************************************************************************
6480 Nonlinear least squares fitting using gradient/Hessian, without individial
6481 weights.
6482 
6483 Nonlinear task min(F(c)) is solved, where
6484 
6485  F(c) = ((f(c,x[0])-y[0]))^2 + ... + ((f(c,x[n-1])-y[n-1]))^2,
6486 
6487  * N is a number of points,
6488  * M is a dimension of a space points belong to,
6489  * K is a dimension of a space of parameters being fitted,
6490  * x is a set of N points, each of them is an M-dimensional vector,
6491  * c is a K-dimensional vector of parameters being fitted
6492 
6493 This subroutine uses f(c,x[i]), its gradient and its Hessian.
6494 
6495 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6496  X - array[0..N-1,0..M-1], points (one row = one point)
6497  Y - array[0..N-1], function values.
6498  C - array[0..K-1], initial approximation to the solution,
6499  N - number of points, N>1
6500  M - dimension of space
6501  K - number of parameters being fitted
6502 
6503 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6504  State - structure which stores algorithm state
6505 
6506 
6507  -- ALGLIB --
6508  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
6509 *************************************************************************/
6510 void lsfitcreatefgh(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6511 void lsfitcreatefgh(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &c, lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6512 
6513 
6514 /*************************************************************************
6515 Stopping conditions for nonlinear least squares fitting.
6516 
6517 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6518  State - structure which stores algorithm state
6519  EpsX - >=0
6520  The subroutine finishes its work if on k+1-th iteration
6521  the condition |v|<=EpsX is fulfilled, where:
6522  * |.| means Euclidian norm
6523  * v - scaled step vector, v[i]=dx[i]/s[i]
6524  * dx - ste pvector, dx=X(k+1)-X(k)
6525  * s - scaling coefficients set by LSFitSetScale()
6526  MaxIts - maximum number of iterations. If MaxIts=0, the number of
6527  iterations is unlimited. Only Levenberg-Marquardt
6528  iterations are counted (L-BFGS/CG iterations are NOT
6529  counted because their cost is very low compared to that of
6530  LM).
6531 
6532 NOTE
6533 
6534 Passing EpsX=0 and MaxIts=0 (simultaneously) will lead to automatic
6535 stopping criterion selection (according to the scheme used by MINLM unit).
6536 
6537 
6538  -- ALGLIB --
6539  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
6540 *************************************************************************/
6541 void lsfitsetcond(const lsfitstate &state, const double epsx, const ae_int_t maxits, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6542 
6543 
6544 /*************************************************************************
6545 This function sets maximum step length
6546 
6547 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6548  State - structure which stores algorithm state
6549  StpMax - maximum step length, >=0. Set StpMax to 0.0, if you don't
6550  want to limit step length.
6551 
6552 Use this subroutine when you optimize target function which contains exp()
6553 or other fast growing functions, and optimization algorithm makes too
6554 large steps which leads to overflow. This function allows us to reject
6555 steps that are too large (and therefore expose us to the possible
6556 overflow) without actually calculating function value at the x+stp*d.
6557 
6558 NOTE: non-zero StpMax leads to moderate performance degradation because
6559 intermediate step of preconditioned L-BFGS optimization is incompatible
6560 with limits on step size.
6561 
6562  -- ALGLIB --
6563  Copyright 02.04.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6564 *************************************************************************/
6565 void lsfitsetstpmax(const lsfitstate &state, const double stpmax, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6566 
6567 
6568 /*************************************************************************
6569 This function turns on/off reporting.
6570 
6571 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6572  State - structure which stores algorithm state
6573  NeedXRep- whether iteration reports are needed or not
6574 
6575 When reports are needed, State.C (current parameters) and State.F (current
6576 value of fitting function) are reported.
6577 
6578 
6579  -- ALGLIB --
6580  Copyright 15.08.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6581 *************************************************************************/
6582 void lsfitsetxrep(const lsfitstate &state, const bool needxrep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6583 
6584 
6585 /*************************************************************************
6586 This function sets scaling coefficients for underlying optimizer.
6587 
6588 ALGLIB optimizers use scaling matrices to test stopping conditions (step
6589 size and gradient are scaled before comparison with tolerances). Scale of
6590 the I-th variable is a translation invariant measure of:
6591 a) "how large" the variable is
6592 b) how large the step should be to make significant changes in the function
6593 
6594 Generally, scale is NOT considered to be a form of preconditioner. But LM
6595 optimizer is unique in that it uses scaling matrix both in the stopping
6596 condition tests and as Marquardt damping factor.
6597 
6598 Proper scaling is very important for the algorithm performance. It is less
6599 important for the quality of results, but still has some influence (it is
6600 easier to converge when variables are properly scaled, so premature
6601 stopping is possible when very badly scalled variables are combined with
6602 relaxed stopping conditions).
6603 
6604 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6605  State - structure stores algorithm state
6606  S - array[N], non-zero scaling coefficients
6607  S[i] may be negative, sign doesn't matter.
6608 
6609  -- ALGLIB --
6610  Copyright 14.01.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
6611 *************************************************************************/
6612 void lsfitsetscale(const lsfitstate &state, const real_1d_array &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6613 
6614 
6615 /*************************************************************************
6616 This function sets boundary constraints for underlying optimizer
6617 
6618 Boundary constraints are inactive by default (after initial creation).
6619 They are preserved until explicitly turned off with another SetBC() call.
6620 
6621 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6622  State - structure stores algorithm state
6623  BndL - lower bounds, array[K].
6624  If some (all) variables are unbounded, you may specify
6625  very small number or -INF (latter is recommended because
6626  it will allow solver to use better algorithm).
6627  BndU - upper bounds, array[K].
6628  If some (all) variables are unbounded, you may specify
6629  very large number or +INF (latter is recommended because
6630  it will allow solver to use better algorithm).
6631 
6632 NOTE 1: it is possible to specify BndL[i]=BndU[i]. In this case I-th
6633 variable will be "frozen" at X[i]=BndL[i]=BndU[i].
6634 
6635 NOTE 2: unlike other constrained optimization algorithms, this solver has
6636 following useful properties:
6637 * bound constraints are always satisfied exactly
6638 * function is evaluated only INSIDE area specified by bound constraints
6639 
6640  -- ALGLIB --
6641  Copyright 14.01.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
6642 *************************************************************************/
6643 void lsfitsetbc(const lsfitstate &state, const real_1d_array &bndl, const real_1d_array &bndu, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6644 
6645 
6646 /*************************************************************************
6647 This function sets linear constraints for underlying optimizer
6648 
6649 Linear constraints are inactive by default (after initial creation).
6650 They are preserved until explicitly turned off with another SetLC() call.
6651 
6652 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6653  State - structure stores algorithm state
6654  C - linear constraints, array[K,N+1].
6655  Each row of C represents one constraint, either equality
6656  or inequality (see below):
6657  * first N elements correspond to coefficients,
6658  * last element corresponds to the right part.
6659  All elements of C (including right part) must be finite.
6660  CT - type of constraints, array[K]:
6661  * if CT[i]>0, then I-th constraint is C[i,*]*x >= C[i,n+1]
6662  * if CT[i]=0, then I-th constraint is C[i,*]*x = C[i,n+1]
6663  * if CT[i]<0, then I-th constraint is C[i,*]*x <= C[i,n+1]
6664  K - number of equality/inequality constraints, K>=0:
6665  * if given, only leading K elements of C/CT are used
6666  * if not given, automatically determined from sizes of C/CT
6667 
6668 IMPORTANT: if you have linear constraints, it is strongly recommended to
6669  set scale of variables with lsfitsetscale(). QP solver which is
6670  used to calculate linearly constrained steps heavily relies on
6671  good scaling of input problems.
6672 
6673 NOTE: linear (non-box) constraints are satisfied only approximately -
6674  there always exists some violation due to numerical errors and
6675  algorithmic limitations.
6676 
6677 NOTE: general linear constraints add significant overhead to solution
6678  process. Although solver performs roughly same amount of iterations
6679  (when compared with similar box-only constrained problem), each
6680  iteration now involves solution of linearly constrained QP
6681  subproblem, which requires ~3-5 times more Cholesky decompositions.
6682  Thus, if you can reformulate your problem in such way this it has
6683  only box constraints, it may be beneficial to do so.
6684 
6685  -- ALGLIB --
6686  Copyright 29.04.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
6687 *************************************************************************/
6688 void lsfitsetlc(const lsfitstate &state, const real_2d_array &c, const integer_1d_array &ct, const ae_int_t k, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6689 void lsfitsetlc(const lsfitstate &state, const real_2d_array &c, const integer_1d_array &ct, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6690 
6691 
6692 /*************************************************************************
6693 This function provides reverse communication interface
6694 Reverse communication interface is not documented or recommended to use.
6695 See below for functions which provide better documented API
6696 *************************************************************************/
6697 bool lsfititeration(const lsfitstate &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6698 
6699 
6700 /*************************************************************************
6701 This family of functions is used to launcn iterations of nonlinear fitter
6702 
6703 These functions accept following parameters:
6704  state - algorithm state
6705  func - callback which calculates function (or merit function)
6706  value func at given point x
6707  grad - callback which calculates function (or merit function)
6708  value func and gradient grad at given point x
6709  hess - callback which calculates function (or merit function)
6710  value func, gradient grad and Hessian hess at given point x
6711  rep - optional callback which is called after each iteration
6712  can be NULL
6713  ptr - optional pointer which is passed to func/grad/hess/jac/rep
6714  can be NULL
6715 
6716 NOTES:
6717 
6718 1. this algorithm is somewhat unusual because it works with parameterized
6719  function f(C,X), where X is a function argument (we have many points
6720  which are characterized by different argument values), and C is a
6721  parameter to fit.
6722 
6723  For example, if we want to do linear fit by f(c0,c1,x) = c0*x+c1, then
6724  x will be argument, and {c0,c1} will be parameters.
6725 
6726  It is important to understand that this algorithm finds minimum in the
6727  space of function PARAMETERS (not arguments), so it needs derivatives
6728  of f() with respect to C, not X.
6729 
6730  In the example above it will need f=c0*x+c1 and {df/dc0,df/dc1} = {x,1}
6731  instead of {df/dx} = {c0}.
6732 
6733 2. Callback functions accept C as the first parameter, and X as the second
6734 
6735 3. If state was created with LSFitCreateFG(), algorithm needs just
6736  function and its gradient, but if state was created with
6737  LSFitCreateFGH(), algorithm will need function, gradient and Hessian.
6738 
6739  According to the said above, there ase several versions of this
6740  function, which accept different sets of callbacks.
6741 
6742  This flexibility opens way to subtle errors - you may create state with
6743  LSFitCreateFGH() (optimization using Hessian), but call function which
6744  does not accept Hessian. So when algorithm will request Hessian, there
6745  will be no callback to call. In this case exception will be thrown.
6746 
6747  Be careful to avoid such errors because there is no way to find them at
6748  compile time - you can see them at runtime only.
6749 
6750  -- ALGLIB --
6751  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
6752 
6753 *************************************************************************/
6754 void lsfitfit(lsfitstate &state,
6755  void (*func)(const real_1d_array &c, const real_1d_array &x, double &func, void *ptr),
6756  void (*rep)(const real_1d_array &c, double func, void *ptr) = NULL,
6757  void *ptr = NULL,
6758  const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6778 void lsfitfit(lsfitstate &state,
6779  void (*func)(const real_1d_array &c, const real_1d_array &x, double &func, void *ptr),
6780  void (*grad)(const real_1d_array &c, const real_1d_array &x, double &func, real_1d_array &grad, void *ptr),
6781  void (*rep)(const real_1d_array &c, double func, void *ptr) = NULL,
6782  void *ptr = NULL,
6783  const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6809 void lsfitfit(lsfitstate &state,
6810  void (*func)(const real_1d_array &c, const real_1d_array &x, double &func, void *ptr),
6811  void (*grad)(const real_1d_array &c, const real_1d_array &x, double &func, real_1d_array &grad, void *ptr),
6812  void (*hess)(const real_1d_array &c, const real_1d_array &x, double &func, real_1d_array &grad, real_2d_array &hess, void *ptr),
6813  void (*rep)(const real_1d_array &c, double func, void *ptr) = NULL,
6814  void *ptr = NULL,
6815  const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6816 
6817 
6818 /*************************************************************************
6819 Nonlinear least squares fitting results.
6820 
6821 Called after return from LSFitFit().
6822 
6823 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6824  State - algorithm state
6825 
6826 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6827  Info - completion code:
6828  * -8 optimizer detected NAN/INF in the target
6829  function and/or gradient
6830  * -7 gradient verification failed.
6831  See LSFitSetGradientCheck() for more information.
6832  * -3 inconsistent constraints
6833  * 2 relative step is no more than EpsX.
6834  * 5 MaxIts steps was taken
6835  * 7 stopping conditions are too stringent,
6836  further improvement is impossible
6837  C - array[0..K-1], solution
6838  Rep - optimization report. On success following fields are set:
6839  * R2 non-adjusted coefficient of determination
6840  (non-weighted)
6841  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
6842  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
6843  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
6844  * MaxError maximum error
6845  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
6846  * WRMSError weighted rms error on the (X,Y).
6847 
6848 ERRORS IN PARAMETERS
6849 
6850 This solver also calculates different kinds of errors in parameters and
6851 fills corresponding fields of report:
6852 * Rep.CovPar covariance matrix for parameters, array[K,K].
6853 * Rep.ErrPar errors in parameters, array[K],
6854  errpar = sqrt(diag(CovPar))
6855 * Rep.ErrCurve vector of fit errors - standard deviations of empirical
6856  best-fit curve from "ideal" best-fit curve built with
6857  infinite number of samples, array[N].
6858  errcurve = sqrt(diag(J*CovPar*J')),
6859  where J is Jacobian matrix.
6860 * Rep.Noise vector of per-point estimates of noise, array[N]
6861 
6862 IMPORTANT: errors in parameters are calculated without taking into
6863  account boundary/linear constraints! Presence of constraints
6864  changes distribution of errors, but there is no easy way to
6865  account for constraints when you calculate covariance matrix.
6866 
6867 NOTE: noise in the data is estimated as follows:
6868  * for fitting without user-supplied weights all points are
6869  assumed to have same level of noise, which is estimated from
6870  the data
6871  * for fitting with user-supplied weights we assume that noise
6872  level in I-th point is inversely proportional to Ith weight.
6873  Coefficient of proportionality is estimated from the data.
6874 
6875 NOTE: we apply small amount of regularization when we invert squared
6876  Jacobian and calculate covariance matrix. It guarantees that
6877  algorithm won't divide by zero during inversion, but skews
6878  error estimates a bit (fractional error is about 10^-9).
6879 
6880  However, we believe that this difference is insignificant for
6881  all practical purposes except for the situation when you want
6882  to compare ALGLIB results with "reference" implementation up
6883  to the last significant digit.
6884 
6885 NOTE: covariance matrix is estimated using correction for degrees
6886  of freedom (covariances are divided by N-M instead of dividing
6887  by N).
6888 
6889  -- ALGLIB --
6890  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
6891 *************************************************************************/
6892 void lsfitresults(const lsfitstate &state, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6893 
6894 
6895 /*************************************************************************
6896 This subroutine turns on verification of the user-supplied analytic
6897 gradient:
6898 * user calls this subroutine before fitting begins
6899 * LSFitFit() is called
6900 * prior to actual fitting, for each point in data set X_i and each
6901  component of parameters being fited C_j algorithm performs following
6902  steps:
6903  * two trial steps are made to C_j-TestStep*S[j] and C_j+TestStep*S[j],
6904  where C_j is j-th parameter and S[j] is a scale of j-th parameter
6905  * if needed, steps are bounded with respect to constraints on C[]
6906  * F(X_i|C) is evaluated at these trial points
6907  * we perform one more evaluation in the middle point of the interval
6908  * we build cubic model using function values and derivatives at trial
6909  points and we compare its prediction with actual value in the middle
6910  point
6911  * in case difference between prediction and actual value is higher than
6912  some predetermined threshold, algorithm stops with completion code -7;
6913  Rep.VarIdx is set to index of the parameter with incorrect derivative.
6914 * after verification is over, algorithm proceeds to the actual optimization.
6915 
6916 NOTE 1: verification needs N*K (points count * parameters count) gradient
6917  evaluations. It is very costly and you should use it only for low
6918  dimensional problems, when you want to be sure that you've
6919  correctly calculated analytic derivatives. You should not use it
6920  in the production code (unless you want to check derivatives
6921  provided by some third party).
6922 
6923 NOTE 2: you should carefully choose TestStep. Value which is too large
6924  (so large that function behaviour is significantly non-cubic) will
6925  lead to false alarms. You may use different step for different
6926  parameters by means of setting scale with LSFitSetScale().
6927 
6928 NOTE 3: this function may lead to false positives. In case it reports that
6929  I-th derivative was calculated incorrectly, you may decrease test
6930  step and try one more time - maybe your function changes too
6931  sharply and your step is too large for such rapidly chanding
6932  function.
6933 
6934 NOTE 4: this function works only for optimizers created with LSFitCreateWFG()
6935  or LSFitCreateFG() constructors.
6936 
6937 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6938  State - structure used to store algorithm state
6939  TestStep - verification step:
6940  * TestStep=0 turns verification off
6941  * TestStep>0 activates verification
6942 
6943  -- ALGLIB --
6944  Copyright 15.06.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
6945 *************************************************************************/
6946 void lsfitsetgradientcheck(const lsfitstate &state, const double teststep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6947 #endif
6948 
6949 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_RBFV2) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
6950 
6951 #endif
6952 
6953 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_SPLINE2D) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
6954 /*************************************************************************
6955 This function serializes data structure to string.
6956 
6957 Important properties of s_out:
6958 * it contains alphanumeric characters, dots, underscores, minus signs
6959 * these symbols are grouped into words, which are separated by spaces
6960  and Windows-style (CR+LF) newlines
6961 * although serializer uses spaces and CR+LF as separators, you can
6962  replace any separator character by arbitrary combination of spaces,
6963  tabs, Windows or Unix newlines. It allows flexible reformatting of
6964  the string in case you want to include it into text or XML file.
6965  But you should not insert separators into the middle of the "words"
6966  nor you should change case of letters.
6967 * s_out can be freely moved between 32-bit and 64-bit systems, little
6968  and big endian machines, and so on. You can serialize structure on
6969  32-bit machine and unserialize it on 64-bit one (or vice versa), or
6970  serialize it on SPARC and unserialize on x86. You can also
6971  serialize it in C++ version of ALGLIB and unserialize in C# one,
6972  and vice versa.
6973 *************************************************************************/
6974 void spline2dserialize(spline2dinterpolant &obj, std::string &s_out);
6975 
6976 
6977 /*************************************************************************
6978 This function unserializes data structure from string.
6979 *************************************************************************/
6980 void spline2dunserialize(const std::string &s_in, spline2dinterpolant &obj);
6981 
6982 
6983 
6984 
6985 /*************************************************************************
6986 This function serializes data structure to C++ stream.
6987 
6988 Data stream generated by this function is same as string representation
6989 generated by string version of serializer - alphanumeric characters,
6990 dots, underscores, minus signs, which are grouped into words separated by
6991 spaces and CR+LF.
6992 
6993 We recommend you to read comments on string version of serializer to find
6994 out more about serialization of AlGLIB objects.
6995 *************************************************************************/
6996 void spline2dserialize(spline2dinterpolant &obj, std::ostream &s_out);
6997 
6998 
6999 /*************************************************************************
7000 This function unserializes data structure from stream.
7001 *************************************************************************/
7002 void spline2dunserialize(const std::istream &s_in, spline2dinterpolant &obj);
7003 
7004 
7005 /*************************************************************************
7006 This subroutine calculates the value of the bilinear or bicubic spline at
7007 the given point X.
7008 
7009 Input parameters:
7010  C - 2D spline object.
7011  Built by spline2dbuildbilinearv or spline2dbuildbicubicv.
7012  X, Y- point
7013 
7014 Result:
7015  S(x,y)
7016 
7017  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
7018  Copyright 05.07.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
7019 *************************************************************************/
7020 double spline2dcalc(const spline2dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7021 
7022

7024 This subroutine calculates the value of the bilinear or bicubic spline at
7025 the given point X and its derivatives.
7026

7029  X, Y- point
7030

7032  F - S(x,y)
7033  FX - dS(x,y)/dX
7034  FY - dS(x,y)/dY
7035  FXY - d2S(x,y)/dXdY
7036

7038  Copyright 05.07.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
7039 *************************************************************************/
7040 void spline2ddiff(const spline2dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, double &f, double &fx, double &fy, double &fxy, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7041 
7042 
7043 /*************************************************************************
7044 This subroutine calculates bilinear or bicubic vector-valued spline at the
7045 given point (X,Y).
7046 
7047 If you need just some specific component of vector-valued spline, you can
7048 use spline2dcalcvi() function.
7049 
7050 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7051  C - spline interpolant.
7052  X, Y- point
7053  F - output buffer, possibly preallocated array. In case array size
7054  is large enough to store result, it is not reallocated. Array
7055  which is too short will be reallocated
7056 
7057 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7058  F - array[D] (or larger) which stores function values
7059 
7060  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
7061  Copyright 01.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7062 *************************************************************************/
7063 void spline2dcalcvbuf(const spline2dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, real_1d_array &f, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7064 
7065

7067 This subroutine calculates specific component of vector-valued bilinear or
7068 bicubic spline at the given point (X,Y).

7072  X, Y- point
7073  I - component index, in [0,D). An exception is generated for out
7074  of range values.
7075 
7076 RESULT:
7077  value of I-th component
7078 
7079  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
7080  Copyright 01.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7081 *************************************************************************/
7082 double spline2dcalcvi(const spline2dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, const ae_int_t i, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7083 
7084 
7085 /*************************************************************************
7086 This subroutine calculates bilinear or bicubic vector-valued spline at the
7087 given point (X,Y).

7091  X, Y- point
7092 
7093 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:

7095  it is reallocated after call to this function. In case you
7096  want to reuse previously allocated F, you may use
7097  Spline2DCalcVBuf(), which reallocates F only when it is too
7098  small.
7099

7101  Copyright 16.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7102 *************************************************************************/
7103 void spline2dcalcv(const spline2dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, real_1d_array &f, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7104 
7105 
7106 /*************************************************************************

7108 bicubic vector-valued spline and its derivatives.

7114

7125 
7126 
7127 /*************************************************************************
7128 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the spline argument.
7129 
7130 Input parameters:
7131  C - spline interpolant
7132  AX, BX - transformation coefficients: x = A*t + B
7133  AY, BY - transformation coefficients: y = A*u + B
7134 Result:
7135  C - transformed spline
7136 
7137  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
7138  Copyright 30.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
7139 *************************************************************************/
7140 void spline2dlintransxy(const spline2dinterpolant &c, const double ax, const double bx, const double ay, const double by, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7141 
7142 
7143 /*************************************************************************
7144 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the spline.
7145 
7146 Input parameters:
7147  C - spline interpolant.
7148  A, B- transformation coefficients: S2(x,y) = A*S(x,y) + B
7149 
7150 Output parameters:
7151  C - transformed spline
7152 
7153  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
7154  Copyright 30.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
7155 *************************************************************************/

7164

7167

7171 void spline2dcopy(const spline2dinterpolant &c, spline2dinterpolant &cc, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7172 
7173 
7174 /*************************************************************************
7175 Bicubic spline resampling
7176 
7177 Input parameters:
7178  A - function values at the old grid,
7179  array[0..OldHeight-1, 0..OldWidth-1]
7180  OldHeight - old grid height, OldHeight>1
7181  OldWidth - old grid width, OldWidth>1
7182  NewHeight - new grid height, NewHeight>1
7183  NewWidth - new grid width, NewWidth>1
7184 
7185 Output parameters:
7186  B - function values at the new grid,
7187  array[0..NewHeight-1, 0..NewWidth-1]
7188 
7189  -- ALGLIB routine --
7190  15 May, 2007
7191  Copyright by Bochkanov Sergey
7192 *************************************************************************/
7193 void spline2dresamplebicubic(const real_2d_array &a, const ae_int_t oldheight, const ae_int_t oldwidth, real_2d_array &b, const ae_int_t newheight, const ae_int_t newwidth, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7194 
7195 
7196 /*************************************************************************
7197 Bilinear spline resampling
7198 
7199 Input parameters:
7200  A - function values at the old grid,
7201  array[0..OldHeight-1, 0..OldWidth-1]
7202  OldHeight - old grid height, OldHeight>1
7203  OldWidth - old grid width, OldWidth>1
7204  NewHeight - new grid height, NewHeight>1
7205  NewWidth - new grid width, NewWidth>1
7206 
7207 Output parameters:
7208  B - function values at the new grid,
7209  array[0..NewHeight-1, 0..NewWidth-1]
7210 
7211  -- ALGLIB routine --
7212  09.07.2007
7213  Copyright by Bochkanov Sergey
7214 *************************************************************************/
7215 void spline2dresamplebilinear(const real_2d_array &a, const ae_int_t oldheight, const ae_int_t oldwidth, real_2d_array &b, const ae_int_t newheight, const ae_int_t newwidth, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7216 
7217 
7218 /*************************************************************************
7219 This subroutine builds bilinear vector-valued spline.
7220 
7221 Input parameters:
7222  X - spline abscissas, array[0..N-1]
7223  Y - spline ordinates, array[0..M-1]
7224  F - function values, array[0..M*N*D-1]:
7225  * first D elements store D values at (X[0],Y[0])
7226  * next D elements store D values at (X[1],Y[0])
7227  * general form - D function values at (X[i],Y[j]) are stored
7228  at F[D*(J*N+I)...D*(J*N+I)+D-1].
7229  M,N - grid size, M>=2, N>=2
7230  D - vector dimension, D>=1
7231 
7232 Output parameters:
7233  C - spline interpolant
7234 
7235  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
7236  Copyright 16.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7237 *************************************************************************/
7238 void spline2dbuildbilinearv(const real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, const real_1d_array &f, const ae_int_t d, spline2dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7239 
7240 
7241 /*************************************************************************
7242 This subroutine builds bicubic vector-valued spline.
7243 
7244 Input parameters:
7245  X - spline abscissas, array[0..N-1]
7246  Y - spline ordinates, array[0..M-1]
7247  F - function values, array[0..M*N*D-1]:
7248  * first D elements store D values at (X[0],Y[0])
7249  * next D elements store D values at (X[1],Y[0])
7250  * general form - D function values at (X[i],Y[j]) are stored
7251  at F[D*(J*N+I)...D*(J*N+I)+D-1].
7252  M,N - grid size, M>=2, N>=2
7253  D - vector dimension, D>=1
7254 
7255 Output parameters:
7256  C - spline interpolant
7257 
7258  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
7259  Copyright 16.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7260 *************************************************************************/
7261 void spline2dbuildbicubicv(const real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, const real_1d_array &f, const ae_int_t d, spline2dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7262 
7263 
7264 /*************************************************************************
7265 This subroutine unpacks two-dimensional spline into the coefficients table
7266 
7267 Input parameters:
7268  C - spline interpolant.
7269 
7270 Result:
7271  M, N- grid size (x-axis and y-axis)
7272  D - number of components
7273  Tbl - coefficients table, unpacked format,
7274  D - components: [0..(N-1)*(M-1)*D-1, 0..19].
7275  For T=0..D-1 (component index), I = 0...N-2 (x index),
7276  J=0..M-2 (y index):
7277  K := T + I*D + J*D*(N-1)
7278 
7279  K-th row stores decomposition for T-th component of the
7280  vector-valued function
7281 
7282  Tbl[K,0] = X[i]
7283  Tbl[K,1] = X[i+1]
7284  Tbl[K,2] = Y[j]
7285  Tbl[K,3] = Y[j+1]
7286  Tbl[K,4] = C00
7287  Tbl[K,5] = C01
7288  Tbl[K,6] = C02
7289  Tbl[K,7] = C03
7290  Tbl[K,8] = C10
7291  Tbl[K,9] = C11
7292  ...
7293  Tbl[K,19] = C33
7294  On each grid square spline is equals to:
7295  S(x) = SUM(c[i,j]*(t^i)*(u^j), i=0..3, j=0..3)
7296  t = x-x[j]
7297  u = y-y[i]
7298 
7299  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
7300  Copyright 16.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7301 *************************************************************************/
7302 void spline2dunpackv(const spline2dinterpolant &c, ae_int_t &m, ae_int_t &n, ae_int_t &d, real_2d_array &tbl, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7303 
7304 
7305 /*************************************************************************
7306 This subroutine was deprecated in ALGLIB 3.6.0
7307 
7308 We recommend you to switch to Spline2DBuildBilinearV(), which is more
7309 flexible and accepts its arguments in more convenient order.
7310 
7311  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
7312  Copyright 05.07.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
7313 *************************************************************************/
7314 void spline2dbuildbilinear(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_2d_array &f, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t n, spline2dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7315 
7316 
7317 /*************************************************************************
7318 This subroutine was deprecated in ALGLIB 3.6.0
7319 
7320 We recommend you to switch to Spline2DBuildBicubicV(), which is more
7321 flexible and accepts its arguments in more convenient order.
7322 
7323  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
7324  Copyright 05.07.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
7325 *************************************************************************/
7326 void spline2dbuildbicubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_2d_array &f, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t n, spline2dinterpolant &c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7327 
7328 
7329 /*************************************************************************
7330 This subroutine was deprecated in ALGLIB 3.6.0
7331 
7332 We recommend you to switch to Spline2DUnpackV(), which is more flexible
7333 and accepts its arguments in more convenient order.
7334 
7335  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
7336  Copyright 29.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
7337 *************************************************************************/
7338 void spline2dunpack(const spline2dinterpolant &c, ae_int_t &m, ae_int_t &n, real_2d_array &tbl, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7339 
7340 
7341 /*************************************************************************
7342 This subroutine creates least squares solver used to fit 2D splines to
7343 irregularly sampled (scattered) data.
7344 
7345 Solver object is used to perform spline fits as follows:
7346 * solver object is created with spline2dbuildercreate() function
7347 * dataset is added with spline2dbuildersetpoints() function
7348 * fit area is chosen:
7349  * spline2dbuildersetarea() - for user-defined area
7350  * spline2dbuildersetareaauto() - for automatically chosen area
7351 * number of grid nodes is chosen with spline2dbuildersetgrid()
7352 * prior term is chosen with one of the following functions:
7353  * spline2dbuildersetlinterm() to set linear prior
7354  * spline2dbuildersetconstterm() to set constant prior
7355  * spline2dbuildersetzeroterm() to set zero prior
7356  * spline2dbuildersetuserterm() to set user-defined constant prior
7357 * solver algorithm is chosen with either:
7358  * spline2dbuildersetalgoblocklls() - BlockLLS algorithm, medium-scale problems
7359  * spline2dbuildersetalgofastddm() - FastDDM algorithm, large-scale problems
7360 * finally, fitting itself is performed with spline2dfit() function.
7361 
7362 Most of the steps above can be omitted, solver is configured with good
7363 defaults. The minimum is to call:
7364 * spline2dbuildercreate() to create solver object
7365 * spline2dbuildersetpoints() to specify dataset
7366 * spline2dbuildersetgrid() to tell how many nodes you need
7367 * spline2dfit() to perform fit
7368 
7369  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
7370  !
7371  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
7372  ! of this function:
7373  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
7374  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
7375  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
7376  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
7377  !
7378  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
7379  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
7380  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
7381 
7382 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7383  D - positive number, number of Y-components: D=1 for simple scalar
7384  fit, D>1 for vector-valued spline fitting.
7385 
7386 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7387  S - solver object
7388 
7389  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
7390  Copyright 29.01.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7391 *************************************************************************/
7392 void spline2dbuildercreate(const ae_int_t d, spline2dbuilder &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7393 
7394 
7395 /*************************************************************************
7396 This function sets constant prior term (model is a sum of bicubic spline
7397 and global prior, which can be linear, constant, user-defined constant or
7398 zero).
7399 
7400 Constant prior term is determined by least squares fitting.
7401 
7402 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7403  S - spline builder
7404  V - value for user-defined prior
7405 
7406  -- ALGLIB --
7407  Copyright 01.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7408 *************************************************************************/
7409 void spline2dbuildersetuserterm(const spline2dbuilder &state, const double v, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7410 
7411 
7412 /*************************************************************************
7413 This function sets linear prior term (model is a sum of bicubic spline and
7414 global prior, which can be linear, constant, user-defined constant or
7415 zero).
7416 
7417 Linear prior term is determined by least squares fitting.
7418 
7419 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7420  S - spline builder
7421 
7422  -- ALGLIB --
7423  Copyright 01.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7424 *************************************************************************/
7425 void spline2dbuildersetlinterm(const spline2dbuilder &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7426 
7427 
7428 /*************************************************************************
7429 This function sets constant prior term (model is a sum of bicubic spline
7430 and global prior, which can be linear, constant, user-defined constant or
7431 zero).
7432 
7433 Constant prior term is determined by least squares fitting.
7434 
7435 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7436  S - spline builder
7437 
7438  -- ALGLIB --
7439  Copyright 01.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7440 *************************************************************************/
7441 void spline2dbuildersetconstterm(const spline2dbuilder &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7442 
7443 
7444 /*************************************************************************
7445 This function sets zero prior term (model is a sum of bicubic spline and
7446 global prior, which can be linear, constant, user-defined constant or
7447 zero).
7448 
7449 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7450  S - spline builder
7451 
7452  -- ALGLIB --
7453  Copyright 01.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7454 *************************************************************************/
7455 void spline2dbuildersetzeroterm(const spline2dbuilder &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7456 
7457 
7458 /*************************************************************************
7459 This function adds dataset to the builder object.
7460 
7461 This function overrides results of the previous calls, i.e. multiple calls
7462 of this function will result in only the last set being added.
7463 
7464 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7465  S - spline 2D builder object
7466  XY - points, array[N,2+D]. One row corresponds to one point
7467  in the dataset. First 2 elements are coordinates, next
7468  D elements are function values. Array may be larger than
7469  specified, in this case only leading [N,NX+NY] elements
7470  will be used.
7471  N - number of points in the dataset
7472 
7473  -- ALGLIB --
7474  Copyright 05.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7475 *************************************************************************/
7476 void spline2dbuildersetpoints(const spline2dbuilder &state, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7477 
7478 
7479 /*************************************************************************
7480 This function sets area where 2D spline interpolant is built. "Auto" means
7481 that area extent is determined automatically from dataset extent.
7482 
7483 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7484  S - spline 2D builder object
7485 
7486  -- ALGLIB --
7487  Copyright 05.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7488 *************************************************************************/
7489 void spline2dbuildersetareaauto(const spline2dbuilder &state, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7490 
7491 
7492 /*************************************************************************
7493 This function sets area where 2D spline interpolant is built to
7494 user-defined one: [XA,XB]*[YA,YB]
7495 
7496 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7497  S - spline 2D builder object
7498  XA,XB - spatial extent in the first (X) dimension, XA<XB
7499  YA,YB - spatial extent in the second (Y) dimension, YA<YB
7500 
7501  -- ALGLIB --
7502  Copyright 05.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7503 *************************************************************************/
7504 void spline2dbuildersetarea(const spline2dbuilder &state, const double xa, const double xb, const double ya, const double yb, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7505 
7506 
7507 /*************************************************************************
7508 This function sets nodes count for 2D spline interpolant. Fitting is
7509 performed on area defined with one of the "setarea" functions; this one
7510 sets number of nodes placed upon the fitting area.
7511 
7512 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7513  S - spline 2D builder object
7514  KX - nodes count for the first (X) dimension; fitting interval
7515  [XA,XB] is separated into KX-1 subintervals, with KX nodes
7516  created at the boundaries.
7517  KY - nodes count for the first (Y) dimension; fitting interval
7518  [YA,YB] is separated into KY-1 subintervals, with KY nodes
7519  created at the boundaries.
7520 
7521 NOTE: at least 4 nodes is created in each dimension, so KX and KY are
7522  silently increased if needed.
7523 
7524  -- ALGLIB --
7525  Copyright 05.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7526 *************************************************************************/
7527 void spline2dbuildersetgrid(const spline2dbuilder &state, const ae_int_t kx, const ae_int_t ky, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7528 
7529 
7530 /*************************************************************************
7531 This function allows you to choose least squares solver used to perform
7532 fitting. This function sets solver algorithm to "FastDDM", which performs
7533 fast parallel fitting by splitting problem into smaller chunks and merging
7534 results together.
7535 
7536 This solver is optimized for large-scale problems, starting from 256x256
7537 grids, and up to 10000x10000 grids. Of course, it will work for smaller
7538 grids too.
7539 
7540 More detailed description of the algorithm is given below:
7541 * algorithm generates hierarchy of nested grids, ranging from ~16x16
7542  (topmost "layer" of the model) to ~KX*KY one (final layer). Upper layers
7543  model global behavior of the function, lower layers are used to model
7544  fine details. Moving from layer to layer doubles grid density.
7545 * fitting is started from topmost layer, subsequent layers are fitted
7546  using residuals from previous ones.
7547 * user may choose to skip generation of upper layers and generate only a
7548  few bottom ones, which will result in much better performance and
7549  parallelization efficiency, at the cost of algorithm inability to "patch"
7550  large holes in the dataset.
7551 * every layer is regularized using progressively increasing regularization
7552  coefficient; thus, increasing LambdaV penalizes fine details first,
7553  leaving lower frequencies almost intact for a while.
7554 * after fitting is done, all layers are merged together into one bicubic
7555  spline
7556 
7557 IMPORTANT: regularization coefficient used by this solver is different
7558  from the one used by BlockLLS. Latter utilizes nonlinearity
7559  penalty, which is global in nature (large regularization
7560  results in global linear trend being extracted); this solver
7561  uses another, localized form of penalty, which is suitable for
7562  parallel processing.
7563 
7564 Notes on memory and performance:
7565 * memory requirements: most memory is consumed during modeling of the
7566  higher layers; ~[512*NPoints] bytes is required for a model with full
7567  hierarchy of grids being generated. However, if you skip a few topmost
7568  layers, you will get nearly constant (wrt. points count and grid size)
7569  memory consumption.
7570 * serial running time: O(K*K)+O(NPoints) for a KxK grid
7571 * parallelism potential: good. You may get nearly linear speed-up when
7572  performing fitting with just a few layers. Adding more layers results in
7573  model becoming more global, which somewhat reduces efficiency of the
7574  parallel code.
7575 
7576  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
7577  !
7578  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
7579  ! of this function:
7580  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
7581  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
7582  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
7583  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
7584  !
7585  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
7586  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
7587  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
7588 
7589 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7590  S - spline 2D builder object
7591  NLayers - number of layers in the model:
7592  * NLayers>=1 means that up to chosen number of bottom
7593  layers is fitted
7594  * NLayers=0 means that maximum number of layers is chosen
7595  (according to current grid size)
7596  * NLayers<=-1 means that up to |NLayers| topmost layers is
7597  skipped
7598  Recommendations:
7599  * good "default" value is 2 layers
7600  * you may need more layers, if your dataset is very
7601  irregular and you want to "patch" large holes. For a
7602  grid step H (equal to AreaWidth/GridSize) you may expect
7603  that last layer reproduces variations at distance H (and
7604  can patch holes that wide); that higher layers operate
7605  at distances 2*H, 4*H, 8*H and so on.
7606  * good value for "bullletproof" mode is NLayers=0, which
7607  results in complete hierarchy of layers being generated.
7608  LambdaV - regularization coefficient, chosen in such a way that it
7609  penalizes bottom layers (fine details) first.
7610  LambdaV>=0, zero value means that no penalty is applied.
7611 
7612  -- ALGLIB --
7613  Copyright 05.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7614 *************************************************************************/
7615 void spline2dbuildersetalgofastddm(const spline2dbuilder &state, const ae_int_t nlayers, const double lambdav, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7616 
7617
