7618 /*************************************************************************
7619 This function allows you to choose least squares solver used to perform
7620 fitting. This function sets solver algorithm to "BlockLLS", which performs
7621 least squares fitting with fast sparse direct solver, with optional
7622 nonsmoothness penalty being applied.
7623 
7624 Nonlinearity penalty has the following form:
7625 
7626  [ ]
7627  P() ~ Lambda* integral[ (d2S/dx2)^2 + 2*(d2S/dxdy)^2 + (d2S/dy2)^2 ]dxdy
7628  [ ]
7629 
7630 here integral is calculated over entire grid, and "~" means "proportional"
7631 because integral is normalized after calcilation. Extremely large values
7632 of Lambda result in linear fit being performed.
7633 
7634 NOTE: this algorithm is the most robust and controllable one, but it is
7635  limited by 512x512 grids and (say) up to 1.000.000 points. However,
7636  ALGLIB has one more spline solver: FastDDM algorithm, which is
7637  intended for really large-scale problems (in 10M-100M range). FastDDM
7638  algorithm also has better parallelism properties.
7639 
7640 More information on BlockLLS solver:
7641 * memory requirements: ~[32*K^3+256*NPoints] bytes for KxK grid with
7642  NPoints-sized dataset
7643 * serial running time: O(K^4+NPoints)
7644 * parallelism potential: limited. You may get some sublinear gain when
7645  working with large grids (K's in 256..512 range)
7646 
7647  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
7648  !
7649  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
7650  ! of this function:
7651  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
7652  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
7653  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
7654  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
7655  !
7656  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
7657  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
7658  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
7659 
7660 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7661  S - spline 2D builder object
7662  LambdaNS- non-negative value:
7663  * positive value means that some smoothing is applied
7664  * zero value means that no smoothing is applied, and
7665  corresponding entries of design matrix are numerically
7666  zero and dropped from consideration.
7667 
7668  -- ALGLIB --
7669  Copyright 05.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7670 *************************************************************************/
7671 void spline2dbuildersetalgoblocklls(const spline2dbuilder &state, const double lambdans, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7672 
7673 
7674 /*************************************************************************
7675 This function allows you to choose least squares solver used to perform
7676 fitting. This function sets solver algorithm to "NaiveLLS".
7677 
7678 IMPORTANT: NaiveLLS is NOT intended to be used in real life code! This
7679  algorithm solves problem by generated dense (K^2)x(K^2+NPoints)
7680  matrix and solves linear least squares problem with dense
7681  solver.
7682 
7683  It is here just to test BlockLLS against reference solver
7684  (and maybe for someone trying to compare well optimized solver
7685  against straightforward approach to the LLS problem).
7686 
7687 More information on naive LLS solver:
7688 * memory requirements: ~[8*K^4+256*NPoints] bytes for KxK grid.
7689 * serial running time: O(K^6+NPoints) for KxK grid
7690 * when compared with BlockLLS, NaiveLLS has ~K larger memory demand and
7691  ~K^2 larger running time.
7692 
7693 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7694  S - spline 2D builder object
7695  LambdaNS- nonsmoothness penalty
7696 
7697  -- ALGLIB --
7698  Copyright 05.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7699 *************************************************************************/
7700 void spline2dbuildersetalgonaivells(const spline2dbuilder &state, const double lambdans, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7701 
7702 
7703 /*************************************************************************
7704 This function fits bicubic spline to current dataset, using current area/
7705 grid and current LLS solver.
7706 
7707  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
7708  !
7709  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
7710  ! of this function:
7711  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
7712  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
7713  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
7714  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
7715  !
7716  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
7717  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
7718  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
7719 
7720 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7721  State - spline 2D builder object
7722 
7723 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7724  S - 2D spline, fit result
7725  Rep - fitting report, which provides some additional info about
7726  errors, R2 coefficient and so on.
7727 
7728  -- ALGLIB --
7729  Copyright 05.02.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
7730 *************************************************************************/
7731 void spline2dfit(const spline2dbuilder &state, spline2dinterpolant &s, spline2dfitreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7732 #endif
7733 
7734 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_RBFV1) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
7735 
7736 #endif
7737 
7738 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_RBF) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
7739 /*************************************************************************
7740 This function serializes data structure to string.
7741 
7742 Important properties of s_out:
7743 * it contains alphanumeric characters, dots, underscores, minus signs
7744 * these symbols are grouped into words, which are separated by spaces
7745  and Windows-style (CR+LF) newlines
7746 * although serializer uses spaces and CR+LF as separators, you can
7747  replace any separator character by arbitrary combination of spaces,
7748  tabs, Windows or Unix newlines. It allows flexible reformatting of
7749  the string in case you want to include it into text or XML file.
7750  But you should not insert separators into the middle of the "words"
7751  nor you should change case of letters.
7752 * s_out can be freely moved between 32-bit and 64-bit systems, little
7753  and big endian machines, and so on. You can serialize structure on
7754  32-bit machine and unserialize it on 64-bit one (or vice versa), or
7755  serialize it on SPARC and unserialize on x86. You can also
7756  serialize it in C++ version of ALGLIB and unserialize in C# one,
7757  and vice versa.
7758 *************************************************************************/
7759 void rbfserialize(rbfmodel &obj, std::string &s_out);
7760 
7761 
7762 /*************************************************************************
7763 This function unserializes data structure from string.
7764 *************************************************************************/
7765 void rbfunserialize(const std::string &s_in, rbfmodel &obj);
7766 
7767 
7768 
7769 
7770 /*************************************************************************
7771 This function serializes data structure to C++ stream.
7772 
7773 Data stream generated by this function is same as string representation
7774 generated by string version of serializer - alphanumeric characters,
7775 dots, underscores, minus signs, which are grouped into words separated by
7776 spaces and CR+LF.
7777 
7778 We recommend you to read comments on string version of serializer to find
7779 out more about serialization of AlGLIB objects.
7780 *************************************************************************/
7781 void rbfserialize(rbfmodel &obj, std::ostream &s_out);
7782 
7783 
7784 /*************************************************************************
7785 This function unserializes data structure from stream.
7786 *************************************************************************/
7787 void rbfunserialize(const std::istream &s_in, rbfmodel &obj);
7788 
7789 
7790 /*************************************************************************
7791 This function creates RBF model for a scalar (NY=1) or vector (NY>1)
7792 function in a NX-dimensional space (NX>=1).
7793 
7794 Newly created model is empty. It can be used for interpolation right after
7795 creation, but it just returns zeros. You have to add points to the model,
7796 tune interpolation settings, and then call model construction function
7797 rbfbuildmodel() which will update model according to your specification.
7798 
7799 USAGE:
7800 1. User creates model with rbfcreate()
7801 2. User adds dataset with rbfsetpoints() (points do NOT have to be on a
7802  regular grid) or rbfsetpointsandscales().
7803 3. (OPTIONAL) User chooses polynomial term by calling:
7804  * rbflinterm() to set linear term
7805  * rbfconstterm() to set constant term
7806  * rbfzeroterm() to set zero term
7807  By default, linear term is used.
7808 4. User tweaks algorithm properties with rbfsetalgohierarchical() method
7809  (or chooses one of the legacy algorithms - QNN (rbfsetalgoqnn) or ML
7810  (rbfsetalgomultilayer)).
7811 5. User calls rbfbuildmodel() function which rebuilds model according to
7812  the specification
7813 6. User may call rbfcalc() to calculate model value at the specified point,
7814  rbfgridcalc() to calculate model values at the points of the regular
7815  grid. User may extract model coefficients with rbfunpack() call.
7816 
7817 IMPORTANT: we recommend you to use latest model construction algorithm -
7818  hierarchical RBFs, which is activated by rbfsetalgohierarchical()
7819  function. This algorithm is the fastest one, and most memory-
7820  efficient.
7821  However, it is incompatible with older versions of ALGLIB
7822  (pre-3.11). So, if you serialize hierarchical model, you will
7823  be unable to load it in pre-3.11 ALGLIB. Other model types (QNN
7824  and RBF-ML) are still backward-compatible.
7825 
7826 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7827  NX - dimension of the space, NX>=1
7828  NY - function dimension, NY>=1
7829 
7830 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7831  S - RBF model (initially equals to zero)
7832 
7833 NOTE 1: memory requirements. RBF models require amount of memory which is
7834  proportional to the number of data points. Some additional memory
7835  is allocated during model construction, but most of this memory is
7836  freed after model coefficients are calculated. Amount of this
7837  additional memory depends on model construction algorithm being
7838  used.
7839 
7840 NOTE 2: prior to ALGLIB version 3.11, RBF models supported only NX=2 or
7841  NX=3. Any attempt to create single-dimensional or more than
7842  3-dimensional RBF model resulted in exception.
7843 
7844  ALGLIB 3.11 supports any NX>0, but models created with NX!=2 and
7845  NX!=3 are incompatible with (a) older versions of ALGLIB, (b) old
7846  model construction algorithms (QNN or RBF-ML).
7847 
7848  So, if you create a model with NX=2 or NX=3, then, depending on
7849  specific model construction algorithm being chosen, you will (QNN
7850  and RBF-ML) or will not (HierarchicalRBF) get backward compatibility
7851  with older versions of ALGLIB. You have a choice here.
7852 
7853  However, if you create a model with NX neither 2 nor 3, you have
7854  no backward compatibility from the start, and you are forced to
7855  use hierarchical RBFs and ALGLIB 3.11 or later.
7856 
7857  -- ALGLIB --
7858  Copyright 13.12.2011, 20.06.2016 by Bochkanov Sergey
7859 *************************************************************************/
7860 void rbfcreate(const ae_int_t nx, const ae_int_t ny, rbfmodel &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7861 
7862 
7863 /*************************************************************************
7864 This function creates buffer structure which can be used to perform
7865 parallel RBF model evaluations (with one RBF model instance being
7866 used from multiple threads, as long as different threads use different
7867 instances of buffer).
7868 
7869 This buffer object can be used with rbftscalcbuf() function (here "ts"
7870 stands for "thread-safe", "buf" is a suffix which denotes function which
7871 reuses previously allocated output space).
7872 
7873 How to use it:
7874 * create RBF model structure with rbfcreate()
7875 * load data, tune parameters
7876 * call rbfbuildmodel()
7877 * call rbfcreatecalcbuffer(), once per thread working with RBF model (you
7878  should call this function only AFTER call to rbfbuildmodel(), see below
7879  for more information)
7880 * call rbftscalcbuf() from different threads, with each thread working
7881  with its own copy of buffer object.
7882 
7883 INPUT PARAMETERS
7884  S - RBF model
7885 
7886 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
7887  Buf - external buffer.
7888 
7889 
7890 IMPORTANT: buffer object should be used only with RBF model object which
7891  was used to initialize buffer. Any attempt to use buffer with
7892  different object is dangerous - you may get memory violation
7893  error because sizes of internal arrays do not fit to dimensions
7894  of RBF structure.
7895 
7896 IMPORTANT: you should call this function only for model which was built
7897  with rbfbuildmodel() function, after successful invocation of
7898  rbfbuildmodel(). Sizes of some internal structures are
7899  determined only after model is built, so buffer object created
7900  before model construction stage will be useless (and any
7901  attempt to use it will result in exception).
7902 
7903  -- ALGLIB --
7904  Copyright 02.04.2016 by Sergey Bochkanov
7905 *************************************************************************/
7906 void rbfcreatecalcbuffer(const rbfmodel &s, rbfcalcbuffer &buf, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7907 
7908 
7909 /*************************************************************************
7910 This function adds dataset.
7911 
7912 This function overrides results of the previous calls, i.e. multiple calls
7913 of this function will result in only the last set being added.
7914 
7915 IMPORTANT: ALGLIB version 3.11 and later allows you to specify a set of
7916  per-dimension scales. Interpolation radii are multiplied by the
7917  scale vector. It may be useful if you have mixed spatio-temporal
7918  data (say, a set of 3D slices recorded at different times).
7919  You should call rbfsetpointsandscales() function to use this
7920  feature.
7921 
7922 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7923  S - RBF model, initialized by rbfcreate() call.
7924  XY - points, array[N,NX+NY]. One row corresponds to one point
7925  in the dataset. First NX elements are coordinates, next
7926  NY elements are function values. Array may be larger than
7927  specified, in this case only leading [N,NX+NY] elements
7928  will be used.
7929  N - number of points in the dataset
7930 
7931 After you've added dataset and (optionally) tuned algorithm settings you
7932 should call rbfbuildmodel() in order to build a model for you.
7933 
7934 NOTE: dataset added by this function is not saved during model serialization.
7935  MODEL ITSELF is serialized, but data used to build it are not.
7936 
7937  So, if you 1) add dataset to empty RBF model, 2) serialize and
7938  unserialize it, then you will get an empty RBF model with no dataset
7939  being attached.
7940 
7941  From the other side, if you call rbfbuildmodel() between (1) and (2),
7942  then after (2) you will get your fully constructed RBF model - but
7943  again with no dataset attached, so subsequent calls to rbfbuildmodel()
7944  will produce empty model.
7945 
7946 
7947  -- ALGLIB --
7948  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
7949 *************************************************************************/
7950 void rbfsetpoints(const rbfmodel &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7951 void rbfsetpoints(const rbfmodel &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7952 
7953 
7954 /*************************************************************************
7955 This function adds dataset and a vector of per-dimension scales.
7956 
7957 It may be useful if you have mixed spatio-temporal data - say, a set of 3D
7958 slices recorded at different times. Such data typically require different
7959 RBF radii for spatial and temporal dimensions. ALGLIB solves this problem
7960 by specifying single RBF radius, which is (optionally) multiplied by the
7961 scale vector.
7962 
7963 This function overrides results of the previous calls, i.e. multiple calls
7964 of this function will result in only the last set being added.
7965 
7966 IMPORTANT: only HierarchicalRBF algorithm can work with scaled points. So,
7967  using this function results in RBF models which can be used in
7968  ALGLIB 3.11 or later. Previous versions of the library will be
7969  unable to unserialize models produced by HierarchicalRBF algo.
7970 
7971  Any attempt to use this function with RBF-ML or QNN algorithms
7972  will result in -3 error code being returned (incorrect
7973  algorithm).
7974 
7975 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7976  R - RBF model, initialized by rbfcreate() call.
7977  XY - points, array[N,NX+NY]. One row corresponds to one point
7978  in the dataset. First NX elements are coordinates, next
7979  NY elements are function values. Array may be larger than
7980  specified, in this case only leading [N,NX+NY] elements
7981  will be used.
7982  N - number of points in the dataset
7983  S - array[NX], scale vector, S[i]>0.
7984 
7985 After you've added dataset and (optionally) tuned algorithm settings you
7986 should call rbfbuildmodel() in order to build a model for you.
7987 
7988 NOTE: dataset added by this function is not saved during model serialization.
7989  MODEL ITSELF is serialized, but data used to build it are not.
7990 
7991  So, if you 1) add dataset to empty RBF model, 2) serialize and
7992  unserialize it, then you will get an empty RBF model with no dataset
7993  being attached.
7994 
7995  From the other side, if you call rbfbuildmodel() between (1) and (2),
7996  then after (2) you will get your fully constructed RBF model - but
7997  again with no dataset attached, so subsequent calls to rbfbuildmodel()
7998  will produce empty model.
7999 
8000 
8001  -- ALGLIB --
8002  Copyright 20.06.2016 by Bochkanov Sergey
8003 *************************************************************************/
8004 void rbfsetpointsandscales(const rbfmodel &r, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8005 void rbfsetpointsandscales(const rbfmodel &r, const real_2d_array &xy, const real_1d_array &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8006 
8007 
8008 /*************************************************************************
8009 DEPRECATED:since version 3.11 ALGLIB includes new RBF model construction
8010  algorithm, Hierarchical RBF. This algorithm is faster and
8011  requires less memory than QNN and RBF-ML. It is especially good
8012  for large-scale interpolation problems. So, we recommend you to
8013  consider Hierarchical RBF as default option.
8014 
8015 ==========================================================================
8016 
8017 This function sets RBF interpolation algorithm. ALGLIB supports several
8018 RBF algorithms with different properties.
8019 
8020 This algorithm is called RBF-QNN and it is good for point sets with
8021 following properties:
8022 a) all points are distinct
8023 b) all points are well separated.
8024 c) points distribution is approximately uniform. There is no "contour
8025  lines", clusters of points, or other small-scale structures.
8026 
8027 Algorithm description:
8028 1) interpolation centers are allocated to data points
8029 2) interpolation radii are calculated as distances to the nearest centers
8030  times Q coefficient (where Q is a value from [0.75,1.50]).
8031 3) after performing (2) radii are transformed in order to avoid situation
8032  when single outlier has very large radius and influences many points
8033  across all dataset. Transformation has following form:
8034  new_r[i] = min(r[i],Z*median(r[]))
8035  where r[i] is I-th radius, median() is a median radius across entire
8036  dataset, Z is user-specified value which controls amount of deviation
8037  from median radius.
8038 
8039 When (a) is violated, we will be unable to build RBF model. When (b) or
8040 (c) are violated, model will be built, but interpolation quality will be
8041 low. See http://www.alglib.net/interpolation/ for more information on this
8042 subject.
8043 
8044 This algorithm is used by default.
8045 
8046 Additional Q parameter controls smoothness properties of the RBF basis:
8047 * Q<0.75 will give perfectly conditioned basis, but terrible smoothness
8048  properties (RBF interpolant will have sharp peaks around function values)
8049 * Q around 1.0 gives good balance between smoothness and condition number
8050 * Q>1.5 will lead to badly conditioned systems and slow convergence of the
8051  underlying linear solver (although smoothness will be very good)
8052 * Q>2.0 will effectively make optimizer useless because it won't converge
8053  within reasonable amount of iterations. It is possible to set such large
8054  Q, but it is advised not to do so.
8055 
8056 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8057  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
8058  Q - Q parameter, Q>0, recommended value - 1.0
8059  Z - Z parameter, Z>0, recommended value - 5.0
8060 
8061 NOTE: this function has some serialization-related subtleties. We
8062  recommend you to study serialization examples from ALGLIB Reference
8063  Manual if you want to perform serialization of your models.
8064 
8065 
8066  -- ALGLIB --
8067  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8068 *************************************************************************/
8069 void rbfsetalgoqnn(const rbfmodel &s, const double q, const double z, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8070 void rbfsetalgoqnn(const rbfmodel &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8071 
8072 
8073 /*************************************************************************
8074 DEPRECATED:since version 3.11 ALGLIB includes new RBF model construction
8075  algorithm, Hierarchical RBF. This algorithm is faster and
8076  requires less memory than QNN and RBF-ML. It is especially good
8077  for large-scale interpolation problems. So, we recommend you to
8078  consider Hierarchical RBF as default option.
8079 
8080 ==========================================================================
8081 
8082 This function sets RBF interpolation algorithm. ALGLIB supports several
8083 RBF algorithms with different properties.
8084 
8085 This algorithm is called RBF-ML. It builds multilayer RBF model, i.e.
8086 model with subsequently decreasing radii, which allows us to combine
8087 smoothness (due to large radii of the first layers) with exactness (due
8088 to small radii of the last layers) and fast convergence.
8089 
8090 Internally RBF-ML uses many different means of acceleration, from sparse
8091 matrices to KD-trees, which results in algorithm whose working time is
8092 roughly proportional to N*log(N)*Density*RBase^2*NLayers, where N is a
8093 number of points, Density is an average density if points per unit of the
8094 interpolation space, RBase is an initial radius, NLayers is a number of
8095 layers.
8096 
8097 RBF-ML is good for following kinds of interpolation problems:
8098 1. "exact" problems (perfect fit) with well separated points
8099 2. least squares problems with arbitrary distribution of points (algorithm
8100  gives perfect fit where it is possible, and resorts to least squares
8101  fit in the hard areas).
8102 3. noisy problems where we want to apply some controlled amount of
8103  smoothing.
8104 
8105 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8106  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
8107  RBase - RBase parameter, RBase>0
8108  NLayers - NLayers parameter, NLayers>0, recommended value to start
8109  with - about 5.
8110  LambdaV - regularization value, can be useful when solving problem
8111  in the least squares sense. Optimal lambda is problem-
8112  dependent and require trial and error. In our experience,
8113  good lambda can be as large as 0.1, and you can use 0.001
8114  as initial guess.
8115  Default value - 0.01, which is used when LambdaV is not
8116  given. You can specify zero value, but it is not
8117  recommended to do so.
8118 
8119 TUNING ALGORITHM
8120 
8121 In order to use this algorithm you have to choose three parameters:
8122 * initial radius RBase
8123 * number of layers in the model NLayers
8124 * regularization coefficient LambdaV
8125 
8126 Initial radius is easy to choose - you can pick any number several times
8127 larger than the average distance between points. Algorithm won't break
8128 down if you choose radius which is too large (model construction time will
8129 increase, but model will be built correctly).
8130 
8131 Choose such number of layers that RLast=RBase/2^(NLayers-1) (radius used
8132 by the last layer) will be smaller than the typical distance between
8133 points. In case model error is too large, you can increase number of
8134 layers. Having more layers will make model construction and evaluation
8135 proportionally slower, but it will allow you to have model which precisely
8136 fits your data. From the other side, if you want to suppress noise, you
8137 can DECREASE number of layers to make your model less flexible.
8138 
8139 Regularization coefficient LambdaV controls smoothness of the individual
8140 models built for each layer. We recommend you to use default value in case
8141 you don't want to tune this parameter, because having non-zero LambdaV
8142 accelerates and stabilizes internal iterative algorithm. In case you want
8143 to suppress noise you can use LambdaV as additional parameter (larger
8144 value = more smoothness) to tune.
8145 
8146 TYPICAL ERRORS
8147 
8148 1. Using initial radius which is too large. Memory requirements of the
8149  RBF-ML are roughly proportional to N*Density*RBase^2 (where Density is
8150  an average density of points per unit of the interpolation space). In
8151  the extreme case of the very large RBase we will need O(N^2) units of
8152  memory - and many layers in order to decrease radius to some reasonably
8153  small value.
8154 
8155 2. Using too small number of layers - RBF models with large radius are not
8156  flexible enough to reproduce small variations in the target function.
8157  You need many layers with different radii, from large to small, in
8158  order to have good model.
8159 
8160 3. Using initial radius which is too small. You will get model with
8161  "holes" in the areas which are too far away from interpolation centers.
8162  However, algorithm will work correctly (and quickly) in this case.
8163 
8164 4. Using too many layers - you will get too large and too slow model. This
8165  model will perfectly reproduce your function, but maybe you will be
8166  able to achieve similar results with less layers (and less memory).
8167 
8168  -- ALGLIB --
8169  Copyright 02.03.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
8170 *************************************************************************/
8171 void rbfsetalgomultilayer(const rbfmodel &s, const double rbase, const ae_int_t nlayers, const double lambdav, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8172 void rbfsetalgomultilayer(const rbfmodel &s, const double rbase, const ae_int_t nlayers, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8173 
8174 
8175 /*************************************************************************
8176 This function sets RBF interpolation algorithm. ALGLIB supports several
8177 RBF algorithms with different properties.
8178 
8179 This algorithm is called Hierarchical RBF. It similar to its previous
8180 incarnation, RBF-ML, i.e. it also builds a sequence of models with
8181 decreasing radii. However, it uses more economical way of building upper
8182 layers (ones with large radii), which results in faster model construction
8183 and evaluation, as well as smaller memory footprint during construction.
8184 
8185 This algorithm has following important features:
8186 * ability to handle millions of points
8187 * controllable smoothing via nonlinearity penalization
8188 * support for NX-dimensional models with NX=1 or NX>3 (unlike QNN or RBF-ML)
8189 * support for specification of per-dimensional radii via scale vector,
8190  which is set by means of rbfsetpointsandscales() function. This feature
8191  is useful if you solve spatio-temporal interpolation problems, where
8192  different radii are required for spatial and temporal dimensions.
8193 
8194 Running times are roughly proportional to:
8195 * N*log(N)*NLayers - for model construction
8196 * N*NLayers - for model evaluation
8197 You may see that running time does not depend on search radius or points
8198 density, just on number of layers in the hierarchy.
8199 
8200 IMPORTANT: this model construction algorithm was introduced in ALGLIB 3.11
8201  and produces models which are INCOMPATIBLE with previous
8202  versions of ALGLIB. You can not unserialize models produced
8203  with this function in ALGLIB 3.10 or earlier.
8204 
8205 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8206  S - RBF model, initialized by rbfcreate() call
8207  RBase - RBase parameter, RBase>0
8208  NLayers - NLayers parameter, NLayers>0, recommended value to start
8209  with - about 5.
8210  LambdaNS- >=0, nonlinearity penalty coefficient, negative values are
8211  not allowed. This parameter adds controllable smoothing to
8212  the problem, which may reduce noise. Specification of non-
8213  zero lambda means that in addition to fitting error solver
8214  will also minimize LambdaNS*|S''(x)|^2 (appropriately
8215  generalized to multiple dimensions.
8216 
8217  Specification of exactly zero value means that no penalty
8218  is added (we do not even evaluate matrix of second
8219  derivatives which is necessary for smoothing).
8220 
8221  Calculation of nonlinearity penalty is costly - it results
8222  in several-fold increase of model construction time.
8223  Evaluation time remains the same.
8224 
8225  Optimal lambda is problem-dependent and requires trial
8226  and error. Good value to start from is 1e-5...1e-6,
8227  which corresponds to slightly noticeable smoothing of the
8228  function. Value 1e-2 usually means that quite heavy
8229  smoothing is applied.
8230 
8231 TUNING ALGORITHM
8232 
8233 In order to use this algorithm you have to choose three parameters:
8234 * initial radius RBase
8235 * number of layers in the model NLayers
8236 * penalty coefficient LambdaNS
8237 
8238 Initial radius is easy to choose - you can pick any number several times
8239 larger than the average distance between points. Algorithm won't break
8240 down if you choose radius which is too large (model construction time will
8241 increase, but model will be built correctly).
8242 
8243 Choose such number of layers that RLast=RBase/2^(NLayers-1) (radius used
8244 by the last layer) will be smaller than the typical distance between
8245 points. In case model error is too large, you can increase number of
8246 layers. Having more layers will make model construction and evaluation
8247 proportionally slower, but it will allow you to have model which precisely
8248 fits your data. From the other side, if you want to suppress noise, you
8249 can DECREASE number of layers to make your model less flexible (or specify
8250 non-zero LambdaNS).
8251 
8252 TYPICAL ERRORS
8253 
8254 1. Using too small number of layers - RBF models with large radius are not
8255  flexible enough to reproduce small variations in the target function.
8256  You need many layers with different radii, from large to small, in
8257  order to have good model.
8258 
8259 2. Using initial radius which is too small. You will get model with
8260  "holes" in the areas which are too far away from interpolation centers.
8261  However, algorithm will work correctly (and quickly) in this case.
8262 
8263  -- ALGLIB --
8264  Copyright 20.06.2016 by Bochkanov Sergey
8265 *************************************************************************/
8266 void rbfsetalgohierarchical(const rbfmodel &s, const double rbase, const ae_int_t nlayers, const double lambdans, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8267 
8268 
8269 /*************************************************************************
8270 This function sets linear term (model is a sum of radial basis functions
8271 plus linear polynomial). This function won't have effect until next call
8272 to RBFBuildModel().
8273 
8274 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8275  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
8276 
8277 NOTE: this function has some serialization-related subtleties. We
8278  recommend you to study serialization examples from ALGLIB Reference
8279  Manual if you want to perform serialization of your models.
8280 
8281  -- ALGLIB --
8282  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8283 *************************************************************************/
8284 void rbfsetlinterm(const rbfmodel &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8285 
8286 
8287 /*************************************************************************
8288 This function sets constant term (model is a sum of radial basis functions
8289 plus constant). This function won't have effect until next call to
8290 RBFBuildModel().
8291 
8292 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8293  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
8294 
8295 NOTE: this function has some serialization-related subtleties. We
8296  recommend you to study serialization examples from ALGLIB Reference
8297  Manual if you want to perform serialization of your models.
8298 
8299  -- ALGLIB --
8300  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8301 *************************************************************************/
8302 void rbfsetconstterm(const rbfmodel &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8303 
8304 
8305 /*************************************************************************
8306 This function sets zero term (model is a sum of radial basis functions
8307 without polynomial term). This function won't have effect until next call
8308 to RBFBuildModel().
8309 
8310 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8311  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
8312 
8313 NOTE: this function has some serialization-related subtleties. We
8314  recommend you to study serialization examples from ALGLIB Reference
8315  Manual if you want to perform serialization of your models.
8316 
8317  -- ALGLIB --
8318  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8319 *************************************************************************/
8320 void rbfsetzeroterm(const rbfmodel &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8321 
8322 
8323 /*************************************************************************
8324 This function sets basis function type, which can be:
8325 * 0 for classic Gaussian
8326 * 1 for fast and compact bell-like basis function, which becomes exactly
8327  zero at distance equal to 3*R (default option).
8328 
8329 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8330  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
8331  BF - basis function type:
8332  * 0 - classic Gaussian
8333  * 1 - fast and compact one
8334 
8335  -- ALGLIB --
8336  Copyright 01.02.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
8337 *************************************************************************/
8338 void rbfsetv2bf(const rbfmodel &s, const ae_int_t bf, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8339 
8340 
8341 /*************************************************************************
8342 This function sets stopping criteria of the underlying linear solver for
8343 hierarchical (version 2) RBF constructor.
8344 
8345 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8346  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
8347  MaxIts - this criterion will stop algorithm after MaxIts iterations.
8348  Typically a few hundreds iterations is required, with 400
8349  being a good default value to start experimentation.
8350  Zero value means that default value will be selected.
8351 
8352  -- ALGLIB --
8353  Copyright 01.02.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
8354 *************************************************************************/
8355 void rbfsetv2its(const rbfmodel &s, const ae_int_t maxits, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8356 
8357 
8358 /*************************************************************************
8359 This function sets support radius parameter of hierarchical (version 2)
8360 RBF constructor.
8361 
8362 Hierarchical RBF model achieves great speed-up by removing from the model
8363 excessive (too dense) nodes. Say, if you have RBF radius equal to 1 meter,
8364 and two nodes are just 1 millimeter apart, you may remove one of them
8365 without reducing model quality.
8366 
8367 Support radius parameter is used to justify which points need removal, and
8368 which do not. If two points are less than SUPPORT_R*CUR_RADIUS units of
8369 distance apart, one of them is removed from the model. The larger support
8370 radius is, the faster model construction AND evaluation are. However,
8371 too large values result in "bumpy" models.
8372 
8373 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8374  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
8375  R - support radius coefficient, >=0.
8376  Recommended values are [0.1,0.4] range, with 0.1 being
8377  default value.
8378 
8379  -- ALGLIB --
8380  Copyright 01.02.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
8381 *************************************************************************/
8382 void rbfsetv2supportr(const rbfmodel &s, const double r, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8383 
8384 
8385 /*************************************************************************
8386 This function builds RBF model and returns report (contains some
8387 information which can be used for evaluation of the algorithm properties).
8388 
8389 Call to this function modifies RBF model by calculating its centers/radii/
8390 weights and saving them into RBFModel structure. Initially RBFModel
8391 contain zero coefficients, but after call to this function we will have
8392 coefficients which were calculated in order to fit our dataset.
8393 
8394 After you called this function you can call RBFCalc(), RBFGridCalc() and
8395 other model calculation functions.
8396 
8397 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8398  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
8399  Rep - report:
8400  * Rep.TerminationType:
8401  * -5 - non-distinct basis function centers were detected,
8402  interpolation aborted; only QNN returns this
8403  error code, other algorithms can handle non-
8404  distinct nodes.
8405  * -4 - nonconvergence of the internal SVD solver
8406  * -3 incorrect model construction algorithm was chosen:
8407  QNN or RBF-ML, combined with one of the incompatible
8408  features - NX=1 or NX>3; points with per-dimension
8409  scales.
8410  * 1 - successful termination
8411 
8412  Fields which are set only by modern RBF solvers (hierarchical
8413  or nonnegative; older solvers like QNN and ML initialize these
8414  fields by NANs):
8415  * rep.rmserror - root-mean-square error at nodes
8416  * rep.maxerror - maximum error at nodes
8417 
8418  Fields are used for debugging purposes:
8419  * Rep.IterationsCount - iterations count of the LSQR solver
8420  * Rep.NMV - number of matrix-vector products
8421  * Rep.ARows - rows count for the system matrix
8422  * Rep.ACols - columns count for the system matrix
8423  * Rep.ANNZ - number of significantly non-zero elements
8424  (elements above some algorithm-determined threshold)
8425 
8426 NOTE: failure to build model will leave current state of the structure
8427 unchanged.
8428 
8429  -- ALGLIB --
8430  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8431 *************************************************************************/
8432 void rbfbuildmodel(const rbfmodel &s, rbfreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8433 
8434 
8435 /*************************************************************************
8436 This function calculates values of the RBF model in the given point.
8437 
8438 IMPORTANT: this function works only with modern (hierarchical) RBFs. It
8439  can not be used with legacy (version 1) RBFs because older RBF
8440  code does not support 1-dimensional models.
8441 
8442 This function should be used when we have NY=1 (scalar function) and NX=1
8443 (1-dimensional space). If you have 3-dimensional space, use rbfcalc3(). If
8444 you have 2-dimensional space, use rbfcalc3(). If you have general
8445 situation (NX-dimensional space, NY-dimensional function) you should use
8446 generic rbfcalc().
8447 
8448 If you want to perform parallel model evaluation from multiple threads,
8449 use rbftscalcbuf() with per-thread buffer object.
8450 
8451 This function returns 0.0 when:
8452 * model is not initialized
8453 * NX<>1
8454 * NY<>1
8455 
8456 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8457  S - RBF model
8458  X0 - X-coordinate, finite number
8459 
8460 RESULT:
8461  value of the model or 0.0 (as defined above)
8462 
8463  -- ALGLIB --
8464  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8465 *************************************************************************/
8466 double rbfcalc1(const rbfmodel &s, const double x0, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8467 
8468 
8469 /*************************************************************************
8470 This function calculates values of the RBF model in the given point.
8471 
8472 This function should be used when we have NY=1 (scalar function) and NX=2
8473 (2-dimensional space). If you have 3-dimensional space, use rbfcalc3(). If
8474 you have general situation (NX-dimensional space, NY-dimensional function)
8475 you should use generic rbfcalc().
8476 
8477 If you want to calculate function values many times, consider using
8478 rbfgridcalc2v(), which is far more efficient than many subsequent calls to
8479 rbfcalc2().
8480 
8481 If you want to perform parallel model evaluation from multiple threads,
8482 use rbftscalcbuf() with per-thread buffer object.
8483 
8484 This function returns 0.0 when:
8485 * model is not initialized
8486 * NX<>2
8487  *NY<>1
8488 
8489 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8490  S - RBF model
8491  X0 - first coordinate, finite number
8492  X1 - second coordinate, finite number
8493 
8494 RESULT:
8495  value of the model or 0.0 (as defined above)
8496 
8497  -- ALGLIB --
8498  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8499 *************************************************************************/
8500 double rbfcalc2(const rbfmodel &s, const double x0, const double x1, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8501 
8502 
8503 /*************************************************************************
8504 This function calculates value of the RBF model in the given point.
8505 
8506 This function should be used when we have NY=1 (scalar function) and NX=3
8507 (3-dimensional space). If you have 2-dimensional space, use rbfcalc2(). If
8508 you have general situation (NX-dimensional space, NY-dimensional function)
8509 you should use generic rbfcalc().
8510 
8511 If you want to calculate function values many times, consider using
8512 rbfgridcalc3v(), which is far more efficient than many subsequent calls to
8513 rbfcalc3().
8514 
8515 If you want to perform parallel model evaluation from multiple threads,
8516 use rbftscalcbuf() with per-thread buffer object.
8517 
8518 This function returns 0.0 when:
8519 * model is not initialized
8520 * NX<>3
8521  *NY<>1
8522 
8523 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8524  S - RBF model
8525  X0 - first coordinate, finite number
8526  X1 - second coordinate, finite number
8527  X2 - third coordinate, finite number
8528 
8529 RESULT:
8530  value of the model or 0.0 (as defined above)
8531 
8532  -- ALGLIB --
8533  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8534 *************************************************************************/
8535 double rbfcalc3(const rbfmodel &s, const double x0, const double x1, const double x2, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8536 
8537 
8538 /*************************************************************************
8539 This function calculates values of the RBF model at the given point.
8540 
8541 This is general function which can be used for arbitrary NX (dimension of
8542 the space of arguments) and NY (dimension of the function itself). However
8543 when you have NY=1 you may find more convenient to use rbfcalc2() or
8544 rbfcalc3().
8545 
8546 If you want to perform parallel model evaluation from multiple threads,
8547 use rbftscalcbuf() with per-thread buffer object.
8548 
8549 This function returns 0.0 when model is not initialized.
8550 
8551 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8552  S - RBF model
8553  X - coordinates, array[NX].
8554  X may have more than NX elements, in this case only
8555  leading NX will be used.
8556 
8557 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8558  Y - function value, array[NY]. Y is out-parameter and
8559  reallocated after call to this function. In case you want
8560  to reuse previously allocated Y, you may use RBFCalcBuf(),
8561  which reallocates Y only when it is too small.
8562 
8563  -- ALGLIB --
8564  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8565 *************************************************************************/
8566 void rbfcalc(const rbfmodel &s, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8567 
8568 
8569 /*************************************************************************
8570 This function calculates values of the RBF model at the given point.
8571 
8572 Same as rbfcalc(), but does not reallocate Y when in is large enough to
8573 store function values.
8574 
8575 If you want to perform parallel model evaluation from multiple threads,
8576 use rbftscalcbuf() with per-thread buffer object.
8577 
8578 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8579  S - RBF model
8580  X - coordinates, array[NX].
8581  X may have more than NX elements, in this case only
8582  leading NX will be used.
8583  Y - possibly preallocated array
8584 
8585 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8586  Y - function value, array[NY]. Y is not reallocated when it
8587  is larger than NY.
8588 
8589  -- ALGLIB --
8590  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8591 *************************************************************************/
8592 void rbfcalcbuf(const rbfmodel &s, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8593 
8594 
8595 /*************************************************************************
8596 This function calculates values of the RBF model at the given point, using
8597 external buffer object (internal temporaries of RBF model are not
8598 modified).
8599 
8600 This function allows to use same RBF model object in different threads,
8601 assuming that different threads use different instances of buffer
8602 structure.
8603 
8604 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8605  S - RBF model, may be shared between different threads
8606  Buf - buffer object created for this particular instance of RBF
8607  model with rbfcreatecalcbuffer().
8608  X - coordinates, array[NX].
8609  X may have more than NX elements, in this case only
8610  leading NX will be used.
8611  Y - possibly preallocated array
8612 
8613 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8614  Y - function value, array[NY]. Y is not reallocated when it
8615  is larger than NY.
8616 
8617  -- ALGLIB --
8618  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8619 *************************************************************************/
8620 void rbftscalcbuf(const rbfmodel &s, const rbfcalcbuffer &buf, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8621 
8622 
8623 /*************************************************************************
8624 This is legacy function for gridded calculation of RBF model.
8625 
8626 It is superseded by rbfgridcalc2v() and rbfgridcalc2vsubset() functions.
8627 
8628  -- ALGLIB --
8629  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8630 *************************************************************************/
8631 void rbfgridcalc2(const rbfmodel &s, const real_1d_array &x0, const ae_int_t n0, const real_1d_array &x1, const ae_int_t n1, real_2d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8632 
8633 
8634 /*************************************************************************
8635 This function calculates values of the RBF model at the regular grid,
8636 which has N0*N1 points, with Point[I,J] = (X0[I], X1[J]). Vector-valued
8637 RBF models are supported.
8638 
8639 This function returns 0.0 when:
8640 * model is not initialized
8641 * NX<>2
8642 
8643  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
8644  !
8645  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
8646  ! of this function:
8647  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
8648  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
8649  !
8650  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
8651  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
8652  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
8653 
8654 NOTE: Parallel processing is implemented only for modern (hierarchical)
8655  RBFs. Legacy version 1 RBFs (created by QNN or RBF-ML) are still
8656  processed serially.
8657 
8658 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8659  S - RBF model, used in read-only mode, can be shared between
8660  multiple invocations of this function from multiple
8661  threads.
8662 
8663  X0 - array of grid nodes, first coordinates, array[N0].
8664  Must be ordered by ascending. Exception is generated
8665  if the array is not correctly ordered.
8666  N0 - grid size (number of nodes) in the first dimension
8667 
8668  X1 - array of grid nodes, second coordinates, array[N1]
8669  Must be ordered by ascending. Exception is generated
8670  if the array is not correctly ordered.
8671  N1 - grid size (number of nodes) in the second dimension
8672 
8673 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8674  Y - function values, array[NY*N0*N1], where NY is a number of
8675  "output" vector values (this function supports vector-
8676  valued RBF models). Y is out-variable and is reallocated
8677  by this function.
8678  Y[K+NY*(I0+I1*N0)]=F_k(X0[I0],X1[I1]), for:
8679  * K=0...NY-1
8680  * I0=0...N0-1
8681  * I1=0...N1-1
8682 
8683 NOTE: this function supports weakly ordered grid nodes, i.e. you may have
8684  X[i]=X[i+1] for some i. It does not provide you any performance
8685  benefits due to duplication of points, just convenience and
8686  flexibility.
8687 
8688 NOTE: this function is re-entrant, i.e. you may use same rbfmodel
8689  structure in multiple threads calling this function for different
8690  grids.
8691 
8692 NOTE: if you need function values on some subset of regular grid, which
8693  may be described as "several compact and dense islands", you may
8694  use rbfgridcalc2vsubset().
8695 
8696  -- ALGLIB --
8697  Copyright 27.01.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
8698 *************************************************************************/
8699 void rbfgridcalc2v(const rbfmodel &s, const real_1d_array &x0, const ae_int_t n0, const real_1d_array &x1, const ae_int_t n1, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8700 
8701 
8702 /*************************************************************************
8703 This function calculates values of the RBF model at some subset of regular
8704 grid:
8705 * grid has N0*N1 points, with Point[I,J] = (X0[I], X1[J])
8706 * only values at some subset of this grid are required
8707 Vector-valued RBF models are supported.
8708 
8709 This function returns 0.0 when:
8710 * model is not initialized
8711 * NX<>2
8712 
8713  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
8714  !
8715  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
8716  ! of this function:
8717  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
8718  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
8719  !
8720  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
8721  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
8722  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
8723 
8724 NOTE: Parallel processing is implemented only for modern (hierarchical)
8725  RBFs. Legacy version 1 RBFs (created by QNN or RBF-ML) are still
8726  processed serially.
8727 
8728 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8729  S - RBF model, used in read-only mode, can be shared between
8730  multiple invocations of this function from multiple
8731  threads.
8732 
8733  X0 - array of grid nodes, first coordinates, array[N0].
8734  Must be ordered by ascending. Exception is generated
8735  if the array is not correctly ordered.
8736  N0 - grid size (number of nodes) in the first dimension
8737 
8738  X1 - array of grid nodes, second coordinates, array[N1]
8739  Must be ordered by ascending. Exception is generated
8740  if the array is not correctly ordered.
8741  N1 - grid size (number of nodes) in the second dimension
8742 
8743  FlagY - array[N0*N1]:
8744  * Y[I0+I1*N0] corresponds to node (X0[I0],X1[I1])
8745  * it is a "bitmap" array which contains False for nodes
8746  which are NOT calculated, and True for nodes which are
8747  required.
8748 
8749 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8750  Y - function values, array[NY*N0*N1*N2], where NY is a number
8751  of "output" vector values (this function supports vector-
8752  valued RBF models):
8753  * Y[K+NY*(I0+I1*N0)]=F_k(X0[I0],X1[I1]),
8754  for K=0...NY-1, I0=0...N0-1, I1=0...N1-1.
8755  * elements of Y[] which correspond to FlagY[]=True are
8756  loaded by model values (which may be exactly zero for
8757  some nodes).
8758  * elements of Y[] which correspond to FlagY[]=False MAY be
8759  initialized by zeros OR may be calculated. This function
8760  processes grid as a hierarchy of nested blocks and
8761  micro-rows. If just one element of micro-row is required,
8762  entire micro-row (up to 8 nodes in the current version,
8763  but no promises) is calculated.
8764 
8765 NOTE: this function supports weakly ordered grid nodes, i.e. you may have
8766  X[i]=X[i+1] for some i. It does not provide you any performance
8767  benefits due to duplication of points, just convenience and
8768  flexibility.
8769 
8770 NOTE: this function is re-entrant, i.e. you may use same rbfmodel
8771  structure in multiple threads calling this function for different
8772  grids.
8773 
8774  -- ALGLIB --
8775  Copyright 04.03.2016 by Bochkanov Sergey
8776 *************************************************************************/
8777 void rbfgridcalc2vsubset(const rbfmodel &s, const real_1d_array &x0, const ae_int_t n0, const real_1d_array &x1, const ae_int_t n1, const boolean_1d_array &flagy, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8778 
8779 
8780 /*************************************************************************
8781 This function calculates values of the RBF model at the regular grid,
8782 which has N0*N1*N2 points, with Point[I,J,K] = (X0[I], X1[J], X2[K]).
8783 Vector-valued RBF models are supported.
8784 
8785 This function returns 0.0 when:
8786 * model is not initialized
8787 * NX<>3
8788 
8789  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
8790  !
8791  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
8792  ! of this function:
8793  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
8794  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
8795  !
8796  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
8797  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
8798  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
8799 
8800 NOTE: Parallel processing is implemented only for modern (hierarchical)
8801  RBFs. Legacy version 1 RBFs (created by QNN or RBF-ML) are still
8802  processed serially.
8803 
8804 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8805  S - RBF model, used in read-only mode, can be shared between
8806  multiple invocations of this function from multiple
8807  threads.
8808 
8809  X0 - array of grid nodes, first coordinates, array[N0].
8810  Must be ordered by ascending. Exception is generated
8811  if the array is not correctly ordered.
8812  N0 - grid size (number of nodes) in the first dimension
8813 
8814  X1 - array of grid nodes, second coordinates, array[N1]
8815  Must be ordered by ascending. Exception is generated
8816  if the array is not correctly ordered.
8817  N1 - grid size (number of nodes) in the second dimension
8818 
8819  X2 - array of grid nodes, third coordinates, array[N2]
8820  Must be ordered by ascending. Exception is generated
8821  if the array is not correctly ordered.
8822  N2 - grid size (number of nodes) in the third dimension
8823 
8824 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8825  Y - function values, array[NY*N0*N1*N2], where NY is a number
8826  of "output" vector values (this function supports vector-
8827  valued RBF models). Y is out-variable and is reallocated
8828  by this function.
8829  Y[K+NY*(I0+I1*N0+I2*N0*N1)]=F_k(X0[I0],X1[I1],X2[I2]), for:
8830  * K=0...NY-1
8831  * I0=0...N0-1
8832  * I1=0...N1-1
8833  * I2=0...N2-1
8834 
8835 NOTE: this function supports weakly ordered grid nodes, i.e. you may have
8836  X[i]=X[i+1] for some i. It does not provide you any performance
8837  benefits due to duplication of points, just convenience and
8838  flexibility.
8839 
8840 NOTE: this function is re-entrant, i.e. you may use same rbfmodel
8841  structure in multiple threads calling this function for different
8842  grids.
8843 
8844 NOTE: if you need function values on some subset of regular grid, which
8845  may be described as "several compact and dense islands", you may
8846  use rbfgridcalc3vsubset().
8847 
8848  -- ALGLIB --
8849  Copyright 04.03.2016 by Bochkanov Sergey
8850 *************************************************************************/
8851 void rbfgridcalc3v(const rbfmodel &s, const real_1d_array &x0, const ae_int_t n0, const real_1d_array &x1, const ae_int_t n1, const real_1d_array &x2, const ae_int_t n2, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8852 
8853 
8854 /*************************************************************************
8855 This function calculates values of the RBF model at some subset of regular
8856 grid:
8857 * grid has N0*N1*N2 points, with Point[I,J,K] = (X0[I], X1[J], X2[K])
8858 * only values at some subset of this grid are required
8859 Vector-valued RBF models are supported.
8860 
8861 This function returns 0.0 when:
8862 * model is not initialized
8863 * NX<>3
8864 
8865  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
8866  !
8867  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
8868  ! of this function:
8869  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
8870  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
8871  !
8872  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
8873  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
8874  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
8875 
8876 NOTE: Parallel processing is implemented only for modern (hierarchical)
8877  RBFs. Legacy version 1 RBFs (created by QNN or RBF-ML) are still
8878  processed serially.
8879 
8880 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8881  S - RBF model, used in read-only mode, can be shared between
8882  multiple invocations of this function from multiple
8883  threads.
8884 
8885  X0 - array of grid nodes, first coordinates, array[N0].
8886  Must be ordered by ascending. Exception is generated
8887  if the array is not correctly ordered.
8888  N0 - grid size (number of nodes) in the first dimension
8889 
8890  X1 - array of grid nodes, second coordinates, array[N1]
8891  Must be ordered by ascending. Exception is generated
8892  if the array is not correctly ordered.
8893  N1 - grid size (number of nodes) in the second dimension
8894 
8895  X2 - array of grid nodes, third coordinates, array[N2]
8896  Must be ordered by ascending. Exception is generated
8897  if the array is not correctly ordered.
8898  N2 - grid size (number of nodes) in the third dimension
8899 
8900  FlagY - array[N0*N1*N2]:
8901  * Y[I0+I1*N0+I2*N0*N1] corresponds to node (X0[I0],X1[I1],X2[I2])
8902  * it is a "bitmap" array which contains False for nodes
8903  which are NOT calculated, and True for nodes which are
8904  required.
8905 
8906 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8907  Y - function values, array[NY*N0*N1*N2], where NY is a number
8908  of "output" vector values (this function supports vector-
8909  valued RBF models):
8910  * Y[K+NY*(I0+I1*N0+I2*N0*N1)]=F_k(X0[I0],X1[I1],X2[I2]),
8911  for K=0...NY-1, I0=0...N0-1, I1=0...N1-1, I2=0...N2-1.
8912  * elements of Y[] which correspond to FlagY[]=True are
8913  loaded by model values (which may be exactly zero for
8914  some nodes).
8915  * elements of Y[] which correspond to FlagY[]=False MAY be
8916  initialized by zeros OR may be calculated. This function
8917  processes grid as a hierarchy of nested blocks and
8918  micro-rows. If just one element of micro-row is required,
8919  entire micro-row (up to 8 nodes in the current version,
8920  but no promises) is calculated.
8921 
8922 NOTE: this function supports weakly ordered grid nodes, i.e. you may have
8923  X[i]=X[i+1] for some i. It does not provide you any performance
8924  benefits due to duplication of points, just convenience and
8925  flexibility.
8926 
8927 NOTE: this function is re-entrant, i.e. you may use same rbfmodel
8928  structure in multiple threads calling this function for different
8929  grids.
8930 
8931  -- ALGLIB --
8932  Copyright 04.03.2016 by Bochkanov Sergey
8933 *************************************************************************/
8934 void rbfgridcalc3vsubset(const rbfmodel &s, const real_1d_array &x0, const ae_int_t n0, const real_1d_array &x1, const ae_int_t n1, const real_1d_array &x2, const ae_int_t n2, const boolean_1d_array &flagy, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8935 
8936 
8937 /*************************************************************************
8938 This function "unpacks" RBF model by extracting its coefficients.
8939 
8940 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8941  S - RBF model
8942 
8943 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8944  NX - dimensionality of argument
8945  NY - dimensionality of the target function
8946  XWR - model information, array[NC,NX+NY+1].
8947  One row of the array corresponds to one basis function:
8948  * first NX columns - coordinates of the center
8949  * next NY columns - weights, one per dimension of the
8950  function being modelled
8951  For ModelVersion=1:
8952  * last column - radius, same for all dimensions of
8953  the function being modelled
8954  For ModelVersion=2:
8955  * last NX columns - radii, one per dimension
8956  NC - number of the centers
8957  V - polynomial term , array[NY,NX+1]. One row per one
8958  dimension of the function being modelled. First NX
8959  elements are linear coefficients, V[NX] is equal to the
8960  constant part.
8961  ModelVersion-version of the RBF model:
8962  * 1 - for models created by QNN and RBF-ML algorithms,
8963  compatible with ALGLIB 3.10 or earlier.
8964  * 2 - for models created by HierarchicalRBF, requires
8965  ALGLIB 3.11 or later
8966 
8967  -- ALGLIB --
8968  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
8969 *************************************************************************/
8970 void rbfunpack(const rbfmodel &s, ae_int_t &nx, ae_int_t &ny, real_2d_array &xwr, ae_int_t &nc, real_2d_array &v, ae_int_t &modelversion, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8971 
8972 
8973 /*************************************************************************
8974 This function returns model version.
8975 
8976 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8977  S - RBF model
8978 
8979 RESULT:
8980  * 1 - for models created by QNN and RBF-ML algorithms,
8981  compatible with ALGLIB 3.10 or earlier.
8982  * 2 - for models created by HierarchicalRBF, requires
8983  ALGLIB 3.11 or later
8984 
8985  -- ALGLIB --
8986  Copyright 06.07.2016 by Bochkanov Sergey
8987 *************************************************************************/
8988 ae_int_t rbfgetmodelversion(const rbfmodel &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8989 #endif
8990 
8991 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_INTCOMP) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
8992 /*************************************************************************
8993 This function is left for backward compatibility.
8994 Use fitspheremc() instead.
8995 
8996 
8997  -- ALGLIB --
8998  Copyright 14.04.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
8999 *************************************************************************/
9000 void nsfitspheremcc(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nx, real_1d_array &cx, double &rhi, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
9001 
9002 
9003 /*************************************************************************
9004 This function is left for backward compatibility.
9005 Use fitspheremi() instead.
9006 
9007  -- ALGLIB --
9008  Copyright 14.04.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
9009 *************************************************************************/
9010 void nsfitspheremic(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nx, real_1d_array &cx, double &rlo, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
9011 
9012 
9013 /*************************************************************************
9014 This function is left for backward compatibility.
9015 Use fitspheremz() instead.
9016 
9017  -- ALGLIB --
9018  Copyright 14.04.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
9019 *************************************************************************/
9020 void nsfitspheremzc(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nx, real_1d_array &cx, double &rlo, double &rhi, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
9021 
9022 
9023 /*************************************************************************
9024 This function is left for backward compatibility.
9025 Use fitspherex() instead.
9026 
9027  -- ALGLIB --
9028  Copyright 14.04.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
9029 *************************************************************************/
9030 void nsfitspherex(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nx, const ae_int_t problemtype, const double epsx, const ae_int_t aulits, const double penalty, real_1d_array &cx, double &rlo, double &rhi, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
9031 #endif
9032 }
9033
